AN ZOOR15302010497
DT Article
TI SEASONAL VARIATIONS OF JELLYFISHES AND SIPHONOPHORES IN THE FIXED
   STATIONS 10 MILES OFFSHORE OF LIBERTAD AND MANTA DURING 2013.
FT VARIACION ESTACIONAL DE LAS MEDUSAS Y SIFONOFOROS EN LAS ESTACIONES
   FIJAS 10 MILLAS COSTA AFUERA DE LA LIBERTAD Y MANTA DURANTE EL 2013.
AU Andrade, Carlos
SO Acta Oceanografica del Pacifico
VL 19
IS 2
PS 43-62
PD 2014
PY 2014
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 0
AB Population variations of two groups of cnidarian (jellyfish and
   siphonophores) collected in permanent stations 10 miles offshore La
   Libertad (02[degree]03'55''S - 81[degree]07'15''W) and Manta
   (0[degree]52'60''S - 80[degree]49'60''W) were analysed during 2013. The
   biomass values of jellyfish at La Libertad and Manta stations were
   greater in both wet and dry season at the vertical level. In this
   stratum on La Libertad during wet season 6 dominant species represented
   by both warm and cold water were evidenced by Aglaura hemistoma, Cunina
   globosa, Ectopleura dumortieri, Rhopalonema velatum, Pelagia noctiluca
   and juveniles of Liriope tetraphylla. During dry season at La Libertad
   and Manta stations 3 dominant species were registered, represented by
   adults of L. tetraphylla, A. hemistoma and S. bitentaculata. In the
   superficial layer of La Libertad the biomass of the cnidarian were
   lower, apearing in the wet season Pelagia noctiluca observed in surface
   Tropical waters with a mean SST of 27.1 [degree]C and 32.5 UPS mean
   salinity. While in Manta the dominant species were A. hemistoma and
   Eutonina scintillans, in the same body of water ATS with a mean SST of
   26.2[degree]C and 33 UPS mean salinity. During dry season on La Libertad
   and Manta were observed a mixed presence of warm and cold water species.
   On La Libertad station two dominant species A. hemistoma, observed on
   July and November, and adults of L. tetraphylla, observed in Superficial
   equatorial waters with a mean SST of 23.5[degree]C and 33.8 UPS mean
   salinity. In Manta station were observed four dominant species, A.
   hemistoma, R. velatum, S. bitentaculata y Obelia sp. in a mean SST of
   25.01[degree]C y 33.3 UPS mean salinity associated with Superficial
   equatorial waters. In the water column on La Libertad station 2 species
   of siphonophores were registered, Muggiaea atlantica and Lensia
   Conoidea, while on Manta station a combination of warm and cold waters
   was observed represented by N. bijuga and M. atlantica. In the dry
   season in La Libertad at surface level a combination of warm and cold
   water was evidenced by D. dispar and M. atlantica, in Manta 4 species
   associated with warm water as Chelophyes contorta, D. dispar, S. biloba
   and S. chuni were recorded. Vertically, in La Libertad were recorded A.
   elegans and M. atlantica in Manta were observed S. biloba and M.
   atlantica. At the surface level during wet season were reported 4
   dominant species typical in warm water, represented by A. okeni, N.
   bijuga, S. quadrivalvis and S. biloba, while in Manta Station were
   recorded S. biloba and S. quadrivalvis. Sea surface temperature in La
   Libertad presented an annual average of 24.6 [plus or minus] 2.04
   [degree]C and salinity of 33.4 [plus or minus] 0.76 PSU, secchi disk of
   12.6 [plus or minus] 3.02 m, while in Manta an average of 25.5 [plus or
   minus] 0.79 [degree]C was observed, salinity of 33.2 [plus or minus]
   0.73 PSU and secchi disk 14.3 [plus or minus] 2.6 m. The Shannon-Wiener
   index in the permanent Station of La Libertad at the surface level
   highlights the maximum diversity during dry season (1.76 bits), while in
   the vertical strata its maximum value was 2.51 bits for the wet season.
   In Manta Station, Shannon reported its maximum for the dry period with
   1.34 bits, while in the vertical stratum was almost similar. In the
   statistical analysis a one factor Anova was applied with a confidence
   interval of 95%, showing that the number of captured cnidarians depends
   on the climatic season the sample is recolected.
C1 Andrade, Carlos; Inst Oceanog Armada, Avda 25 Julio Base Naval Sur,Via
   Pto Maritimo, Guayaquil, Ecuador, Ecuador.
SC Zoology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology
SN 1010-4402
BD Ecology; Abiotic factors; Marine zones; Pacific Ocean
DE Hydromedusae; Siphonophorida [Biomass /  / seasonal variation]
   [Community structure /  / ] [Abiotic factors /  / ] [South Pacific /
   Ecuador, La Libertad & Manta / ]. 
TN Coelenterates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Cnidaria, Hydrozoa
OR Hydromedusae (Hydrozoa). 
   Siphonophorida (Hydrozoa).

PT J
AN ZOOR15312073323
DT Article
TI ['Benthic polychaetes of the Gulf of Guayaquil'.]
FT 'Poliquetos bentonicos del Golfo de Guayaquil'.
AU Villamar, Francisco
SO Acta Oceanografica del Pacifico
VL 19
IS 1
PS 511-585
PD 2014
PY 2014
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 0
AB A total of 37 species of benthic polichaetes are identified, included in
   18 families and 27 genus. 18 species are well-known to in the Pacific
   eastern and 31 to the rest of the ecuatorian coast. 1414 specimens were
   collected of 13 samples of sediments of the Gulf of Guayaquil, at depths
   between 13 and 1598 in. Morphological variations are met. They were
   noticed in the respective diagnosis. One new species is described for
   the eastern tropical Pacific Ocean: Grubeulepis guayanensis.
C1 Villamar, Francisco; Inst Oceanog Armada, Div Biol Marina, POB 5940,
   Guayaquil, Ecuador, Ecuador.

PT J
AN ZOOR15301003893
DT Article
TI ON THE STATUS OF THE RADIOLARIAN GENERA LONCHOSPHAERA POPOFSKY, 1908 AND
   ARACHNOSTYLUS HOLLANDE AND ENJUMET, 1960.
AU Dumitrica, Paulian (Paulian.Dumitrica@unil.ch) 
SO Acta Palaeontologica Romaniae
VL 9
IS 2
PS 59-66
PD 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The article discusses the structural and taxonomic problems of the
   radiolarian genera Lonchosphaera Popofsky, 1908 and Arachnostylus
   Hollande and Enjumet, 1960. To solve them the author studied their
   initial skeletons that represent the main basis of radiolarian taxonomy
   at genus and suprageneric levels. He concluded that Arachnostylus is a
   younger synonym of Lonchosphaera and that this genus is a member of the
   family Excentroconchidae Hollande and Enjumet, 1960. The type species is
   re-described and two new species of Lonchosphaera (L. mariae n. sp. and
   L. cauleti n. sp.) are described herein.
C1 Dumitrica, Paulian; Dennigkofenweg 33, Gumligen, CH-3073, Switzerland,
   Switzerland.
EM Paulian.Dumitrica@unil.ch
SC Zoology
SN 1842-371X
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type material; Diagnosis; Synonymy;
   Taxonomy; Taxonomic position; Marine zones; Pacific Ocean; Geological
   time periods
DE Lonchosphaera cauleti [South Pacific / Peru / new species] [Caenozoic / 
   / ]. 
   Lonchosphaera mariae [South Pacific /  / new species] [Caenozoic /  / ].
   
TN Protozoans
ST Protozoa, Sarcomastigophora, Sarcodina, Actinopoda, Polycystinea
OR Lonchosphaera - Popofsky 1908 (Polycystinea): [Emended diagnosis, P. 63;
   Syn nov, Arachnostylus Hollande & Enjumet 1960, p. 63; Referred to,
   Excentroconchidae, p. 62]. 
   Lonchosphaera cauleti (Polycystinea): [Sp nov, Peru (marine), Caenozoic,
   P. 65; Fossil]. 
   Lonchosphaera mariae (Polycystinea): [Sp nov, South Pacific, Caenozoic,

PT J
AN ZOOR15403015148
DT Article
TI New records of helminth parasites in two species of river fish, province
   of Salta, Argentina.
FT Nuevos registros de helmintos parasitos en dos especies de peces
   fluviales, provincia de Salta, Argentina.
AU Ailan Choke, Lorena (lorenaailanchoke@gmail.com) 
   Ramallo, Geraldine
   Nieva, Lucia
   Davies, Dora
SO Acta Zoologica Lilloana
VL 58
IS 2
PS 253-257
PD 2014
PY 2014
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 0
AB Specimens of Trichomycterus spegazzini (Berg, 1897) and Jenynsia
   alternimaculata (Fowler, 1916) were collected in rivers and other water
   courses in the province of Salta. Both species were parasitized with the
   nematode Contracaecum sp. and Cucullanus (Cucullanus) pinnai pinnai
   (Travassos, Artigas & Pereira, 1928), the cestode Nomimoscolex sp. and
   unidentified metacestodes. However, the nematode Procamallanus
   (Spirocamallanus) pintoi (Kohn & Fernandes, 1988) and the digenean
   Genarchella sp. infected only specimens of Trichomycterus spegazzini
   (Berg, 1897). Moreover, the nematodes Procamallanus (Spirocamallanus)
   hilarii (Vaz & Pereira), 1934 and Rhabdochona (Rhabdochona) acuminata
   (Molin, 1860) were exclusive of specimens of Jenynsia alternimaculata
   (Fowler, 1916). In addition, the geographical distribution of the
   following species was enlarged: P. (S.) hilarii, P (S.) pintoi,
   Contracaecum sp., Rhabdochona (R.) acuminata, C. (C.) pinnai pinnai,
   Nomimoscolex sp. and Genarchella sp. Furthermore, we recorded
   Trichomycterus spegazzini and Jenynsia alternimaculata as new hosts for
   these species.
C1 Ailan Choke, Lorena; Univ Nacl Salta, Fac Ciencias Nat, Salta,
   Argentina, Argentina.
EM lorenaailanchoke@gmail.com

SN 0065-1729

PT J
AN ZOOR15308051556
DT Article
TI A revision of the Afrotropical species of Festucula Simon, 1901
   (Araneae: Salticidae).
AU Azarkina, Galina N. (urmakuz@gmail.com) 
   Foord, Stefan H.
SO African Invertebrates
VL 55
IS 2
PS 351-375
PD 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The Afrotropical species of the jumping spider genus Festucula Simon,
   1901 are revised. The genus now contains eight species. Three new
   species, F. haddadi sp. n. ([male][female] from South Africa) F. leroyae
   sp. n. ([male][female] from South Africa and Namibia) and F. robustus
   sp. n. ([male][female] from South Africa) F. australis Lawrence, 1927 is
   removed from its synonymy with F. festuculaeformis F. lineata Simon,
   1901, previously treated as nomen dubium, is revalidated and
   redescribed. Three further species, F. australis Lessert, 1933, F.
   festuculaeformis Lessert, 1933 and F. lawrencei Lessert, 1933, are
   redescribed.
C1 Azarkina, Galina N.; Russian Acad Sci, Siberian Branch, Frunze St 11,
   Novosibirsk, 630091, Russia, Russia.
EM urmakuz@gmail.com

SN 1681-5556

   359].

   synonymy, With Festucula australis Lawrence 1927, p. 359].

DT Article
TI Description of Potophila verrucosa, gen. n. et sp. n. (Diptera:
   Psychodidae: Psychodinae) from the West Usambara mountains, Tanzania.
AU Kvifte, Gunnar M. (gunnar.kvifte@um.uib.no) 
SO African Invertebrates
VL 55
IS 2
PS 413-417
PD 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Potophila verrucosa gen. n. et sp. n. is described based on a male from
   the West Usambara mountains, three times as long as the internode, an
   asymmetrical aedeagus and two parameres carrying rugose morphoventral
   appendages. Potophila verrucosa cannot be placed in a systematic context
   with certainty, but several characters are consistent with a
   relationship to the tribe Psychodini.

PT J
AN ZOOR15605035260
DT Article
TI In pursuit of Aricia morronensis Ribbe, 1910, a French species
   (Lepidoptera Lycaenidae).
FT A la poursuite d'Aricia morronensis Ribbe, 1910, une espece francaise
   (Lepidoptera Lycaenidae).
AU Descimon, Henri (descimon.henri@free.fr) 
SO Alexanor
VL 26
IS 5-8
PS 259-286
PD Jan 2014
PY 2014
LA French
U1 0
U2 0
AB We present here observations showing that the Lycaenid butterfly A.
   morronensis is present in French territory in three Pyrenean localities,
   where it has permanent populations. On the habitat concerned, it
   appeared to be associated with Erodium glandulosum (Geraniaceae), an
   Iberian endemic, and this was subsequently confirmed through breeding.
   The foodplant is to be found only on calcareous cliffs, very steep and
   of difficult access. The first locality, which was already known, is
   located in the Department Hautes-Pyrenees, close to the village of
   Gavarnie, the second one above Fabian in the Aure Valley, in the same
   region of the central Pyrenees, and the third one in the neighbourhood
   of Llo, in the Department Pyrenees-Orientales. The altitude of these
   localities lies between 1,400 and 2,000 m. A. morronensis does not
   appear to be associated with colonies of Erodium species closely related
   to E. glandulosum which occur in the Department Ariege, in the Corbieres
   region and even in the Department Alpes-Maritimes. Close examination of
   the collected butterflies showed that they belong to the subspecies
   ordesae Sagarra, 1930, of which boudranei Leraut should be a junior
   synonym.
C1 Descimon, Henri; 2 Blvd Rougemt, Marseille, F-13012, France, France.
EM descimon.henri@free.fr
SC Nutrition &Dietetics; Zoology
SN 0002-5208
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Synonymy; Nutrition; Diet; Zoogeography; Land
   zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Europe
DE Aricia morronensis [Food plants / Erodium glandulosum / Specificity; new
   record; systematics] [Zoogeography / Biogeography / ] [France /  /
   biology; distribution]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; Lepidopterans
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Lepidoptera, Glossata, Heteroneura,
   Papilionoidea, Lycaenidae
OR Aricia morronensis - Ribbe 1910 (Lycaenidae): [New record]. 
   Aricia morronensis ordesae - Sagarra 1930 (Lycaenidae): [Syn nov, Aricia
   morronensis boudranei Leraut 1999, p. 278]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15605035260
DA 2020-09-17

PT J
AN ZOOR15202010938
DT Article
TI New variety of Peridinium gatunense Nygaard f. kinnereta Krachmalny
   (Dinophyta) from Lake Kinneret (Israel).
AU Krakhmalnyi, A.F. (krakhmalnyy_a@mail.ru) 
   Wasser, S.P.
   Nevo, E.
   Kapitanchuk, L.M.
SO Algologia
VL 24
IS 2
PS 227-233
PD 2014
PY 2014
LA Russian
U1 0
U2 0
AB Diagnosis and description of the new variety of Peridinium gatunense
   var. kinnereta Krachmalny var. nov. from the lake Kinneret (Israel) are
   given. This variety differs from the type one by the morphology and
   position of the apical plates and sutures between them (1' [long dash]
   asymmetrical, large, its upper part is shifted to the left side of the
   body; 3' [long dash] wedge, elongated; 4' [long dash] almost
   rectangular, its length more than twice exceeds the width; sutures
   between 4' and 7'', 4' and 1' plates form an almost straight line;
   suture between 1' and 2' is considerably less than between1' and 4'
   plates, consequently the shape of the plate 1' is close to triangular).
   Comparison between P. gatunense var. kinnereta and the samples from the
   other regions where this species is recorded (fresh reservouars of the
   North, Central and South America, Central Africa, Europe and Tasmania)
   was carried out.
C1 Krakhmalnyi, A.F.; Institute for Evolutionary Ecology NAS of Ukraine,
   37, Lebedeva St., 03143 Kiev, Ukraine, Ukraine.
EM krakhmalnyy_a@mail.ru

   Eurasia; Asia

DT Article
TI A revision of the Italian and Corsican species of the genus Anillus
   Jacquelin du Val, 1851, with description of a new species (Coleoptera,
   Carabidae, Bembidiini, Anillina).
FT Revisione delle specie del genere Anillus Jacquelin du Val, 1851 di
   italia e corsica, con descrizione di una nuova specie (coleoptera,
   Carabidae, Bembidiini, Anillina).
AU Magrini, Paolo (duvalius@paolomagrini.it) 
SO Annali del Museo Civico di Storia Naturale "Giacomo Doria"
VL 106
PS 133-171
PD 2014
PY 2014
LA Italian
U1 0
U2 0
AB In this contribution, the author provided a review of the Italian and
   Corsican s pecies of the genus Anillus, mostly based on the features of
   the copulatory piece of endophallus, which shows constant characters in
   each of the treated taxa. On the contrary, the habitus of the
   representatives of this genus only in some cases shows reliable
   characters for a correct identification (larger size in Anillus angelae
   Magrini & Vanni, 1989, wide and depressed body in Anillus petriolii n.
   sp., for instance) so that the females specimens are hard to identify,
   in particular in cases of sympatric or syntopic species. Male genitalia
   of all species known so far from Italy and Corsica are illustrated, as
   well as the aedeagus of Anillus hypogaeus Aube, 1861 from Provence, the
   distribution of which reaches the geographical borders of Italy. Anillus
   petriolii new species is described from southern Latium, characterised
   by medium-large size, dilated body, aedeagus and copulatory piece
   different from those of all other known species. For the peculiar
   features of its aedeagus and copulatory piece, Anillus corsicus Perris,
   1869 is upgraded to distinct species, not subspecies of Anillus frater
   Aube, 1863, as previously treated in the current literature. Therefore,
   for their relationships illustrated in the text, Anillus genuensis
   Ganglbauer, 1900 and Anillus sardonius Jeannel, 1937 became subspecies
   of Anillus corsicus, not of A. frater. The following new synonymies are
   established: Anillus florentinus latistilus Jeannel, 1937 = Anillus
   corsicus corsicus Perris, 1869 and Anillus cirocchii Magrini & Vanni,
   1989 = Anillus angelae Magrini & Vanni, 1989 Anillus sekerai Reitter,
   1906 and Anillus strupii Meschnigg, 1944 are confirmed as junior
   synonyms of Anillus florentinus Dieck, 1869, and Anillus andreinii
   Jeannel, 1937 is confirmed as valid species. From the geographical point
   of view, two species have large ranges of distribution in Italy: Anillus
   florentinus is widely spread in Central Italy, the Padanian Plain and NE
   Italy, and Anillus bordonii Magrini & Vanni, 1993 is spread in the
   peninsular Italy; all other species of the genus present very small or
   punctiform ranges of distribution, in some cases very discontinuous.
C1 Magrini, Paolo; Via Gianfilippo Braccini 7, Florence, I-50141, Italy,
   Italy.
EM duvalius@paolomagrini.it

   position; Status; Key; Documentation; Publications; General morphology;
   Reproduction; Reproductive system; Zoogeography; Land zones; Palaearctic
   region; Eurasia; Europe; France

   Anillus frater corsicus - Perris 1869 (Carabidae): [Raised to, Anillus
   corsicus, p. 170].

   florentinus Dieck 1869, p. 171]. 
   Anillus strupii - Meschnigg 1944 (Carabidae): [Junior synonym, Of
   Anillus florentinus Dieck 1869, p. 171].

DT Article
TI A REVISION OF THE GENUS HADRUROIDES POCOCK, 1893 IN ECUADOR MAINLAND
   WITH THE DESCRIPTIONS OF THREE NEW SPECIES, THE DEFINITION OF A NEW
   SUBGENUS AND A NEW RECORD (SCORPIONES, CARABOCTONIDAE).
AU Rossi, Andrea (kaiserscorpion@gmail.com) 
SO Annali del Museo Civico di Storia Naturale "Giacomo Doria"
VL 106
PS 193-210
PD 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB The species of the genus Hadrztroides Pocock, 1893 in Ecuador mainland
   are revised. Three new species, related to H. maculatus (Thorell, 1876),
   are described: H. doriai, H. elenae and H. moreti. The genus Hadruroides
   is split into two subgenera: the nominal subgenus includes now only one
   species, H. charcasus (Karsch, 1879), whereas Loztrencoides n. subgen.
   includes all other known species. A new record of H. charcaszts in
   Ecuador is reported. The total number of Hadruroides species in Ecuador
   mainland is now raised to six and an identification key is given.

   Florence, Italy, Italy.

AB On the basis of materials collected in some Sicilian localities, new
   records are quoted for four species of the genus Idris, one of them not
   yet known for the island, and three new species (I. martinae, I.
   robertae and I. santinii), all belonging to the new "martinae group",
   are described and figured. Some notes on the genitalia of

DT Article
TI The genus Ovobathysciola Jeannel, 1924, endemic to Sardinia, with
   description of five new species (Coleoptera, Cholevidae, Leptodirini).
FT Il genere Ovobathysciola Jeannel, 1924, endemico di sardegna, con
   descrizione di cinque nuove specie (Coleoptera, Cholevidae,
   Leptodirini).
AU Casale, Achille (a_casale@libero.it) 
SO Annali del Museo Civico di Storia Naturale "Giacomo Doria"
VL 106
PS 223-289
PD 2014
PY 2014
LA Italian
U1 0
U2 0
AB The genus Ovobathysciola Jeannel, 1924, endemic to Sardinia, is reviewed
   and five new species are described. The genus currently includes
   subterranean cholevid beetles at different degrees of specialisation to
   the subterranean habitat, very interesting from taxonomic,
   biospeleological and biogeographic points of view. he following new
   species are described: in the O. majori species group (here proposed) O.
   castrimedusae n. sp. (caves near Asuni and Samugheo), O. deleddae n. sp.
   (Galtelli, caves of Tuttavista Mt.) and O. paeoniae n. sp. (caves in the
   "Supramonte" of Baunei); in the monospecific O. magrinii species group
   (here proposed) O. magrinii n. sp. (endogean on Gonare Mt., Orune,
   Nuoro); in the O. grafittii species group (here proposed) O.
   supramontana n. sp. (from caves in the "Supramonti" of Urzulei and
   Orgosolo). O. gestroi (Fairmaire, 1872), widely spread in caves of the
   so-called "Tacchi" of Ogliastra (SE Sardinia), is so far confirmed as an
   isolated taxon in a separate species group. Notes on taxonomy and
   biogeography of the genus, and a key for identification of all
   Ovobathysciola species known so far, are also provided.
C1 Casale, Achille; Univ Sassari, Dipartimento Sci Nat & Terr, Via Muroni
   25, Sassari, I-07100, Italy, Italy.

AN ZOOR15208047401
DT Article
TI Revision of the Sardinian species belonging to the genera Pselaphostomus
   Reitter, 1909 and Paramaurops Jeannel, 1948 (Coleoptera, Staphylinidae,
   Pselaphinae).
FT Revisione delle specie sarde dei generi Pselaphostomus Reitter, 1909 e
   Paramaurops Jeannel, 1948 (coleoptera, Staphylinidae, Pselaphinae).
AU Poggi, Roberto (rpoggi@comune.genova.it) 
   Fancello, Luca
   Leo, Piero
SO Annali del Museo Civico di Storia Naturale "Giacomo Doria"
VL 106
PS 291-332
PD 2014
PY 2014
LA Italian
U1 0
U2 1
AB All the Pselaphostomzts and Paramaurops species from Sardinia are
   revised and keyed; lectotypes, where necessary, are selected and aedeagi
   illustrated; some news about ecology and distribution is also given. The
   genus Pselaphostomus now includes eight species, four of which are new
   for science and described here: barbaricinus, domusnovae, focarilei and
   nuragicus. The hypothesis of the presence in Sardinia of Pselaphostomus
   revelierei, as well as of Pselaphostomus hiesenwetteri, is definitively
   rejected; the two taxa are exclusive of Corsica and their quotations for
   Sardinia can be attributed to old mistakes in labeling the specimens.
   Lastly, the synonymy of Pselaplzostomus sardous "var." banariensis
   (Dodero, 1919) versus Pselaphostomus sardous (Dodero, 1919) is
   confirmed. As refers to the genus Paramaurops, it now includes five
   species, one of which is here described as a new (geminus). Even in this
   case one taxon must be deleted from the list of Sardinian fauna:
   Paramaurops ancestralis (Binaghi, 1945), described from specimens
   erroneously labeled as collected in Sardinia, is simply a synonym of the
   Corsican endemic Paramaurops corsicus (Saulcy, 1874) (n. syn.). And,
   closing, the synonymies of Paramaurops sardous "ssp." aritzensis
   (Dodero, 1919) and Paramaurops sardous "var." microcephalzts (Dodero,
   1919) versus Paramaurops sardous (Saulcy, 1874) are confirmed.

TI RECORD OF THE GENUS COLOPTERUS ERICHSON, 1842 FROM SIKKIM - DARJEELING
   HIMALAYA, INDIA, WITH DESCRIPTION OF A NEW SPECIES (COLEOPTERA,
   NITIDULIDAE).
AU Pal, Tarun Kumar (tkpal51@rediffmail.com) 
   Dasgupta, Jhikmik
SO Annali del Museo Civico di Storia Naturale "Giacomo Doria"
VL 106
PS 333-346
PD 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Colopterus Erichson is recorded for the first time in India from the
   places of Sikkim and Darjeeling with a new species, viz., Colopterus
   robertopoggii. The genus and the new species are (re)described.

   India.

DT Article
TI Revision of the Amauropini from Piedmont (Coleoptera, Staphylinidae,
   Pselaphinae).
FT Revisione degli Amauropini del piemonte (coleoptera, Staphylinidae,
   Pselaphinae).
AU Poggi, Roberto (rpoggi@comune.genova.it) 
SO Annali del Museo Civico di Storia Naturale "Giacomo Doria"
VL 106
PS 361-381
PD 2014
PY 2014
LA Italian
U1 0
U2 1
AB The Amauropini inhabiting the Piedmont Region (N-W Italy), all endemic,
   are revised, figured and keyed. The genus Tropidamaurops Jeannel is
   confirmed as monospecific, with T. carinatus (Baudi di Selve) present in
   the section of Graian Alps. The genus Paramaurops Jeannel includes four
   species, from the Lepontine till the Cottian Alps: P. pirazzolii
   (Saulcy), P. alpinus (Dodero), P. vesulanus (Binaghi) (previously
   considered as subspecies of alpinus) and P. lanai n. sp. (from the high
   Stura di Lanzo Valley).
C1 Poggi, Roberto; Museo Civ Storia Nat Giacomo Doria, Via Brigata Liguria
   9, Genoa, I-16121, Italy, Italy.

PT J
AN ZOOR15507046656
DT Article
TI The Metatheria (Mammalia) from the "Mesopotamiense" (Late Miocene) of
   Entre Rios Province, Argentina, and a reconsideration of Philander
   entrerianus (Ameghino, 1899).
FT Los Metatheria (Mammalia) del "Mesopotamiense" (Mioceno Tardio) de la
   Provincia de Entre Rios, Argentina, y una reconsideracion de Philander
   entrerianus (Ameghino, 1899).
AU Goin, Francisco J. (fgoin@fcnym.unlp.edu.ar) 
   Noriega, Jorge I.
   de los Reyes, Martin
SO Asociacion Paleontologica Argentina Publicacion Especial
VL 14
IS 1
PS 109-117
PD 2014
PY 2014
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 0
AB Didelphimorphia and Sparassodonta are two of the most important lineages
   of Metatheria from the Neogene of South America. Both groups are
   recorded at the most basal sections of the Ituzaingo Formation (=
   "Mesopotamian") from the late Miocene (Huayquerian Age) of Entre Rios
   Province, Argentina. Earlier revisions dealing on the taxonomy of
   "Mesopotamian" metatherians focused on two subjects: (1) The specific
   status of some of the registered taxa and (2) the age of the fossil
   bearing sediments. The controversial identity of Philander entrerianus
   (Ameghino) and its temporal assignment, as well as that of the also
   recorded Chironectes sp., are good examples. The recent finding of new
   material belonging to Philander entrerianus allows to broaden the
   knowledge of the species and brings information about the age of
   sediments containing this and other taxa. Additionally, an upgraded
   summary of the species of Metatheria until now known from the
   "Mesopotamian" at Entre Ros Province is presented.
C1 Goin, Francisco J.; Division Paleontologia Vertebrados, Facultad de
   Ciencias Naturales y Museo, Paseo del Bosque s/n, B1900FWA La Plata,
   Argentina, Argentina.
EM fgoin@fcnym.unlp.edu.ar
SC Zoology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Paleontology
SN 0328-347X
BD Systematics; Taxonomy; Ecology; Land zones; Neotropical region; South
   America; Geological time periods; Caenozoic; Tertiary; Neogene
DE Metatheria [Ecology / Palaeoecology / Systematics] [Argentina / Entre
   Rios / ] [Miocene / Huayquerian / ]. 
TN Chordates; Mammals; Marsupials; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Mammalia, Marsupialia, Didelphidae
OR Metatheria (Mammalia): [Fossil]. 
   Philander entrerianus - (Ameghino 1899) (Didelphidae): [Status, P. 112].

PT J
AN ZOOR15606042382
DT Article
TI Analyses of morphology and mitochondrial DNA reveal a deep split within
   Parnassius charltonius Gray, (1853) (Lepidoptera, Papilionidae).
AU Churkin, Sergei V. (serghelios2007@yahoo.com) 
   Michel, Francois
SO Atalanta (Marktleuthen)
VL 45
PS 97-125
PD 2014
PY 2014
UR http://www.dfzs.info/contents_a.html
AW https://www.zobodat.at/pdf/Atalanta_45_0097-0125.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The article presents the synthesis of mtDNA, morphological and
   geographical data on different groups of taxa united under the name
   Parnassius charltonius Gray, (1853). Parnassius romanoviGrum-Grshimailo,
   1885 stat. nov. constitutes a bona species distributed in Alai, Ghissar,
   West Pamirs/Badakhshan and the SW edges of Tian-Shan. It is
   characterized by a reduced uncus (which is shorter than the tegumen) and
   a reduced third submarginal spot on the HW underside. The status of the
   taxa deckerti Verity, 1907 and voigti Bang-Haas, 1927 is questionable
   and needs further clarification. Especially the latter taxon could
   constitute a separate species. Comparative analysis of mtDNA and
   morphological data makes it possible to interpret the action of
   evolutionary factors in the history of the taxa.
C1 Churkin, Sergei V.; Jubileinyi pr., 14-168, Reutov, 143952, Moscow reg.,
   Russia, Russia.
EM serghelios2007@yahoo.com
SC Zoology; Anatomy &Morphology
SN 0171-0079

   and luminescence; Colour; Genetics; Evolution; Zoogeography

   implications] [Markings /  / ] [Molecular genetics / Mitochondrial
   genetic diversity / ] [Phylogeny / Phylogenetic relationships / ]
   [Zoogeography / Geographic range / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; Lepidopterans
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Lepidoptera, Glossata, Heteroneura,

   nov. and Oeneis hora stashkivi subspec. nov. Both were found at Uitas

TI Discovery of two new species of the 'elfin' butterflies from Shaanxi
   Province, China. (Lycaenidae, Theclinae).
AU Huang, Hao (cmdhhxx@hotmail.com) 
   Zhou, Li-Ping
SO Atalanta (Marktleuthen)
VL 45
PS 139-150
PD 2014
PY 2014
UR http://www.dfzs.info/contents_a.html
AW https://www.zobodat.at/pdf/Atalanta_45_0139-0150.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of the genus Cissatsuma Johnson, 1992 and a new species of
   the genus Ahlbergia Bryk, 1946 from Shaanxi province, China are
   described. The immature stages of these two species are briefly
   reported. All species of Ahlbergia, Novosatsuma and Cissatsuma with the
   [female] previously unknown are discussed, and the following taxonomic
   changes are given: Ahlbergia matusiki (Johnson, 1992) comb. nov. (=
   Novosatsuma matusiki Johnson, 1992); Cissatsuma pictila (Johnson, 1992)
   comb. nov. (= Ahlbergia pictila Johnson, 1992); Ahlbergia zhujianhuai
   Huang&Wu, 2003 syn. nov. (= A. circe montivaga Johnson, 1992).

DT Article
TI New or little known butterflies from China (Lepidoptera: Nymphalidae et
   Lycaenidae).
AU Huang, Hao (cmdhhxx@hotmail.com) 
SO Atalanta (Marktleuthen)
VL 45
PS 151-162
PD 2014
PY 2014
UR http://www.dfzs.info/contents_a.html
AW https://www.zobodat.at/pdf/Atalanta_45_0151-0162.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Lethe liyufeii spec. nov. is described from western Sichuan, Shaanxi and
   Henan. Lethe lisuae (Huang, 2002) comb. nov. (= Zophoessa lisuae Huang,
   2002) is rediscovered and confirmed to be a good species, with 5
   [male][male] more, collected from Gongshan area, NW Yunnan. Lethe
   neofasciata Lee, 1985 is discovered from Luojishan, Xichang area,
   southern Sichuan. Lethe ocellata Poujade, 1885 is discovered from
   southeastern Yunnan, with Lethe ocellata mon Yoshino, 2008 considered as
   a new junior synonym. Lethe yoshikoae (Koiwaya, 2011) comb. nov. (=
   Zophoessa yoshikoae Koiwaya, 2011) is rediscovered from West Tianmushan,
   Zhejiang Province, with 6 [male][male] collected. Zophoessa zhangi
   Huang, Wu&Yuan, 2003 is considered as a new junior synonym of Lethe leei
   Zhao&Wang, 2000 stat. nov. (= Lethe helle leei Zhao&Wang, 2000). Lethe
   yunnana bozanoi subspec. nov. is described from Shaanxi Province. Minois
   pauper liuyei subspec. nov. is described from Lijiang, NW Yunnan.
   Polycaena matuta shii subspec. nov. is described from central Tibet.

DT Article
TI Some new and little-known species of the genus Metathrinca Meyrick, 1908
   from Indonesia. (Lepidoptera, Xyloryctidae).
AU Lvovsky, Alexandr L. (Alexander.Lvovsky@zin.ru) 
SO Atalanta (Marktleuthen)
VL 45
PS 195-197
PD 2014
PY 2014
UR http://www.dfzs.info/contents_a.html
AW https://www.zobodat.at/pdf/Atalanta_45_0195-0197.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Five new species of the moth genus Metathrinca Meyrick, 1908 are
   described from Indonesia. The species Metathrinca coenophyes Diakonoff,
   (1968), described from the Philippines, is recorded for the first time
   from Java (Indonesia). The types of the new species are deposited in the
   National Museum of Natural History in Leiden, The Netherlands. One
   paratype of Metathrinca diakonoffi spec. nov. is deposited in the
   Zoological Institute of the Russian Academy of Sciences, Saint
   Petersburg.
C1 Lvovsky, Alexandr L.; Zoological Institute, Russian Academy of Sciences,
   Universitetskaya nab., 1, 199034 St.-Petersburg, Russia, Russia.
EM Alexander.Lvovsky@zin.ru
SC Zoology
SN 0171-0079
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Oriental region;
   Eurasia; Asia
DE Metathrinca coenophyes [Indonesia /  / New record]. 
   Metathrinca diakonoffi; Metathrinca halmahere; Metathrinca mentawirella;
   Metathrinca sampitella; Metathrinca wegneri [Indonesia /  / New
   species].

PT J
AN ZOOR15304024706
DT Article
TI ABUNDANCE AND DISTRIBUTION OF ENDOPARASITIC HELMINTHS IN ANABAS
   TESTUDINEUS (BLOCH, 1792) FROM A POLLUTED BEEL OF BANGLADESH.
AU Bhuiyan, Aminul Islam (aminul_islam89@yahoo.com) 
   Bushra, Jannatul
   Ghani, Osman
SO Bangladesh Journal of Zoology
VL 42
IS 1
PS 1-10
PD 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Abundance and distribution of the endoparasitic helminths in Anabas
   testudineus (collected from a polluted water body) was analyzed. Out of
   50 fish observed, 42 (84%) were parasitized by at least one species.
   Five metazoan endoparasites, one trematode (Neopecoelina
   saharanpuriensis) and four nematodes (Ascaridida sp., Contracaecum sp.,
   Camallanus anabantis and C. pearsei) were recorded. Prevalence was
   higher in female (90%) hosts than males (75%). A significant positive
   correlation was observed between the standard length of the host and the
   abundance for parasites except Ascaridida sp. Nematodes were the more
   prevalent group (72%) than trematodes (48%). No parasitic species was
   observed as central species category; three parasites (N.
   saharanpuriensis, Ascaridida sp. and Contracaecum sp.) were considered
   as secondary and Camallanus spp. as satellite species. All nematode
   parasites showed aggregated distribution pattern and the trematode
   showed random distribution pattern. Interspecies association between two
   species of parasite was low.
C1 Bhuiyan, Aminul Islam; Univ Dhaka, Dept Zool, Dhaka, 1000, Bangladesh,
   Bangladesh.
EM aminul_islam89@yahoo.com
SC Zoology; Parasitology; Marine &Freshwater Biology; Environmental
   Sciences &Ecology
SN 0304-9027
BD Parasites diseases and disorders; Parasites; Helminth parasites; Hosts;
   Habitat; Pollution; Land zones; Oriental region; Eurasia; Asia

DT Article
TI A new species of Liolaemus of the L. nigromaculatus group (Iguania:
   Liolaemidae) from Atacama Region, Chile.
FT Una nueva especie de Liolaemus del grupo de L. nigromaculatus (Iguania:
   Liolaemidae) para la Region de Atacama, Chile.
AU Marambio-Alfaro, Yery
   Troncoso-Palacios, Jaime (jtroncosopalacios@gmail.com) 
SO Basic and Applied Herpetology
VL 28
PS 65-77
PD 2014
PY 2014
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 0
AB Here, we describe a new species of Liolaemus (Iguania: Liolaemidae) from
   the coastal desert of Atacama in the vicinity of Barranquilla, Chile.
   This new species belongs to the L. nigromaculatus group and can be
   distinguished from the other species of the group and the remaining
   species of the genus Liolaemus, by the striking color pattern of the
   male, with black head and dorsum, and light blue thighs and tail, as
   well as other scalation features that allow its diagnosis. With this new
   species, the L. nigromaculatus group increases to 13 species.
C1 Troncoso-Palacios, Jaime; Univ Chile, Fac Med, Casilla 70005, Santiago,
   7, Chile, Chile.
EM jtroncosopalacios@gmail.com

   region; South America

   subordinate taxa, P. 71]. 
   Liolaemus nigrocoeruleus (Iguanidae): [Sp nov, Chile, P. 67].

PT B
AN ZOOR15404019622
DT Book chapter
TI A new scansorial species of Platymantis Gunther, 1858 (Anura:
   Ceratobatrachidae) from Manus Island, Admiralty Archipelago, Papua New
   Guinea.
AU Richards, Stephen L. (steve.richards@samuseum.sa.gov.au) 
   Oliver, Paul
   Brown, Rafe M.
ED Telnov, Dmitry
SO Biodiversity, biogeography and nature conservation in Wallacea and New
   Guinea. Volume II.
PS 123-134
PD 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Recent surveys and examination of museum specimens have revealed at
   least seven new species of frogs from the remote Admiralty Archipelago
   off northern Papua New Guinea. This includes six species of the genus
   Platymantis Gunther, 1858 (Family Ceratobatrachidae) of which three,
   Platymantis admiraltiensis Richards, Mack, Austin, 2007, P. latro
   Richards, Mack, Austin, 2007 and P. manus Kraus, Allison, 2009 have been
   described since 2007. Here we describe an additional species of
   Platymantis from Manus Island in the Admiralty Archipelago. The new
   species is most similar morphologically to Platymantis macrosceles
   Zweifel, 1975 and P. citrinospilus Brown, Richards, Broadhead, 2013 both
   from New Britain Island in the Bismarck Archipelago, in having greatly
   expanded finger and toe discs and a slender body form, but differs from
   both of those species in a suite of morphological and acoustic
   characters. Frog diversity on Manus Island is high for such a small and
   isolated oceanic island group, and is considerably higher than the
   nearby and much larger New Ireland.
C1 Richards, Stephen L.; S Australian Museum, Herpetol Dept, Adelaide, SA,
   5000, Australia, Australia.
EM steve.richards@samuseum.sa.gov.au
PU The Entomological Society of Latvia
PA Riga
SC Zoology
BN 978-9984-9768-7-7
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Australasian region;
   Australasia
DE Platymantis custos [Papua New Guinea /  / New species]. 
TN Amphibians; Chordates; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Amphibia, Lissamphibia, Anura, Ranidae
OR Platymantis custos (Ranidae): [Sp nov, Papua New Guinea, P. 124]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15404019622
DA 2020-09-17

LA English

AB A new genus (Guineella gen. nov.) and twelve new species of Xantholinini

   are the first of their genera known from New Guinea (Adamantea
   fluviatilis, Adamantea karkar and Australinus papuanus).

   Paradoxosomatidae: Eustrongylosomatini).
AU Golovatch, Sergei I. (sgolovatch@yandex.ru) 
   Stoev, Pavel
ED Telnov, Dmitry
SO Biodiversity, biogeography and nature conservation in Wallacea and New
   Guinea. Volume II.
PS 149-156
PD 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The oligotypic genus Silvattia Jeekel, 2009, which has hitherto been
   known to comprise only two species from New Guinea, is rediagnosed and
   shown to include further three species from Papua New Guinea: Silvattia
   petarberoni sp. nov., S. perplexa sp. nov. and S. jeekeli sp. nov. A key
   is given to all five species of the genus.

AN ZOOR15404019628
DT Book chapter
TI Species of Ditropopsis EA Smith, 1897 (Architaenioglossa: Cyclophoridae)
   from the Papuan region: taxonomic review.
AU Greke, Kristine (k.greke@gmail.com) 
ED Telnov, Dmitry
SO Biodiversity, biogeography and nature conservation in Wallacea and New
   Guinea. Volume II.
PS 187-208
PD 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The gastropod genus Ditropopsis E.A. Smith, 1897 (Architaenioglossa:
   Cyclophoridae) from New Guinea, Raja Ampat and the Moluccan Archipelago
   is revised. Six informal species groups of 27 species are recognized for
   the study region including twelve new species, which are described and
   illustrated: Ditropopsis alta sp. nov., D. halmaherica sp. nov., D.
   magna sp. nov., D. majalibit sp. nov., D. monticola sp. nov., D.
   pallidioperculata sp. nov., D. pyramis sp. nov., D. tamarau sp. nov., D.
   telnovi sp. nov., D. unicarinata sp. nov., D. waigeoensis sp. nov., and
   D. wallacei sp. nov. Redescriptions of two insufficiently described
   species are given. An updated faunal checklist, key to Ditropopsis
   species and a short biogeographical analysis are presented for the
   Papuan region.
C1 Greke, Kristine; Stopinu Novads, Dzidrinas, Darza iela 10, Riga,
   LV-2130, Latvia, Latvia.
EM k.greke@gmail.com
PU The Entomological Society of Latvia
PA Riga
SC Zoology
BN 978-9984-9768-7-7

TI New species of Aphanisticus Latreille, 1810 (Coleoptera: Buprestidae)
   from Sulawesi, Indonesia and from Australia.
AU Kalashian, Mark Yu (mkalashian1@gmail.com) 
   Kuban, Vitezslav

   Guinea. Volume II.

AB Aphanisticus barclayi sp. nov., Aphanisticus sulawesicus sp. nov. from
   Sulawesi (Indonesia), and Aphanisticus australasiae sp. nov.,
   Aphanisticus queenslandicus sp. nov. from Queensland, Australia are
   described and figured. The species from Sulawesi belong to A. chloris
   Obenberger, 1928 species-groups and those from Australia belong to A.
   endeloides Carter, 1924 species-group. Keys to species of both groups
   are provided.

AN ZOOR15404019633
DT Book chapter
TI Gerontha peterseni sp. nov. - a new species from Papua New Guinea
   (Lepidoptera: Tineidae) found in material of the 'Kaiserin
   Augusta-Fluss-Expedition'.
AU Mey, Wolfram (wolfram.mey@mfn-berlin.de) 
ED Telnov, Dmitry
SO Biodiversity, biogeography and nature conservation in Wallacea and New
   Guinea. Volume II.
PS 235-240
PD 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB This paper is a first result of the study of Microlepidoptera collected
   by the Kaiserin Augusta-Fluss-Expedition in 1912-13. A short account
   introduces the expedition. The genus Gerontha Walker, 1864 contains 24
   species including the herein described species G. peterseni sp. nov. The
   male genitalia are illustrated and compared with the genitalia of G.
   acrosthenia Zaguljaev, 1972, which occurs sympatrically with the new
   species in Papua-New Guinea. A list of all species of the genus is
   provided.
C1 Mey, Wolfram; Humboldt Univ, Leibniz Inst, Invalidenstr 43, Berlin,
   D-10115, Germany, Germany.
EM wolfram.mey@mfn-berlin.de
PU The Entomological Society of Latvia
PA Riga
SC Zoology
BN 978-9984-9768-7-7
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Documentation; Publications; Land
   zones; Australasian region; Australasia
DE Gerontha [Checklists / Distributional checklist / ]. 
   Gerontha acrosthenia [Papua New Guinea /  / New record]. 
   Gerontha peterseni [Papua New Guinea /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; Lepidopterans
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Lepidoptera, Glossata, Heteroneura,
   Tineoidea, Tineidae
OR Gerontha - Walker 1864 (Tineidae). 
   Gerontha acrosthenia (Tineidae): [New record]. 
   Gerontha peterseni (Tineidae): [Sp nov, Papua New Guinea, P. 238].

   incana-Gruppe ohne Philippinen.

PT B
AN ZOOR15404019635
DT Book chapter
TI Taxonomic revision of the genus Sapintus Casey, 1895 (Coleoptera:
   Anthicidae: Anthicinae) from the Indo-Australian transition zone, with
   remarks on some Oriental and Australian taxa.
AU Telnov, Dmitry (anthicus@gmail.com) 
ED Telnov, Dmitry
SO Biodiversity, biogeography and nature conservation in Wallacea and New
   Guinea. Volume II.
PS 255-344
PD 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Species of Sapintus Casey, 1895 from Wallacea and the Papuan region were
   revised. Thirty one species confirmed for the study area. Ten species
   new to science are described and illustrated, namely Sapintus (s. str.)
   airi sp. nov. (Solomon Islands), S. (s. str.) celeripes sp. nov. (W New
   Guinea), S. (s. str.) curvitibia sp. nov. (Solomon Islands), S. (s.
   str.) densepunctatus sp. nov. (W New Guinea), S. (s. str.) geminus sp.
   nov. (Papua New Guinea), S. (s. str.) gemitus sp. nov. (Sulawesi), S.
   (s. str.) macrops sp. nov. (W New Guinea), S. (s. str.) malut sp. nov.
   (North Moluccas), S. (s. str.) monstrosiantennatus sp. nov. (Sulawesi),
   and S. (s. str.) sexualis sp. nov. (W New Guinea). Redescriptions of
   another 21 species are given. Thirteen new combinations and 12 new
   synonymy are proposed. One revised status and two new names are
   proposed. Seven lectotype designations are made. An identification keys
   to species of Sapintus Casey, 1895 of the study area and an annotated
   species list are presented. Biogeographical peculiarities of Sapintus
   Casey, 1895 in the lndo-Australian transition zone are discussed for the
   first time. Ecological and bionomical observations are analysed.
   Possible mimicry cases among Sapintus and other beetle families
   (Cleridae, Chrysomelidae) were discussed. Additionally, eight species
   new to science from the Oriental region are described and illustrated,
   namely S. andreaskopetzi sp. nov. (Nepal), S. angulapex sp. nov. (The
   Philippines: Palawan), S. curvatus sp. nov. (Thailand), S. echinatus sp.
   nov. (Indonesian Borneo), S. gracilentus sp. nov. (Vietnam), S.
   hartmanni sp. nov. (Nepal), S. lao sp. nov. (Laos), and S. vietnamensis
   sp. nov. (Vietnam).
C1 Telnov, Dmitry; Stopinu Novads, Dzidrinas, Darza iela 10, Riga, LV-2130,
   Latvia, Latvia.
EM anthicus@gmail.com
PU The Entomological Society of Latvia
PA Riga
SC Anatomy &Morphology; Zoology
BN 978-9984-9768-7-7

PT B
AN ZOOR15404019636
DT Book chapter
TI Taxonomic revision of the Cladonotinae (Orthoptera: Tetrigidae) from the
   islands of South-East Asia and from Australia, with general remarks to
   the classification and morphology of the Tetrigidae and descriptions of
   new genera and species from New Guinea and New Caledonia.
AU Tumbrinck, Josef (j.tumbrinck@t-online.de) 
ED Telnov, Dmitry
SO Biodiversity, biogeography and nature conservation in Wallacea and New
   Guinea. Volume II.
PS 345-396
PD 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A key for the identification of the subfamilies of Tetrigidae is
   revised. The South-East Asian genera and species of the Cladonotinae are
   taxonomically reviewed and a key is provided for the identification of
   the genera. A checklist is given for all genera, species and subspecies.
   Six new genera, Boczkitettix gen. nov., Devriesetettix gen. nov.,
   Ichikawatettix gen. nov., Ingrischitettix gen. nov., Planotettix gen.
   nov., Willemsetettix gen. nov., and 36 new species, Boczkitettix
   manokwariensis sp. nov., Cladonotella riedeli sp. nov., Dolatettix
   hochkirchi sp. nov., Dolatettix lehmanni sp. nov., Eurymorphopus
   bolivariensis sp. nov., Gestroana bayerriveriensis sp. nov., Gestroana
   cyclopensis sp. nov., Gestroana flasbarthi sp. nov., Gestroana gressitti
   sp. nov., Gestroana karimuiensis sp. nov., Gestroana kleukersi sp. nov.,
   Gestroana moanemaniensis sp. nov., Gestroana morobensis sp. nov.,
   Gestroana mounthagensis sp. nov., Gestroana pannosa sp. nov., Gestroana
   sedlaceki sp. nov., Gestroana willemsei sp. nov., Gestroana yapenensis
   sp. nov., Ichikawatettix detzeli sp. nov., Ichikawatettix kleinertae sp.
   nov., Ingrischitettix mountalbilalaensis sp. nov., Planotettix
   astrolabebayensis sp. nov., Planotettix biroi sp. nov., Planotettix
   buergersi sp. nov., Planotettix cyclopensis sp. nov., Planotettix
   fartmanni sp. nov., Planotettix karubakensis sp. nov., Planotettix maai
   sp. nov., Planotettix mountbaduriensis sp. nov., Planotettix planus sp.
   nov., Planotettix riedei sp. nov., Willemsetettix laeensis sp. nov.,
   Willemsetettix maai sp. nov., Willemsetettix oriomoensis sp. nov.,
   Willemsetettix wauensis sp. nov., Willemsetettix willemsei sp. nov., are
   described. New combinations and revised status include Boczkitettix
   borneensis (Bolivar, 1887) comb. nov., Devriesetettix dorreus (Hancock,
   1909) comb. nov., Gestroana bicristulata (Gunther, 1938) comb. nov.,
   Holoarcus intermedius (Willemse, 1932) comb. nov., Holoarcus truncatus
   (Hancock, 1909) comb. nov., Ichikawatettix exsertus (Gunther, 1938)
   comb. nov., Piezotettix sulcatus (Bolivar, 1887) comb. nov. The
   following new synonyms are established: Xistrella Bolivar, 1909 =
   Pseudogignotettix Liang, 1990 syn. nov., Cladonotella beccarii (Bolivar,
   1898) = Cladonotella insulana Willemse, 1961 syn. nov. One new name is
   proposed: Holoarcus ferwillemsei nom. nov.
C1 Tumbrinck, Josef; Flees 1, Wassenberg, D-41849, Germany, Germany.
EM j.tumbrinck@t-online.de
PU The Entomological Society of Latvia
PA Riga
SC Zoology
BN 978-9984-9768-7-7

   Gestroana gressitti (Saltatoria): [Sp nov, Papua New Guinea, P. 364]. 
   Gestroana karimulensis (Saltatoria): [Sp nov, Papua New Guinea, P. 364].
   
   Gestroana kleukersi (Saltatoria): [Sp nov, Indonesia, P. 365]. 
   Gestroana moanemaniensis (Saltatoria): [Sp nov, Indonesia, P. 366]. 
   Gestroana morobensis (Saltatoria): [Sp nov, Papua New Guinea, P. 366]. 
   Gestroana mounthagensis (Saltatoria): [Sp nov, Papua New Guinea, P.
   367]. 
   Gestroana pannosa (Saltatoria): [Sp nov, Papua New Guinea, P. 368]. 
   Gestroana sedlaceki (Saltatoria): [Sp nov, Papua New Guinea, P. 369]. 
   Gestroana willemsei (Saltatoria): [Sp nov, Indonesia, P. 369]. 
   Gestroana yapenensis (Saltatoria): [Sp nov, Indonesia, P. 370]. 
   Holoarcus - Hancock 1909 (Saltatoria): [Key to species, P. 374].

DT Book chapter
TI The Monosyntaxis Swinhoe, 1901 complex of sibling species in New Guinea
   (Lepidoptera: Erebidae: Arctiinae: Lithosiini).
AU de Vos, Rob (rob.devos@naturalis.nl) 
ED Telnov, Dmitry
SO Biodiversity, biogeography and nature conservation in Wallacea and New
   Guinea. Volume II.
PS 397-405
PD 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Six new species of Monosyntaxis Swinhoe, 1901 have been discovered in
   New Guinea. They belong to a complex of sibling species of which some
   are difficult to distinguish by wing pattern alone from the common M.
   bipunctata (Bethune-Baker, 1904) from Southeast Papua New Guinea.
   However, the genitalia are strikingly different, and the aedeagi
   especially proved to have distinct diagnostic characters. The new
   species are M. honeyi sp. nov., M. fojaensis sp. nov., M. kobowrensis
   sp. nov., M. arfakensis sp. nov., M. kratkeensis sp. nov., and M.
   postfuscata sp. nov. All the new species seem to occur allopatrically in
   the high mountain areas of New Guinea and are described here and
   compared with the already known M. bipunctata (Bethune-Baker, 1904), M.
   persimilis Rothschild, 1912 and M. bimaculata De Vos, 2009.
C1 de Vos, Rob; Nat Biodivers Ctr RMNH, Dept Entomol, Darwinweg 2, Leiden,
   NL-2333 CR, Netherlands, Netherlands.
EM rob.devos@naturalis.nl
PU The Entomological Society of Latvia
PA Riga
SC Zoology
BN 978-9984-9768-7-7

PT B

DT Book chapter
TI A revision of the genus Nemophas Thomson, 1864 (Coleoptera:
   Cerambycidae), with descriptions of a new subgenus Pilomophas and a new
   genus Nemoplophora.
AU Wallin, Henrik (henrik.wallin@saiglobal.com) 
   Kvamme, Torstein
   Nylander, Ulf
ED Telnov, Dmitry
SO Biodiversity, biogeography and nature conservation in Wallacea and New
   Guinea. Volume II.
PS 407-436
PD 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB All parts of the male genitalia characters of the valid species of
   Nemophas Thomson, 1864 are described for the first time. An exception is
   Nemophas bennigseni Aurivillius, 1908 incertae sedis since no male
   specimens were available for dissection, and, consequently, its
   taxonomic position could not be clarified. A new genus Nemoplophora gen.
   nov. is described and Nemoplophora subcylindricus (Aurivillus, 1927)
   comb. nov. is transferred from Nemophas. Nemoplophora subcylindricus
   comb. nov. appears to be more closely related to the genus Anoplophora
   Hope, 1839, in regards to the short antennae in males and several male
   genitalia characters. Nemophas ramosi Schulze, 1920 is placed in the new
   subgenus Pilomophas subgen. nov. N. (Pilomophas) ramosi exhibits unique
   male genitalia characters, which are used as the main basis for
   describing the subgenus. A comparative study, including genitalia
   characters of species from six related genera from the Oriental and
   Australian regions, clarifies the taxonomic position of Nemophas and
   Nemoplophora gen. nov. and the taxonomic borders to related genera.
   Nemophas grayi m. quinquefasciatus Breuning, 1943 syn. nov. is
   considered to be a junior synonym of N. grayii (Pascoe, 1859). Nemophas
   subterrubens Heller, 1924 syn. nov. is considered to be a junior synonym
   of N. (Pilomophas) ramosi. Nemophas subcylindricus var. virescens
   Aurivillius, 1927 syn. nov. is considered to be a junior synonym of
   Nemoplophora subcylindricus (Aurivillius, 1927) comb. nov. All the valid
   species of Nemophas and Nemoplophora gen. nov. are redescribed. A new
   dichotomous key to the species level is provided, incorporating male
   genitalia characters, as well as a key to the generic and subgeneric
   level. The geographical distribution of Nemophas and Nemoplophora is
   discussed. N. ammiralis Schwarzer, 1931, N. bennigseni Aurivillius, 1908
   and N. websteri Jordan, 1898, have, to our knowledge, not been collected
   since 1934. It is therefore uncertain if these beautiful species are
   extant.
C1 Wallin, Henrik; Swedish Museum Nat Hist, Sect Entomol, POB 50007,
   Stockholm, SE-10405, Sweden, Sweden.
EM henrik.wallin@saiglobal.com

PA Riga
SC Zoology
BN 978-9984-9768-7-7

   Diagnosis; Description; Combination; Synonymy; Taxonomy; Key

   Cerambycidae

DT Article
TI REDESCRIPTION OF SOME INDIAN LEPIDOCYRTUS SP (COLLEMBOLA-ENTOMOBRYIDAE).
AU Raghuraman, M.
   Santeshwari (Sanfrmvns@gmail.com) 
   Singh, J.
SO Bioscan
VL 9
IS 2
PS 455-460
PD 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The genus Lepidocyrtus of Collembola (Arthropleona - Entomobryidae) has
   been described. The species Lepidocyrtus lignorum and L. curvicollis are
   reported for the first time from India. The specimens were collected
   from soil litter. L. curvicollis and L. lignorum has characterized by
   the presence of scales on the I st and II nd segments of antennae, legs
   beyond coxae and dorsal side of manubrium. The species L. lignorum is
   characterized by normal mesonotum. Presence of R marcochaetae on head
   but S and T setae absent. On abd. 4 lateral macrochaeta E1 set between
   L2 and L3. L. curvicollis is characterized by mesonotum hood-like
   projecting, blunt at tip. Head without macrosetae. R S and T microsetae
   present. On abd. 4 lateral macrochaeta E1 set behind L2. Unguiculus of
   L. curvicollis shows serrated structure.
C1 Santeshwari; Banaras Hindu Univ, Dept Entomol & Agr Zool, Varanasi,
   Uttar Pradesh, 221005, India, India.
EM Sanfrmvns@gmail.com
SC Zoology

   Eurasia; Asia

DT Article
TI Composition and fish species richness in piedmont streams and rivers of
   the Cusiana River drainage in the Colombian Orinoco River Basin.
FT Composicion y riqueza ictica en quebradas y rios del piedemonte de la
   cuenca del rio Cusiana, Orinoquia colombiana.
AU Urbano-Bonilla, Alexander (a.urbano@javeriana.edu.co) 
   Prada-Pedreros, Saul
   Zapata, Angela
   Barrera-Catano, Jose I.
   Moreno-Cardenas, Ana C.
SO Biota Colombiana
VL 15
SU 1
PS 52-69
PD 2014
PY 2014
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 0
AB In order to provide information on the composition and richness of fish
   in the Colombian Orinoco piedmont (Tauramena -Casanare), collections
   were made every two months (June 2012 -February 2013), and standardized
   (arts-length-time), for six streams and three rivers from de Cusiana
   River piedmont, Orinoco River Basin, Colombia. 88 species where
   registered, 33 found on streams and 78 on rivers, there all grouped into
   six orders, 24 families and 56 genera. Two orders: Characiformes (43
   sp.) and Siluriformes (34 sp.) and two families: Characidae (27 sp.) and
   Loricariidae (15 sp.) had the highest species richness. The results
   obtained increase the number of species to from the Cusiana River
   drainage by 26 species, for a new total of 141 species; nine of these
   had been considered endemic to other sub-drainages. There was also a
   record of a new order and family (Synbranchiformes: Synbranchidae) and a
   new genus Ceratobranchia. Eight of the reported species of the reported
   species require further confirmation because they are new records. The
   importance of fish diversity and human intervention that the Cusiana
   River drainage is suffering makes this research a tool for the
   conservation of this aquatic ecosystems and its fish species.
C1 Urbano-Bonilla, Alexander; Pontificia Univ Javeriana, Dept Biol, Bogota
   Dc, Colombia, Colombia.
EM a.urbano@javeriana.edu.co
SC Zoology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Marine &Freshwater Biology
SN 0124-5376

   ] [Colombia / Orinoco River Basin, Cusiana River / ].

DT Article
TI The drosophilids (Diptera: Drosophilidae) from a Laurisilva patch in
   Madeira with two new records for this island.
AU Rego, C. (crego@fc.ul.pt) 
   Boieiro, M.
   Goncalves, Y.
   Menezes, D.
   Aguin-Pombo, D.
   Capela, R.
SO Bocagiana (Funchal)
VL 238
PS 1-8
PD 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The drosophilid fauna of Madeira consists of 20 species from 6 different
   genera, including one endemic species, Drosophila madeirensis Monclus,
   1984. In spite of several studies on Madeira drosophilids, little is
   known on the spatial distribution and phenology of most species,
   particularly of those associated to the native laurel forest. In this
   study, the drosophilid fauna of a Laurisilva patch was studied over an
   18-month period in Chao da Ribeira (Seixal, northern Madeira) using
   several sampling techniques. As a result of this study, seventeen
   species were recorded including two new records for Madeira: Drosophila
   phalerata (Meigen, 1830) and Lordiphosa n. sp., a new unnamed species.
   The current knowledge of Madeiran drosophlid fauna is also briefly
   discussed.
C1 Rego, C.; Univ Acores, Dept Ciencias Agr, Terceira, Acores, P-9700042,
   Portugal, Portugal.
EM crego@fc.ul.pt

PT J
AN ZOOR15208047333
DT Article
TI EFECT OF Beauveria bassiana and ENTOMOPATHOGENIC NEMATODE Steinernema sp
   ON Galleria mellonella LARVAE.
FT EFECTO DE Beauveria bassiana y DEL ENTOMONEMATODO Steinernema sp. SOBRE
   LARVAS DE Galleria mellonella.
AU Bacca, Tito (titobacca@gmail.com) 
   Lagos, Tulio Cesar B.
SO Boletin Cientifico Museo de Historia Natural Universidad de Caldas
VL 18
IS 1
PS 247-258
PD Jan 2014
PY 2014
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 7
AB In the integrated pest management the use of several biological control
   agents is common such as the entomopathogenic fungi (EF) and nematode
   parasites of insects (NE). These two pathogens may have the same host
   and habitat, leading to the appearance of synergism or antagonism
   relations when colonizing the same host. Based on the foregoing, this
   work had as main objective to study the interaction that can occur
   between Beauveria bassiana (Bb) and Steinernema sp. (Ss) in the
   lepidopteron Galleria mellonella (GM) larvae individually and as a
   group. The experimental unit was composed of six GM larvae from 24 wells
   placed in tissue culture dishes, with filter paper. Bb was used in a
   concentration of 1 x 103 (n= 9) spores/ml per larvae and Ss was used in
   a concentration of 100 infective juvenile (IJ) per larva. Sterile water
   was used as control. In general, it could be found that the percentage
   of mortality at 48 hours, for the treatment in which simultaneous
   application was performed, was higher and statistically different from
   that of individual treatments. In relation to the development of Ss,
   although there were no significant differences concerning the
   differentiation of sexes, there was decreased production of infective
   juveniles and penetration rate (variables evaluated to establish the
   effect of the fungus on the nematode). In the case of fungus, its
   sporulation was significantly reduced. Finally, although there is an
   increased effectiveness in pest control when pathogens are used
   together, the development of each of the organisms is affected possibly
   by competition for the host in which case, the agent that colonizes
   first dominates. In general terms the understanding of these
   interactions on a specific target insect will make it possible to
   determine the compatibility of the components of biological control to
   be used and will help increase the efficiency in the reduction of the
   pest.
C1 Bacca, Tito; Univ Narino, Fac Ciencias Agr, Torobajo, Pasto, Colombia,
   Colombia.
EM titobacca@gmail.com
OI Bacca, Tito/0000-0002-2960-5527
SC Zoology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Parasitology; Infectious
   Diseases; Mycology
SN 0123-3068
BD Animals and man; Control; Parasites diseases and disorders; Parasites;
   Helminth parasites; Hosts; Insect hosts; Diseases and disorders;
   Microbial diseases
DE Galleria mellonella [Biological control /  / larva] [ / Biocontrol agent
   interactions / ] [Nematode parasites / Steinernema / ] [ /  / ] [Fungal
   diseases / Beauveria bassiana / ]. 
   Steinernema [Biological control /  / ] [Lepidopteran hosts / Galleria
   mellonella / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; Lepidopterans; Nematodes
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Lepidoptera, Glossata, Heteroneura,
   Pyraloidea, Pyralidae, Nematoda
OR Galleria mellonella (Pyralidae): [Host]. 
   Steinernema (Nematoda): [Parasite]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15208047333
DA 2020-09-17
ER

PT J
AN ZOOR15307045438
DT Article
TI Description of a new species of Coracinotus Barat, 2010 from the Iberian
   Peninsula. (Orthoptera, Tettigoniidae, Bradyporinae).
FT Descripcion de una nueva especie de Coracinotus Barat, 2012 de la
   peninsula iberica (Orthoptera, Tettigoniidae, Bradyporinae).
AU Barranco, Pablo (pbvega@ual.es) 
   Gomez, Ricardo
SO Boletin de la Asociacion Espanola de Entomologia
VL 38
IS 1-2
PS 149-156
PD 2014
PY 2014
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of the katydid from the province of Granada (Spain) is
   described. It belongs to the recently described genus Coracinotus Barat,
   2012 distributed along the Eastern Betic mountains ranges. The new
   species is characterized by the tight tegminal reticulation, pronotum
   very elevated in the metazone with very weak side keels. The titillators
   show a particular "U" shape, with a very short distal portion, serrated
   with strong teeth, and the apex expanded and tridentated. The cerci and
   titillators are comparated by using SEM photographies.

TI A new species of Pterolepis Rambur, 1838, from Ibiza (Balearic Islands).
   (Orthoptera, Tettigoniidae).

   peninsula iberica) (Orthoptera, Tettigoniidae).
AU Barranco, Pablo (pbvega@ual.es) 
SO Boletin de la Asociacion Espanola de Entomologia
VL 38
IS 3-4
PS 313-324
PD 2014
PY 2014
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 0
AB A specimen of Pterolepis Rambur, 1838 accidentally captured by pine pest
   cerambycids beetles monitoring in Ibiza (Islas Baleares) is studied.
   This capture is the first recod of the genera for the Balearic Islands.
   The female subgenital plate has a particular shape which allows us
   describe a new species, characterized by medial keel and two oval basal
   tubercles.

   Ortega, Gregorio

SO Bolleti de la Societat d'Historia Natural de les Balears
VL 57
PS 37-54
PD 2014
PY 2014
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of the genus Periacanthus Bittner, 1875 (Crustacea,
   Decapoda) is described within siliciclastic sediments of the slope of
   the middle Cuisian (Eocene) of Huesca (Aragon, Spain), which increase
   the genus to five taxa Periacanthus. The new species differs from other
   species in the genus by the possession of two expansions as well
   developed antlers on its side edges.

TI The Curculionoidea Monti Prenestini, with description of a new species
   of Otiorhynchus Germar (Coleoptera, Curculionoidea).
FT I curculionoidei dei Monti Prenestini, con descrizione di una nuova
   specie di Otiorhynchus Germar (Coleoptera, Curculionoidea).
AU Casalini, Roberto (casalini.roberto@gmail.com) 
   Colonnelli, Enzo
SO Bollettino del Museo Civico di Storia Naturale di Verona Botanica
   Zoologia
VL 38
PS 135-160
PD 2014
PY 2014
LA Italian
U1 0
U2 0
AB Curculionoidea of Monti Prenestini, with description of a new species of
   Otiorhynchus (Coleoptera, Curculionoidea) The 468 species found on Monti
   Prenestini, a mountain range of moderate extent and elevation situated
   in Latium east of Rome, are listed. The new edaphic Otiorhynchus
   (Lixorrhynchus) hystricis n. sp., differing from all hitherto known
   species of the subgenus by the combination of reduced eyes placed below
   the derm surface, edentate femora, and internal margin of protibiae
   lacking of large tooth is described. Short faunistic or/and taxonomic
   notes on notheworthy species are given. A new synonymy is established:
   Aulacobaris gudenusi (A. Schultze, 1901) (= A. gudenusi purpurascens (A.
   Schultze, 1901), syn. rev.).

   I-00195, Italy, Italy.

AB In the present paper Gibbovalva squamosa sp. n. (Gracillariidae), leaf
   miner of Tabernaemontana probably crassa Benth. (Apocynaceae), is
   described from western Africa (Republic of Guinea). The generic
   placement is widely treated since the new species presents additional
   differential characters than the other Gibbovalva species this is the
   first report of the presence of Gibbovalva in the Afrotropical Region.

PT J
AN ZOOR15206033917
DT Article
TI Fish of Santonian (upper Cretaceous) of Apricena (South Italy). 7.
   Garganoclupea svetovidovi gen. and sp nov gen. and Apricenaclupea
   ridewoodi sp nov (Teleostei, Clupeiformes).
FT Les poissons du Santonien (Cretace superieur) d'Apricena (Italie du
   Sud). 7. Garganoclupea svetovidovi gen. et sp. nov. et Apricenaclupea
   ridewoodi gen. et sp. nov. (Teleostei, Clupeiformes).
AU Taverne, Louis (louis.taverne@gmail.com) 
SO Bollettino del Museo Civico di Storia Naturale di Verona Geologia
   Paleontologia Preistoria
VL 38
PS 27-49
PD 2014
PY 2014
LA French
U1 0
U2 0
AB The osteology of Garganoclupea svetovidovi gen. and sp. nov. and of
   Apricenaclupea ridewoodi gen. and sp. nov., two clupeiform fishes from
   the marine Upper Santonian of Apricena ( Promontory of Gargano, Foggia
   province, Apulia, southern Italy) is described in details. Garganoclupea
   shares five apomorphies with the Clupeoidei, namely the autogenous
   parhypural, the long end thin postcleithra, the first uroneural fused to
   the preural vertebra 1, a lateral spur on the central caudal ray and the
   lost of the lateral line. But it appears more primitive than all other
   known Clupeoidei by the preservation of the beryciform foramen and of
   the articular head of the first hypural, by the large size of the ural
   vertebra 1 and by the lack of a true pleurostyle. That justifies the
   erection for it of a peculiar family, the Garganoclupeidae.
   Apricenaclupea appears to belong to the family Clupeidae, the subfamily
   Pellonulinae and the tribe Ehiravini. Indeed, it possesses two finlets
   behind the principal anal fin. It differs from the four other genera of
   Ehiravini which also exhibit finlets.
C1 Taverne, Louis; Residence Les Platanes, Blvd Souverain 142 Boite 8,
   Brussels, B-1170, Belgium, Belgium.
EM louis.taverne@gmail.com
SC Zoology
SN 1590-8402

   Eurasia; Europe; Geological time periods; Mesozoic
DE Apricenaclupea; Garganoclupea [Cretaceous /  / New genus]. 
   Apricenaclupea ridewoodi; Garganoclupea svetovidovi [Italy /  / new
   species] [Cretaceous /  / ]. 
TN Chordates; Fish; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Pisces, Osteichthyes, Actinopterygii,
   Clupeiformes, Clupeidae
OR Garganoclupea (Clupeiformes): [Gen nov, Of new family Garganoclupeidae,
   Type species Garganoclupea svetovidovi, p. 28, Cretaceous; Fossil]. 
   Garganoclupea svetovidovi (Clupeiformes): [Sp nov, Italy, Cretaceous, P.
   28; Fossil]. 
   Garganoclupeidae (Clupeiformes): [Fam nov, Of suborder Clupeoidei, Type
   genus Garganoclupea, p. 28].

   Apricenaclupea ridewoodi, p. 38, Cretaceous; Fossil].

   Fossil].

AN ZOOR15205029132
DT Article
TI Notes on the Elaphocera of Sardinia, description of a new species and
   re-evaluation of the species described by Erichson and Gene (Insecta,
   Coleoptera, Scarabaeidae, Melolonthinae, Tanyproctini).
FT Appunti sulle Elaphocera di sardegna, descrizione di una nuova specie e
   rivalutazione delle specie descritte da Erichson e Gene (insecta,
   Coleoptera, Scarabaeidae, weelolonthinae, Tanyproctini).
AU Fancello, Luca (l.fancello@hotmail.it) 
   Bazzato, Erika
   Cillo, Davide
SO Bollettino del Museo di Storia Naturale di Venezia
VL 65
PS 67-101
PD 2014
PY 2014
LA Italian
U1 0
U2 0
AB In this paper we report the results of a study on the Sardinian species
   of Elaphocera Gene, 1836 (Coleoptera Scarabaeidae Melolonthinae
   Tanyproctini). Based on the examination of nearly 1,700 specimens, we
   studied the morphology of both sexes, with the identification of new
   morphological characters useful for the diagnosis of the species. The
   type series of the two species currently listed for Sardinia in the
   literature were considered, E. enzarginata (Gyllenhal in Schonherr,
   1817) and E. erichsoni Kraatz, 1882, including all the typical material
   available for their respective synonyms. E. emarginata is confirmed as a
   good species whereas E. sardoa Rambur, 1843 is re-confirmed as synonym
   of it. E. dilatata Erichson, 1840 (a synonym of E. erichsoni) and E.
   obscura Gene, 1836 (a synonym of E. enzarginata) are recognized as
   distinct species. Based on the type series, E. erichsoni is recognized
   as a subspecies of E. obscura. On the other hand, it is demonstrated the
   misinterpretation of the taxon erichsoni by all recent authors following
   the revision of Baraud and is therefore suggested to review all
   erichsoni records published in the recent literature. It is also
   described E. leoi Fancello & Cillo, n. sp., endemic to a restricted
   coastal area of the Cagliari province. Geonemic data as well as the
   biological ones related to phenology and ethology are discussed for all
   species. Finally, it is discussed the influence of climate and temporary
   atmospheric phenomena on the populations of the five taxa recognized for
   Sardinia. A neotype for E. obscura is designated.
C1 Fancello, Luca; Via Bainsizza 12, Cagliari, I-09123, Italy, Italy.
EM l.fancello@hotmail.it
SC Zoology; Behavioral Sciences; Environmental Sciences &Ecology;
   Meteorology &Atmospheric Sciences
SN 2039-4160
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type material; Synonymy; Taxonomy;
   Status; Behaviour; Ecology; Abiotic factors; Physical factors; Land
   zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Europe; Italy
DE Elaphocera [Behaviour /  / taxonomic review] [Population dynamics /
   Seasonal abundance / ] [Climate and weather /  / ] [Sardinia /  / ]. 
   Elaphocera leoi [Sardinia /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Polyphaga, Scarabaeoidea,
   Scarabaeidae
OR Elaphocera - Gene 1836 (Scarabaeidae). 
   Elaphocera dilatata - Erichson 1840 (Scarabaeidae): [Removal from
   synonymy, With Elaphocera erichsoni, p. 73]. 
   Elaphocera emarginata - (Gyllenhal in Schoenherr 1817) (Scarabaeidae):
   [Senior synonym, Of Elaphocera sardoa Rambur 1843, p. 86; Removal from
   synonymy, Elaphocera obscura Gene 1836, p. 78; Status, P. 86]. 
   Elaphocera erichsoni - Kraatz 1882 (Scarabaeidae): [Downgraded to,
   Elaphocera obscura erichsoni, p. 78; Removal from synonymy, Elaphocera
   dilatata Erichson 1840, p. 73]. 
   Elaphocera leoi - Fancello & Cillo 2015 (Scarabaeidae): [Sp nov,
   Sardinia, P. 87]. 
   Elaphocera obscura - Gene 1836 (Scarabaeidae): [Neotype designated, P.
   78; Removal from synonymy, With Elaphocera emarginata (Gyllenhal in
   Schoenherr 1817), p. 78]. 
   Elaphocera obscura erichsoni - Kraatz 1882 (Scarabaeidae): [Downgraded
   from, Elaphocera erichsoni, p. 78]. 
   Elaphocera sardoa - Rambur 1843 (Scarabaeidae): [Junior synonym, Of
   Elaphocera emarginata (Gyllenhal in Schoenherr 1817), p. 86].

DT Article
TI A NEW OTIORHYNCHUS GERMAR FROM THE SIBILLINI MOUNTAINS, CENTRAL
   APENNINES (Coleoptera, Curculionidae).
AU Colonnelli, Enzo (ecolonnelli@yahoo.it) 
   Forbicioni, Leonardo
SO Bollettino dell'Associazione Romana di Entomologia
VL 69
IS 1-4
PS 71-76
PD 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The new species Otiorhynchus (Aranihus) faucium n. sp. from the
   Sibillini Mountains, central Apennines, Italy is described. It differs
   from the extremely close O. misellus Stierlin, 1861 from the French and
   Italian Maritime Alps by its longer and thicker lifted setae usually
   with truncate apex, obviously larger subquadrate elytral striae, much
   more raised and coarsely sculptured elytral intervals, flattened or even
   slightly concave basal third.

DT Article
TI The family Buccinidae Rafinesque,1815 in the Italian Plio-Pleistocene:
   the genera Aplus De Gregorio, 1884, Engina Gray, 1839 e Gemophos Olsson
   & Harbinson, 1953 (Gastropoda).
FT La famiglia Buccinidae Rafinesque, 1815 nel Plio-Pleistocene italiano: i
   generi Aplus De Gregorio, 1884, Engina Gray, 1839 e Gemophos Olsson &
   Harbinson, 1953 (Gastropoda).
AU Brunetti, M. Mauro (mbrunetti45@gmail.com) 
   Della Bella, Giano
SO Bollettino Malacologico
VL 50
IS 1
PS 11-32
PD Jan 2014
PY 2014
LA Italian
U1 0
U2 0
AB In the family Buccinidae Rafinesque, 1815 the species of the genus Aplus
   De Gregorio, 1884, previously assigned by several authors to the genera
   Pollia Gray in Sowerby, 1834, Cantharus Roding, 1798, Tritonidea
   Swainson, 1840 and Anna Risso, 1826 were examined. In the Italian
   Pliocene the following species are present: Aplus nilus De Gregorio,
   1884, Aplus ansus De Gregorio, 1884, Aplus aequicostatus (Bellardi,
   1877), Aplus plioparvus (Sacco, 1904), Aplus pliounifilosus n. sp. and
   Aplus pliorecens n. sp., the latter also occurring in the Eraly
   Pleistocene. In the Late Pleistocene the Recent species Aplus dorbignyi
   (Payraudeau, 1827) appears, whereas another species of the same genus
   from the Gelasian of Emilia remains undetermined as Aplus sp., due to
   the scantiness of material. The genus Engina Gray, 1839 occurs in the
   Pliocene with only Engina pusilla (Bellardi, 1877), whereas the fossil
   record of the Recent Mediterranean species Engina leucozona (Philippi,
   1843) are rare and all referable to the Late Pleistocene. In the
   Pleistocene, the genus Gemophos Olsson & Harbison, 1953 occurs with two
   species, Geomophos viverratus (Kiener, 1834) from the Tyrrhenian stage,
   and Geomophos advena (Malatesta, 1960) from the Calabrian, the latter
   only based on the original record.
C1 Brunetti, M. Mauro; Via 28 Settembre 1944 2, Rioveggio, BO, I-40036,
   Italy, Italy.
EM mbrunetti45@gmail.com
SC Zoology; Paleontology; Anatomy &Morphology
SN 0394-7149

   Shell; Ecology; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Europe;
   Geological time periods; Caenozoic; Quaternary; Tertiary; Neogene

   /  / ].

   Buccinidae [Shell morphology /  / systematics] [Fossil assemblages /  /
   ] [Italy /  / distribution; faunal list; stratigraphical distribution]
   [Pleistocene / Plio-Pleistocene / ] [Pliocene /  / ].

OR Aplus pliorecens (Muricoidea): [Sp nov, Italy, Pliocene, P. 22; Fossil].

TI A new Mediterranean species of Fusinus (Gastropoda: Fasciolariidae).
FT Una nuova specie mediterranea di Fusinus (Gastropoda, Fasciolariidae).
AU Russo, Paolo (russorusso@virgilio.it) 
   Germana, Alfio
SO Bollettino Malacologico
VL 50
IS 1
PS 54-58
PD Jan 2014
PY 2014
LA Italian
U1 0
U2 2
AB A new Fusinus species is described as Fusinus corallinus n. sp. from the
   Ionian Sea. The new species was collected from coralligenous bottoms,
   50-70 m deep, in the Secca di Pachino, off Marzamemi (south-eastern
   Sicily). It is a relatively small species (maximum shell height 19 mm),
   with strong axial ribs and reddish spiral chords. It is compared with
   Fusinus alternatus Buzzurro & Russo, 2007 and with F. ventimigliae Russo
   & Renda, 2013, which are the most similar congeners, either.
   morphologically and distributionally.

DT Article
TI Turonian gastropods from the Coastal Basin of Gabon: Gabon store
   section, South of Libreville.
AU Musavu Moussavou, Benjamin (musavu@yahoo.fr) 
   Ngnibome Angoue, Martial
SO Bulletin de l'Institut Scientifique Section Sciences de la Terre - Rabat
VL 36
PS 19-26
PD 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The taxonomy and palaeoecology of the Turonian gastropods fauna from the
   geological section 'Gabon Store' (southern Libreville, Gabon) are
   discussed. Seven taxa are recognized: Armenocerithium haidingeri
   (Zekeli), Cerithium sp. A, Cerithium sp. B, Cerithium sp. C, Nerinea
   sp., Pseudamaura sp. and Turritella sp. Two genera Armenocerithium anda
   Nerinea are reported from the Gabonese coastal basin for the first time.
   The association of macrobenthic fauna (gastropods and bivalves)
   indicates: (1) a medium water energy level and (2) a stable and soft
   substrate during Turonian deposit of the 'Gabon store' section.
C1 Musavu Moussavou, Benjamin; Univ Sci & Tech Masuku, Dept Geol, BP 943,
   Franceville, Gabon, Gabon.
EM musavu@yahoo.fr

   Geological time periods; Mesozoic

   Gastropoda [Fossil assemblages /  / systematics] [Environmental
   indicators / Palaeoenvironmental indications / ] [Gabon / Libreville / ]
   [Cretaceous / Turonian / ].

DT Article
TI Description of a new Heros species (Teleostei, Cichlidae) from the Rio
   Orinoco drainage and notes on Heros severus Heckel, 1840.
AU Staeck, Wolfgang (staeck@googlemail.com) 
   Schindler, Ingo
SO Bulletin of Fish Biology
VL 15
IS 1-2
PS 121-136
PD 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Heros liberifer sp. n. is described from the drainage of the upper and
   middle Rio Orinoco in Venezuela. The new species is distinguished from
   all other Heros species by its unique colouration pattern of several
   horizontal series of tiny bright red dots on the lower half of the body
   sides and by its unusual brood care. Heros liberifer sp. n. can be
   distinguished from the syntopic Heros reveries Heckel, 1840 by a
   distinct caudal spot, narrower lips, a bright red iris and the 4th
   vertical bar, which is not shortened, but extends from the anal fin base
   to the base of the dorsal fin. In addition, comments are made on the
   colouration of live specimens of Heros severer, its distribution and
   ecology.
C1 Staeck, Wolfgang; Grat 41 a, Berlin, D-14195, Germany, Germany.
EM staeck@googlemail.com
SC Zoology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology
SN 1867-5417

   Ecology; Land zones; Neotropical region; South America

   Heros severus [Colour /  / systematics] [Ecology /  / ] [Brazil /  /
   distribution]. 
TN Chordates; Fish; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Pisces, Osteichthyes, Actinopterygii,
   Perciformes, Cichlidae

   Heros severus - Heckel 1840 (Cichlidae): [Diagnostic characters, P. 126;
   Emended diagnosis, P. 129].

DT Article
TI A new genus and species of Dermestidae (Coleoptera) from the Eckfeld
   Maar crater (Middle Eocene, Germany).
AU Hava, Jiri
   Wappler, Torsten (twappler@uni-bonn.de) 
SO Bulletin of Geosciences
VL 89
IS 1
PS 67-74
PD 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Eckfeldattagenus eocenicus gen. et sp. nov. is described from the Middle
   Eocene Eckfeld Maar (Germany) on the basis of completely preserved
   specimens, representing one of the rare reports of fossil skin beetles
   (Coleoptera: Dermestidae: Attageninae). The new genus and species
   differs from all other Dermestidae by the very flat body form and
   pronotum, and its unique structure of the antennal club and the wrinkled
   elytral surface.
