PT J
AN ZOOR15210065913
DT Article
TI CONODONTS FROM THE CARNIAN-NORIAN BOUNDARY (UPPER TRIASSIC) OF BLACK
   BEAR RIDGE, NORTHEASTERN BRITISH COLUMBIA, CANADA.
AU Orchard, Michael J. (morchard@nrcan.gc.ca) 
SO Bulletin of the New Mexico Museum of Natural History and Science
VL 64
PS 1-139
PD 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Conodonts from the Carnian-Norian Boundary (CNB) interval at the Global
   Stratigraphic Section and Point (GSSP) candidate section at Black Bear
   Ridge (BBR), British Columbia, Canada, include five previously
   introduced genera (Acuminatella, Kraussodontus, Parapetella, Primatella,
   Quadralella), 71 new species (plus nine previously named, and 13 more in
   open nomenclature), and 47 new morphotypes. These elements, and others
   previously known, display progressive morphogenesis through the strata
   of the Ludington and Pardonet formations, which represent a continuous
   Upper Triassic slope-basin succession at the western edge of Pangea. Two
   conodont zones and nine subzones are defined for the interval, in
   ascending stratigraphic order: Carnepigondolella samueli Zone with the
   subzones of C. eozoae-Kraussodontus ludingtonensis, C. zoae, C.
   medioconstricta, and C. spenceri; the Primatella primitia Zone with the
   subzones of Acuminatella sagittale-Parapetella beattyi, A.
   angusta-Metapolygnathus dylani, A. acuminata-Pa. prominens, M. parvus
   (three subdivisions), and Primatella asymmetrica-Norigondolella sp.
   These strata are capped by the Early Norian Epigondolella quadrata Zone.
   Conodont faunal turnovers are identified at the boundary between the
   samueli and primitia zones with the extinction of Carnepigondolella, and
   between the primitia and quadrata zones with the extinction of
   Acuminatella and Primatella. However, the most significant turnover is
   in the boundary interval of the acuminata-prominens and parvus subzones
   where, respectively, 16 and 46 taxa disappear, including all
   Quadralella, Kraussodontus, and most Parapetella species. This turnover
   falls within a 5 m boundary interval bracketed by diagnostic ammonoids
   of the Upper Carnian Klamathites macrolobatus Zone and those of the
   Lower Norian Stikinoceras kerri Zone. The undated boundary interval
   includes an organic carbon isotope minimum, and the first occurrences of
   the bivalve Halobia austriaca, and the ammonoid Pterosirenites.
   Conodonts from this boundary interval are also identified in association
   with H. austriaca and Pterosirenites at nearby Pardonet Hill east (PHE).
   Matrix from archival ammonoid collections of the Macrolobatus Zone has
   also yielded the boundary conodont faunas, implying that the entire
   boundary interval at BBR is equivalent to the Macrolobatus Zone. Broad
   correlation with the GSSP candidate section at Pizzo Mondello (PM) in
   Sicily can be achieved at several levels around the parvus Subzone: at
   its base with the appearance of the name-giver; at levels within it
   based on the appearances of Parapetella destinae, Parapetella irwini,
   and Primatella bifida; and at its top where typical Carnian taxa
   disappear (equivalent to event T3 at PM). At BBR, the parvus Subzone
   documents the decline and extinction of Carnian conodont genera, the
   bloom of diminutive taxa, and the ascendency of the Primatella stock,
   precursor of Epigondolella. The parvus Subzone includes significant
   conodont, ammonoid, and bivalve appearances that could serve as indices
   or proxies for the CNB, but use of any of them would have the effect of
   assigning some Macrolobatus Zone collections to the Norian Stage. The
   base of the asymmetrica-Norigondolella Subzone of the primitia Zone
   offers a CNB position that is most closely aligned with the traditional
   base of the Norian, i.e. at the base of the Kern Zone, and only that
   position assigns all Anatropites-bearing collections to the Carnian. At
   BBR, this level is defined by the disappearance of Metapolygnathus
   parvus and its diminutive associates rather than by new appearances.
   Uncommon taxa that appear at that time may be endemics: Acuminatella
   curvata at BBR, and Primatella? gulloae at PM. The disappearance of M
   parvus and its associates close the Carnian chapter in conodont
   evolution, and their extinction may be favored as a natural boundary.
   Such a position for the CNB does, however, remove Halobia species as
   definitive indices, and places the range of Pterosirenites on both sides
   of the Carnian-Norian Boundary. Subsequent floods of Norigondolella,
   initially N. norica, provide a strong and definitive Norian signal at
   BBR and nearby sections. In addition to five new genera and nine new
   species previously introduced from BBR, the following new taxa are
   named: Acuminatella binodosa, A. constricta, A. curvata, A. denticulata,
   A. longicarinata, A. sagittale, A. sinuosa, A.? extensa, A.? prima,
   Carnepigondolella anitae, C. gibsoni, C. milanae, C. postsamueli, C.
   spenceri, Kraussodontus ludingtonensis, K. margaretae, K. roberti, K.
   rosiae, K. urbanae, K. vancouverense, K. wendae, Metapolygnathus dylani,
   Norigondolella norica, Parapetella beattyi, P. broatchae, P. clareae, P.
   columbiense, P. cordillerense, P. destinae, P. elegantula, P. hillarae,
   P. irwini, P. johnpauli, P. lanei, P. posterolata, P. prominens
   angulare, P. p. circulare, P. pumilio, P. riteri, P. rubae, P.
   willifordi, Primatella bifida, P. circulare, P. elongata, P. mclearni,
   P. oblonga, P. ovale, P. posteroglobosa, P. rectangulare, P.
   rhomboidale, P. rotunda, P. stanleyi, P. subquadrata, P triangulare, P.
   vanlierae, Quadralella deflecta, Q. karenae, Q. kathleenae, Q.
   mcrobertsi, Q. pardoneti, Q. posteroexpansa, Q. postlobata, Q.
   praecommunisti curvata, Q. p. ornata, Q. roysi, Q. sigmoidale, and Q.
   willistonense.
C1 Orchard, Michael J.; Geol Survey Canada, Nat Resources Canada, 1500-605
   Robson St, Vancouver, BC, V6B 5J3, Canada, Canada.
EM morchard@nrcan.gc.ca
SC Zoology; Paleontology
SN 1524-4156
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Nearctic region; North
   America; Canada; Geological time periods; Mesozoic
DE Acuminatella binodosa; Acuminatella constricta; Acuminatella curvata;
   Acuminatella denticulata; Acuminatella longicarinata; Acuminatella
   sagittale; Acuminatella sinuosa; Acuminatella? extensa; Acuminatella?
   prima; Carnepigondolella anitae; Carnepigondolella gibsoni;
   Carnepigondolella milanae; Carnepigondolella postsamueli;
   Carnepigondolella spenceri; Kraussodontus ludingtonensis; Kraussodontus
   margaretae; Kraussodontus roberti; Kraussodontus rosiae; Kraussodontus
   urbanae; Kraussodontus vancouverense; Kraussodontus wendae;
   Metapolygnathus dylani; Norigondolella norica; Parapetella beattyi;
   Parapetella broatchae; Parapetella clareae; Parapetella columbiense;

   Parapetella lanei; Parapetella posterolata; Parapetella pumilio;

   Primatella bifida; Primatella circulare; Primatella elongata; Primatella
   mclearni; Primatella oblonga; Primatella ovale; Primatella
   posteroglobosa; Primatella rectangulare; Primatella rhomboidale;

   Primatella triangulare; Primatella vanlierae; Quadralella deflecta;
   Quadralella karenae; Quadralella kathleenae; Quadralella mcrobertsi;
   Quadralella pardoneti; Quadralella posteroexpansa; Quadralella
   postlobata; Quadralella roysi; Quadralella sigmoidale; Quadralella
   willistonense [British Columbia /  / new species] [Triassic /  / ]. 
   Conodonta [British Columbia / Black Bear Ridge / stratigraphical
   distribution; systematics] [Triassic / Upper Triassic / ]. 
   Halobia austriaca; Pterosirenites [British Columbia /  / new record]
   [Triassic / Upper Triassic / ]. 
   Parapetella prominens angulare; Parapetella prominens circulare;
   Quadralella praecommunisti curvata; Quadralella praecommunisti ornata
   [British Columbia /  / new subspecies] [Triassic /  / ]. 
TN Conodonts; Invertebrates; Molluscs
ST Animalia, Conodonta, Mollusca, Bivalvia, Pteriomorphia, Ostreoida,
   Pectinoidea, Cephalopoda, Ammonoidea, Ceratitida
OR Conodonta (Animalia): [Fossil]. 
   Acuminatella binodosa (Conodonta): [Sp nov, British Columbia, Triassic,

DT Article
TI A REVIEW OF VERTEBRATE TRACK-BEARING FORMATIONS FROM THE MESOZOIC AND
   EARLIEST CENOZOIC OF WESTERN CANADA WITH A DESCRIPTION OF A NEW THEROPOD
   ICHNOSPECIES AND REASSIGNMENT OF AN AVIAN ICHNOGENUS.
AU McCrea, Richard T.
   Buckley, Lisa G.
   Plint, A. Guy
   Currie, Philip J.
   Haggart, James W.
   Helm, Charles W.
   Pemberton, S. George
SO Bulletin of the New Mexico Museum of Natural History and Science
VL 62
PS 5-94
PD 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB The past quarter century has seen a marked increase in the recognition
   of fossil vertebrate tracksites in western Canada. Most of these finds
   were made in Alberta and British Columbia, but the Yukon Territory can
   lay claim to at least one tracksite and probably has the potential to
   yield more sites. The record of dinosaur tracks with skin impressions
   has increased dramatically, and is now represented by specimens of
   ankylosaurs, large ornithopods, small theropods and tyrannosauroids.
   Notable new finds include the first record of sauropods in Canada,
   evidence of herding behavior in ankylosaurs and the first pterosaur
   tracks in Canada. First discoveries of track specimens from several
   formations in western Canada include the Mountain Park Member of the
   Gates Formation in Alberta, and the Boulder Creek, Goodrich, Kaskapau,
   Cardium and Marshybank formations in northeastern British Columbia.
   Significant finds continue to be made in the Wapiti Formation in western
   Alberta near Grande Prarie and in northeastern British Columbia. An
   important step in the recognition and preservation of important track
   resources was made in Alberta when the tracksites in the Gates Formation
   near Grande Cache were designated as a provincial heritage resource in
   2006. Tracks are virtually unknown from pre-Cretaceous rocks in western
   Canada, with the only possible exception being the last stage of the
   Jurassic (Tithonian). The majority of the oldest tracksites are found in
   and around the Rocky Mountains of British Columbia, whereas the younger
   tracksites are found in the Foothills and Plains of both British
   Columbia and Alberta. The record of fossil vertebrate tracks in western
   Canada is important for filling the temporal gaps in known occurrences
   of terrestrial vertebrates left by a sparse skeletal record. Fossil
   tracks and trackways can also be used to interpret the behavior,
   biomechanics and ecology of extinct animals in ways not possible to
   realize solely from the study of skeletal remains.
C1 McCrea, Richard T.; Peace Reg Palaeontol Res Ctr, Box 1540, Tumbler
   Ridge, BC, V0C 2W0, Canada, Canada.
SC Paleontology; Zoology
SN 1524-4156

   Combination; Ecology; Fossil traces; Land zones; Nearctic region; North
   America; Canada; Geological time periods; Mesozoic

DT Article
TI DINOSAUR TRACKS FROM THE HELL CREEK FORMATION (UPPER CRETACEOUS,
   MAASTRICHTIAN), SOUTH DAKOTA.
AU Lockley, Martin
   Triebold, Mike
   Janke, Paul R.
SO Bulletin of the New Mexico Museum of Natural History and Science
VL 62
PS 459-468
PD 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB The first dinosaur trackway reported from the Hell Creek Formation
   (Harding County, South Dakota) consists of a large theropod trackway
   compOsed of 15 footprints, preserved as 3-D sideritic ironstone casts in
   a mudstone matrix. This sedimentological style of preservation is only
   known from one other recently-reported site in the Hell Creek of
   Montana. This suggests that footprints may be preserved in mud-dominated
   sequences where such traces are not normally sought or found.
   Morphologically, the tracks are 3-D foot replicas formed by the natural
   casting of the top, sides and undersides (plantar surface) of digits.
   This fully 3-D mode of preservation is rare, and few examples are known,
   including a spectacular example from the Cretaceous of Spain. The Hell
   Creek trackway indicates a large gracile theropod (foot length 60 cm)
   with a short hallux, wide digit divarication and a lack of
   well-developed digital pads. Most of the footprints also reveal
   well-developed metatarsal impressions, suggesting that the trackmaker
   was sinking deep into the substrate due to soft conditions underfoot,
   but could also possibly involve a deliberate crouching or stalking
   behavior. The trackway morphology is quite distinct from anything
   currently known in Cretaceous deposits from western North America and is
   therefore assigned to the new ichnotaxon Wakinyantanka styxi ichnogen.
   and ichno sp. nov.
C1 Lockley, Martin; Univ Colorado, Dinosaur Trackers Res Grp, POB 173364,
   Denver, CO, 80217, USA, USA.
SC Zoology; Paleontology
SN 1524-4156
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Ecology; Fossil traces; Land zones;
   Nearctic region; North America; USA; Geological time periods; Mesozoic

   Dakota / Harding County / ] [Cretaceous / Maastrichtian / ]. 
   Fossil Miscellanea [Fossil tracks / Trackway / Attributed to Dinosauria
   (Reptilia); new record; systematics] [South Dakota / Harding County /
   trackway attributed to Dinosauria (Reptilia)] [Cretaceous /
   Maastrichtian / ]. 
   Theropoda [Fossil tracks / Newly described trace fossil, Cretaceous / ]
   [ / Newly described trace fossil, Cretaceous, South Dakota / ] [South
   Dakota /  / newly described trace fossil] [Cretaceous /  / New genus
   described from fossil track] [ /  / ]. 
   Wakinyantanka [Fossil tracks / New genus possibly attributable to
   Theropoda (Reptilia), Cretaceous / ] [Cretaceous /  / New genus
   described from fossil track; Possibly attributable to Theropoda
   (Reptilia)]. 
   Wakinyantanka styxi [Fossil tracks / New species possibly attributable

   Theropoda (Reptilia); Fossil]. 
   Wakinyantanka styxi (Animalia): [Sp nov, South Dakota, Cretaceous, P.
   463, Described from fossil track, possibly attributable to Theropoda
   (Reptilia); Fossil].

DT Article
TI THE ICHNOTAXONOMY OF HOPPING VERTEBRATE TRACKWAYS FROM THE CENOZOIC OF
   THE WESTERN USA.
AU Lockley, Martin G.
   Milner, Andrew R.C.
SO Bulletin of the New Mexico Museum of Natural History and Science
VL 62
PS 489-500
PD 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Tracks attributable to hopping vertebrates are rare in the fossil
   record. However, where they occur they are highly distinctive and easily
   differentiated from the tracks of other vertebrates that used different
   gaits. Among the groups of small extant vertebrates that hop, frogs,
   certain rodents, and some birds are well known. Trackways of two of
   these groups, frogs and rodents, occur in Cenozoic deposits of the
   western USA. However, despite highly distinctive and diagnostic
   morphologies, the material described here previously lacked any formal
   ichnotaxonomic designations. A well-preserved Eocene trackway of a frog
   from the Flagstaff Formation of Utah is here named Ranapes laci
   ichnogen. et ichnsp. nov. It is only the second example of frog
   footprints from the fossil record, and the first to show a clear
   trackway sequence with both manus and pes traces. Trackways of hopping,
   mouse-sized rodents occur quite abundantly in two Miocene deposits in
   the western USA (Colorado and Utah), where they registered trackways
   indicating both bipedal and quadrupedal progression. These rodent tracks
   have distinctive morphologies that justify the naming of the new
   ichnogenus Musaltipes represented by two easily differentiated
   ichnospecies: M. longidigitus, representing bipedal progression, and M
   occidens ichnosp nov., representing quadrupedal progression. Although
   the trackways of small hopping vertebrates are similar due to this
   distinctive mode of locomotion, they are different in detail due to
   differences in pedal and manual morphology pertaining to unrelated
   groups. In addition, they have hitherto been recorded from quite
   different paleoenvironments.
C1 Lockley, Martin G.; Univ Colorado, Dinosaur Trackers Res Grp, POB
   173364, Denver, CO, 80217, USA, USA.
SC Zoology; Paleontology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology
SN 1524-4156

   Land zones; Nearctic region; North America; USA; Geological time
   periods; Caenozoic; Tertiary; Neogene; Palaeogene

DT Article
TI FIRST MENTION OF THE FAMILY PSEUDONOTIDANIDAE (CHONDRICHTHYES:
   NEOSELACHII) IN THE JURASSIC OF NORMANDY.
AU Cuny, Gilles (gilles.cuny@gmail.com) 
   Tabouelle, Jerome
SO Bulletin Sciences et Geologie Normandes
VL 7
PS 21-28
PD 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The discovery of a tooth of cf. Pseudonotidanus sp. is reported from the
   Bathonian of Normandy. Its morphology supports the transfer of the
   species terencei from the genus Welcommia to the genus Pseudonotidanus.
   It also supports the idea that Pseudonotidanidae might be basal
   Hexanchiformes rather than Synechodontiformes.

DT Article
TI First record of Neuroterus galls on twigs in Mexico with description of
   two new species (Hym.: Cynipidae).
AU Pujade-Villar, Juli (jpujade@ub.edu) 
   Cibrian-Tovar, David
   Barrera-Ruiz, Uriel M.
   Melika, George
SO Butlleti de la Institucio Catalana d'Historia Natural
VL 78
PS 3-9
PD 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Two species of oak gallwasps, Neuroterus ellongatum Pujade-Villar &
   Melika n. sp. and N. verrucum Pujade-Villar n. sp., known from the
   asexual generations only, are described from Mexico. This is the first
   record of Neuroterus species which are inducing galls in twigs. Both
   species are inducing galls on an endemic Mexican oak, Quercus laeta.
   Data on the diagnosis, distribution and biology of the new species are
   given.
C1 Pujade-Villar, Juli; Univ Barcelona, Fac Biol, Avda Diagonal 645,
   Barcelona, E-08028, Spain, Spain.
EM jpujade@ub.edu
SC Parasitology; Zoology
SN 1133-6889
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Parasites diseases and disorders;
   Hosts; Land zones; Nearctic region; North America
DE Neuroterus ellongatum; Neuroterus verrucum [Plant hosts / Quercus laeta
   / New parasite species] [Mexico /  / New species from plant host]. 
TN Arthropods; Hymenopterans; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Hymenoptera, Apocrita, Terebrantia,
   Cynipoidea, Cynipidae

TI A new Mexican species (Hym., Cynipidae) inducing tuberous galls in twigs
   of oaks (Fagaceae).
AU Pujade-Villar, Juli (jpujade@ub.edu) 
   Garcia-Martinon, Rosa D.
   Equihua-Martinez, Amando
   Estrada-Venegas, Edith G.
   Ferrer-Suay, Mar
SO Butlleti de la Institucio Catalana d'Historia Natural
VL 78
PS 93-98
PD 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new cynipid gallwasp species, Andricus fusiformis Pujade-Villar n.
   sp., is described from Mexico. This species is known only from asexual
   females and induces stem galls in young shoots of Quercus obtusata.
   Diagnosis, biology and distribution data of this new species is given.
   Diagnostic characters are illustrated.

TI New or interesting Coleoptera from les Planes de Son and la mata de
   Valencia (Alt Aneu, Lleida Pyrenees).

AB Cryobius infimus sonensis ssp. n. and Trechus latebricola pallaresanus
   ssp. n. (Coleoptera: Carabidae) are described from Les Planes de Son i
   la mata de Valencia (Alt Aneu, Pyrenees of Lleida, northeastern Iberian
   Peninsula). Additional information is provided about other outstanding
   species cited in the study of the Coleoptera from Les Planes de Son i la
   mata de Valencia (Agullo et al., 2010), updating its Iberian
   distribution, and introducing some corrections to the published data.

DT Article
TI First record of the invasive tingid species Corythauma ayyari (Drake,
   1933) in the Iberian Peninsula (Insecta: Hemiptera: Heteroptera:
   Tingidae).
AU Roca-Cusachs, Marcos (marcosrocacusachs@gmail.com) 
   Goula, Marta
SO Butlleti de la Institucio Catalana d'Historia Natural
VL 78
PS 119-123
PD 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Corythauma ayyari (Drake, 1933) ( Heteroptera: Tingidae) is reported for
   the first time in the Iberian Peninsula. Four specimens were collected
   in Puigmolto (Sant Pere de Ribes, Barcelona, Spain), 45 km southwest of
   Barcelona city. This Oriental invasive species may become pest causing
   necrosis on the leaves of its host plant species, usually ornamental
   plants, among which jasmine (Jasminum sp.) is the most common.

   Barcelona, E-08028, Spain, Spain.

PT J
AN ZOOR15312074745
DT Article
TI Phytoplankton Monitoring in the Western Isles Region of the Bay of Fundy
   during 2007-2013.
AU Martin, J.L.
   LeGresley, M.M.
   Gidney, M.E.
SO Canadian Technical Report of Fisheries and Aquatic Sciences
VL 3105
PS i-v, 1-262
PD 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB A monitoring program was initiated in May 1987 to study phytoplankton
   populations in the Western Isles region of the Bay of Fundy, southwest
   New Brunswick. This report provides another 5 yr of total phytoplankton
   community data to add to the results from 1987-2006 published
   previously. Only 2012 and 2013 data for the harmful algal bloom (HAB)
   species, Alexandrium fundyense (paralytic shellfish poisoning) and all
   Pseudo-nitzschia species (amnesic shellfish poisoning or domoic acid
   poisoning), are presented in this document. Samples were collected for
   phytoplankton distribution and abundance at five locations-Brandy Cove,
   Lime Kiln Bay, Deadmans Harbour, the Wolves Islands, and mid
   Passamaquoddy Bay. Additional parameters measured included nutrients,
   Secchi depth, and depth profiles for fluorescence, temperature, and
   salinity and they are documented in a separate report. Samples were
   collected at the surface from all locations and additional discrete
   depths of 10 m, 25 m, and 50 m at the Wolves Islands for all years
   except 2013. Species observed at concentrations >=10 000 cells[center
   dot]L-1 during all five yr (2007-2011) were: Alexandrium fundyense,
   Chaetoceros socialis, Chaetoceros spp., Cylindrotheca closterium,
   Dictyocha speculum, Eutreptiella sp., Guinardia delicatula, Heterocapsa
   triquetra, Leptocylindrus minimus, Mesodinium rubrum, Pseudo-nitzschia
   delicatissima group, Pseudo-nitzschia pungens, Scrippsiella Trochoidea,
   Scrippsiella sp., Thalassiosira spp. as well as the groups of
   unarmoured/armoured dinoflagellates and tintinnids. There were ten
   species that occurred at concentrations greater than 100 000
   cells[center dot]L-1 in 2007. In 2008, 2009, 2010 and 2011 there were
   seven, eleven, eight and ten species, respectively observed at
   concentrations greater than 100 000 cells[center dot]L-1. M. rubrum and
   the P. delicatissima group have been observed at concentrations greater
   than 10 000 cells[center dot]L-1 during all of the past 25 yr. Highest
   concentrations of A. fundyense observed at our monitoring sites during
   the 2007-2013 period were 5.03 x 105 cells[center dot]L-1 on July 24,
   2007 at Deadmans Harbour. The highest numbers observed during other
   years were: 4.60 x 105 cells[center dot]L-1 on July 2, 2008 at Deadmans
   Harbour; 2.79 x 10 5 cells[center dot]L-1 on June 30, 2009 at Brandy
   Cove; 5.80 x 10 4 cells[center dot]L-1 on June 29, 2010 at the Wolves
   Islands; 1.03 x 105 cells[center dot]L-1 at Deadmans Harbour on July 19,
   2011; 1.57 x 104 cells[center dot]L-1 on May 15, 2012 at Deadmans
   Harbour; and 6.68 x 10 3 cells[center dot]L-1 at the Wolves on June 18,
   2013. The 2009 elevated Brandy Cove concentrations were the highest in
   the region for that year. This was also the first time since the time
   series was initiated that the greatest concentration was observed at
   Brandy Cove. During most years and at all stations, A. fundyense cells
   were minor components (<50%) of the total phytoplankton community. Data
   since 1995 indicate that there were 47 new (possibly introduced) species
   detected in the region.
C1 Martin, J.L.; Fisheries & Oceans Canada, Biol Stn, 531 Brandy Cove Rd,
   St Andrews, NB, E5B 2L9, Canada, Canada.
SC Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Zoology
SN 0706-6457
BD Ecology; Abiotic factors; Marine zones; Atlantic Ocean
DE Phytomastigophorea [Community structure /  / ] [Population dynamics /
   Population monitoring / ] [Abiotic factors / Environmental factors / ]
   [North Atlantic / Canada, New Brunswick, Bay of Fundy, Western Isles /
   distribution]. 
TN Protozoans
ST Protozoa, Sarcomastigophora, Mastigophora
OR Phytomastigophorea (Mastigophora). 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15312074745
DA 2020-09-17

PT J
AN ZOOR15312074744
DT Article
TI Phytoplankton Monitoring in the Western Isles Region of the Bay of Fundy
   during 2003-2006.
AU Martin, J.L.
   LeGresley, M.M.
SO Canadian Technical Report of Fisheries and Aquatic Sciences
VL 3100
PS i-v, 1-190
PD 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB A monitoring program was initiated in May 1987 to study phytoplankton
   populations in the Western Isles region of the Bay of Fundy, southwest
   New Brunswick. This report provides another four yr of data to add to
   the results from 1987-2002 published previously. Samples were collected
   for phytoplankton distribution and abundance at five locations -Brandy
   Cove, Lime Kiln Bay, Deadmans Harbour, the Wolves Islands and mid
   Passamaquoddy Bay. Additional parameters measured included plant
   nutrients (ammonia, nitrite, nitrate, phosphate and silicate), Secchi
   depth, and depth profiles for fluorescence, temperature and salinity
   which are documented in a separate report. Samples were collected at the
   surface from all locations and additional discrete depths of 10 m, 25 m,
   and 50 m at the Wolves Islands. Species observed at concentrations >= 10
   000 cells.L-1 during all of the four yr (2003 to 2006) were: Alexandrium
   fundyense, Chaetoceros debilis, Chaetoceros socialis, Chaetoceros spp.,
   Dictyocha speculum, Eutreptiella sp., Guinardia delicatula, Heterocapsa
   triquetra, Leptocylindrus minimus, Mesodinium rubrum, Pseudo-nitzschia
   delicatissima group, Pseudo-nitzschia seriata group, and Skeletonema
   costatum. In addition to the previously listed species, there were seven
   species that occurred at concentrations greater than 100 000 cells.L-1
   in 2003 and six species that were observed at concentrations greater
   than 100 000 cells.L-1 in 2004 and 2006 while 2005 only had five species
   above this threshold. There was one group of species, the P.
   delicatissima group that reached concentrations greater than one million
   cells.L-1 in 2005 and 2006. M. rubrum and the P. delicatissima group
   have been observed at concentrations greater than 10 000 cells.L-1
   during all of the past 20 yr. Highest concentrations of A. fundyense
   (the organism responsible for producing paralytic shellfish toxins)
   observed at our monitoring sites during 2003 were 9.07 x 104 cells.L-1
   on September 9 at the Wolves Islands. The highest numbers observed
   during 2004, 2005 and 2006 were 3.19 x 105 cells.L-1 on August 3 at the
   Wolves Islands; 5.2 x 104 cells.L-1 on July 12 at Lime Kiln, and 4.9 x
   104 cells.L-1 at Lime Kiln on July 25, respectively. The years 2003 and
   2004 were unusual because massive concentrations of A. fundyense
   (similar to those observed in the late 1970s and 1980) were observed and
   resulted in salmon mortalities at culture operations.
C1 Martin, J.L.; Fisheries & Oceans Canada, Biol Stn, 531 Brandy Cove Rd,
   St Andrews, NB, E5B 2L9, Canada, Canada.
SC Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Zoology
SN 0706-6457
BD Ecology; Abiotic factors; Marine zones; Atlantic Ocean
DE Phytomastigophorea [Community structure /  / ] [Population dynamics /
   Population monitoring / ] [Abiotic factors / Environmental factors / ]
   [North Atlantic / Canada, New Brunswick, Bay of Fundy, Western Isles /
   distribution]. 
TN Protozoans
ST Protozoa, Sarcomastigophora, Mastigophora
OR Phytomastigophorea (Mastigophora). 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15312074744

PT J
AN ZOOR15510065127
DT Article
TI Revision of Neotropical Aphrophorine Spittlebugs, Part 3: A New
   Caribbean Tribe Leocomiini (Hemiptera, Cercopoidea).
AU Hamilton, K.G. Andrew (hamiltona@agr.gc.ca) 
SO Caribbean Naturalist
VL 11
PS 1-45
PD 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new tribe Leocomiini, related to Orthoraphini and Capnodistini, is
   described from the Caribbean Basin and Central America. Seven genera and
   33 species are described and keyed, including 2 new genera, Arcadiana
   and Lepyronura, plus 12 new species: Arcadiana acunai and Dasyoptera
   spinifera from Cuba; Enocomia jamaicensis, Lepyronura bulbosa, and L.
   minuenda from Jamaica; L. furcata from Hispaniola; Epicranion martorelli
   from Puerto Rico; E. contrastum, E. ferrudorsum, Leocomia cincta, and L.
   pedestris from Central America; plus Epicranion (Conicranion subg.nov.)
   trispinatum from Venezuela. Asprocranites Ramos, 1957 is synonymized
   with Dasyoptera Metcalf&Bruner, 1925; Gaeta Metcalf&Bruner and
   Pseudocraniolum Hedicke are reduced to subgenera of Leocomia Ball; and
   Gaetopsis Ramos plus Leocomiopsis Metcalf and Bruner are made subgenera
   of Enocomia and Epicranion, respectively. These changes create 9 new
   combinations, and 2 other species are synonymized: Leocomia grisea
   (Metcalf and Bruner, 1925) with L. maestralis Metcalf and Bruner, 1925;
   and L. fulva (Metcalf and Bruner, 1925) with L. pileae (Metcalf and
   Bruner, 1925). One species is renamed Dasyoptera fasciata to replace the
   secondary homonym created when Asprocranites variegata Ramos, 1957 is
   transferred by generic synonymy. All these changes are summarized in a
   checklist. The phylogeny and distribution of Leocomiini indicates an
   origin on Caribbean islands with subsequent dispersal to the mainland.
C1 Hamilton, K.G. Andrew; Agr & Agrifood Canada, Cent Expt Farm, KW Neatby
   Bldg, Ottawa, ON, K1A 0C6, Canada, Canada.
EM hamiltona@agr.gc.ca
SC Zoology
SN 2326-7119

   Combination; Synonymy; Available name; Taxonomy; Taxonomic position;
   Status; Key; Land zones; Nearctic region; Neotropical region; North
   America; Central America; West Indies; South America

   Liolaemus puritamensis - Nunez & Fox 1989 (Iguanidae): [Syn nov,
   Liolaemus filiorum Pincheira-Donoso y Ramirez 2005, p. 114]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15206039026
OA DOAJ Gold

PT J
AN ZOOR15402006095
DT Article
TI HYDROGEN AND OXYGEN STABLE ISOTOPIC ANALYSIS OF ANIMAL BONE COLLAGEN
   FROM ERLITOU SITE, YANSHI, HENAN PROVINCE.
AU Si Yi (simuxuan@163.com) 
   Li Zhipeng
   Hu Yaowu
   Yuan Jing
   Wang Changsui
SO Disiji Yanjiu
VL 34
IS 1
PS 196-203
PD Jan 2014
PY 2014
LA Chinese
U1 0
U2 2
AB Currently, hydrogen and oxygen stable isotopic analysis of bone collagen
   of humans or animals from archaeological sites has been increasingly
   used in palaeodietary reconstruction in international bioarchaeological
   fields. Basically, the hydrogen and oxygen in bone collagen are from the
   foods and drinking water consumed by humans or animals,which is derived
   from the living ecosystem directly. Therefore, differentiation of
   hydrogen and oxygen isotope values can provide valuable information on
   the diets, drinking water, palaeoclimate and palaeoenvironment as well
   as potential organism movement. Although this technique is
   blooming,there has been no any similar study reported in China. Erlitou
   site, believed to be an exceptionally large urban center of Erlitou
   culture, is located in Erlitou Village of Zhaizhen Town, Henan Province,
   China, dating to 1880 [approximately] 1521 BC according to the
   chronological studies from the Xia-Shang-Zhou chronology project.
   According to the marvelous archaeological features, this site is
   generally regarded as the capital of Xia Dynasty. To understand animal
   feeding strategies and possible migrations, bone samples of 31 animals
   from the Erlitou site were chosen for hydrogen and oxygen stable isotope
   analysis of bulk bone collagen. Samples were comprised of 6 cattle (Bos
   sp.),6 sheep (Ovis sp.),13 pigs (Sus scrofa domesticus), and 6
   deer(Cervus nippon). There is no exact criteria to reveal the bone
   diagenesis of hydrogen and oxygen specifically. Therefore, the integrity
   of bone collagen is used as the only standard to reveal the possible
   contamination. The indexes, such as the collagen yields, carbon and
   nitrogen contents and atomic C/N ratios of bone collagen from all
   samples, are all located with the well-preserved range, indicating that
   the collagen extracted can be used for isotopic analysis. Hydrogen
   isotope analysis suggests that the pigs as omnivore had higher mean 8D
   value (-63.6[plus or minus]7.1[per mill],n=13) than other animals (deer,
   cattle and sheep) as herbivore, which relates to the isotopic enrichment
   along the trophic level. However,this trend is not significant if one
   outliner of pig is omitted. The standard deviation of [delta]18O values
   of pigs is the lowest (0.3[per mill]) among the four kinds of animals,
   which possibly relate with the strict control on breeding time and
   slaughter age for pigs by humans. Compared with the wild animal (deer
   with the mean value of 9.1 [plus or minus] 0.7[per mill]o,n = 5),higher
   mean [delta]18O values for domestic cattle (10.4 [plus or minus] 0.
   4[per mill],n = 5) and sheep (11.1 [plus or minus] 0. 6[per mill], n =
   5) are observed, due to more open habitat and the consumption of more C4
   plants (millets by-products) and plant fiber fed by humans. Furthermore,
   the mean [delta]18O value of sheep is higher than that of cattle,due to
   the fact that sheep relied more on plant stems or leaves to gain the
   drinking water. It is interesting to note that ruminant animals (deer,
   cattle, and sheep) had higher [delta]18O values than non ruminant
   animals (pigs), which can be interpreted as the differences of
   metabolism and resources of food and drinking water. At last, some
   individuals with unusual [delta]D or [delta]18O values within each
   animal species might be caused by the tribute or cultural exchange from
   other places to the Erlitou site.
C1 Si Yi; Chinese Acad Sci, Inst Vertebrate Paleontol & Paleoanthropol,
   Beijing, 100044, China, China.
EM simuxuan@163.com
SC Zoology; Biochemistry &Molecular Biology; Anatomy &Morphology; Nutrition
   &Dietetics; Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Paleontology
SN 1001-7410
BD Biochemistry; Skeletal and supporting structures; Skeleton; Nutrition;
   Ecology; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia; China;
   Geological time periods; Caenozoic; Quaternary
DE Bos; Cervus nippon; Ovis; Sus scrofa domesticus [Biochemistry / Hydrogen
   & oxygen stable isotopic analysis / comparative study] [Bone / Bone
   collagen / ] [Diet / Palaeodiet / ] [Trophic structure / Trophic level /
   ] [Henan / Yanshi, Erlitou Site / ] [Holocene /  / ]. 
TN Chordates; Mammals; Ungulates; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Mammalia, Artiodactyla, Bovidae,
   Cervidae, Suidae
OR Bos (Bovidae): [Fossil]. 
   Ovis (Bovidae): [Fossil]. 
   Cervus nippon (Cervidae): [Fossil]. 
   Sus scrofa domesticus (Suidae): [Fossil]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15402006095
DA 2020-09-17

DT Article
TI A new species of Galumna (Galumna) (Acari, Oribatida, Galumnidae) from
   Vietnam.
AU Ermilov, Sergey G. (ermilovacari@yandex.ru) 
   Anichkin, Alexander E.
SO Ecologica Montenegrina
VL 1
IS 1
PS 9-14
PD 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Oribatid mite species of the family Galumnidae, Galumna (Galumna)
   parakazakhstani sp. nov., is described from litter of pine plantation in
   Dong Nai Culture and Nature Reserve (southern Vietnam). The new species
   is most similar to G. (G.) kazakhstani Krivolutskaya, 1952, however, it
   differs from the latter by the body size, morphology of bothridial setae
   and notogastral porose areas Al, development of anterior notogastral
   margin, and location of medial pore.

TI Checklist of the water mites (Acari, Hydrachnidia) of Iran: Second
   supplement and description of one new species.
AU Pesic, Vladimir (vladopesic@gmail.com) 
   Smit, Harry
   Saboori, Alireza
SO Ecologica Montenegrina
VL 1
IS 1
PS 30-48
PD 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB As a supplement to the list of the mite fauna of Iran compiled by Pesic
   and Saboori (2007), an additional faunistic list of water mites (Acari,
   Hydrachnidia) from Iran is presented based on recently published data.
   The total number of species and subspecies of water mites (Acari,
   Hydrachnidia) recorded from Iran up to date is 186 species, in 43 genera
   and 25 families. Based on new material, one new species, Atractides
   elburzensis n. sp. is described from a stream in N Iran.

TI First finding of epibiont peritrich and suctorian ciliates (Ciliophora)
   on oligochaetes and harpacticoid copepods from the deep-water
   hypoxic/anoxic conditions of the Black Sea.
AU Sergeeva, Nelli (nserg05@mail.ru) 
   Dovgal, Igor
SO Ecologica Montenegrina
VL 1
IS 1
PS 49-54
PD 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Three species of commensal ciliates (Cothurnia maritima Ehrenberg, 1838
   on oligochaete Tubificoides sp.; Paracineta livadiana (Mereschkowsky,
   1881) and Corynophrya lyngbyi (Ehrenberg, 1834) on harpacticoid copepods
   Amphiascella subdebilis (Willey, 1935), Haloschizopera pontarchis Por,
   1959, Cletodes tenuipes Scott, 1896 and Enhydrosoma longifurcatum Sars,
   1909) were found in the Black Sea deep-water under hypoxic/anoxic
   conditions for the first time. Corynophrya lyngbyi is reported for the
   first time in the Black Sea.

DT Article
TI Tandonia bolensis n. sp., a new slug (Gastropoda: Pulmonata: Milacidae)
   from the island of Brae (Dalmatia, Croatia).
AU De Mattia, Willy (Willy.DeMattia@icgeb.org) 
   Nardi, Gianbattista
SO Ecologica Montenegrina
VL 1
IS 3
PS 123-130
PD 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The genus Tandonia Lessona & Pollonera, 1882 is represented along the
   Western Balkans by about 13 taxa, most of which are regional endemics.
   Recent collecting on the island of Brae (Croatia) has provided a single,
   fully grown specimen of a totally black slug. A careful investigation of
   the genital anatomy and body traits, reveal characteristic and unique
   morphological features which until now have never been observed in other
   representatives of the genus. Such results have led to the description
   of new species. Tandonia bolensis n. sp. is easily distinguishable by
   virtue of its genital features, the dummy-like penial-atrial papilla,
   and the long and partially spiral-convoluted, thorny spermatophore.
C1 De Mattia, Willy; ICGEB, Padriciano 99, Trieste, I-34149, Italy, Italy.
EM Willy.DeMattia@icgeb.org
SC Zoology
SN 2336-9744; 2336-9744

   Eurasia; Europe

   Tandonia bolensis [Croatia /  / New species]. 
TN Invertebrates; Molluscs
ST Animalia, Mollusca, Gastropoda, Pulmonata, Stylommatophora, Vitrinoidea
OR Tandonia (Vitrinoidea). 
   Tandonia bolensis (Vitrinoidea): [Sp nov, Croatia, P. 125].

TI Pholeuonopsis (Pholeuonopsis) perucensis sp n., a new troglobitic
   leiodid beetle (Coleoptera: Leiodidae: Cholevinae: Leptodirini) from
   Bosnia and Herzegovina.
AU Curcic, Srecko (srecko@bio.bg.ac.rs) 
   Vrbica, Maja
   Vesovic, Nikola
   Mulaomerovic, Jasminko
   Curcic, Bozidar
SO Ecologica Montenegrina
VL 1
IS 3
PS 176-183
PD 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new leptodirine beetle species, Pholeuonopsis (Pholeuonopsis)
   perucensis sp. n., from a cave in Eastern Bosnia and Herzegovina is both
   described and diagnosed. The structure of both male and female genitalia
   and other taxonomically important characters are imaged. The new beetle
   species is clearly distinct from all other congeners. It probably
   belongs to an old phyletic lineage of Tertiary origin, like other known
   Pholeuonopsis taxa from the Western Balkan Peninsula. The new species is
   both an endemic and a relict inhabiting solely Eastern Bosnia and
   Herzegovina.
C1 Curcic, Srecko; Univ Belgrade, Inst Zool, Studentski Trg 16, Belgrade,
   11000, Serbia, Serbia.
EM srecko@bio.bg.ac.rs

   Eurasia; Europe

   species].

TI Trechus (Trechus) nezlobinskyi, a new high-altitude ground beetle

AU Hristovski, Slavco (slavco_h@pmf.ukim.mk)

IS 3

PD 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Trechus (Trechus) nezlobinskyi sp. n. is described from a high-altitude
   area of Jablanica Mt. (southwest Republic of Macedonia). The new species
   belongs to the "obtusiusculus" group of species and it is treated as
   most closely related to Trechus (Trechus) ravasinianus Lorenz, 1998 from
   Central Albania. The diagnostic characters of the new species are
   described and illustrated.

DT Article
TI Checklist of the water mites (Acari, Hydrachnidia) of Korea, with
   description of one new subgenus and two new species.
AU Pesic, Vladimir (vladopesic@gmail.com) 
SO Ecologica Montenegrina
VL 1
IS 4
PS 204-230
PD 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Using published records and original data, a checklist was compiled of
   the water mite (Acari, Hydrachnidia) fauna of Korea. The total number of
   species and subspecies recorded from Korea up to date is 74 species, in
   32 genera and 13 families. One new subgenus, Orientmomonia, and two new
   species are described: Albia (Albiella) kseniae and Momonia
   (Orientmomonia) koreana; the first description of the male is given for
   Atractides gracilis (Sokolow, 1934). Woolastookia concava Kim & Chung,
   1996 is synonymized with W. elongata (Sokolow, 1934). Additionally,
   first records for Korea are given for Panisopsis orientalis Imamura &
   Mitchell, 1967, Hydrodroma torrenticola (Walter, 1908), Hygrobates
   (Hygrobates) longiporus Thor, 1898, and Arrenurus (Truncaturus) sp. near
   corsicus (E. Angelier, 1951).
C1 Pesic, Vladimir; Univ Montenegro, Dept Biol, Podgorica, 81000,
   Montenegro, Montenegro.
EM vladopesic@gmail.com
OI Pesic, Vladimir/0000-0002-9724-345X

TI Two new species of the genus Bythinella Moquin-Tandon, 1856 (Mollusca:
   Gastropoda: Hydrobiidae) from the Western Balkan Peninsula.
AU Gloeer, Peter (gloeer@malaco.de) 
   Pesic, Vladimir
SO Ecologica Montenegrina
VL 1
IS 4
PS 249-255
PD 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Two new species of the genus Bythinella Moquin-Tandon, 1856, i.e. B.
   marici n. sp. from Bosnia and Hercegovina, and B. istoka n. sp. from
   Kosovo were described. The holotypes of both species as well as the
   penis morphology are depicted. In addition a list and distribution map
   of the Bythinella spp. occuring in the Western Balkan Peninsula is
   provided.

DT Article
TI Paragonimus gondwanensis n. sp. (Digenea, Paragonimidae), parasite of
   mammals (humans and carnivores) in Cameroon.
AU Bayssade-Dufour, Christiane
   Chermette, Rene
   Sundic, Danijela
   Radujkovic, Branko M. (danijelasun@yahoo.com) 
SO Ecologica Montenegrina
VL 1
IS 4
PS 256-267
PD 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Paragonimus gondwanensis n. sp. (hitherto undescribed) is reported from
   the lungs of naturally infected cat (Felis catus Linnaeus, 1758) and
   civet (Civettictis civetta (Schreber, 1776)) from Cameroon. Its
   description is based on the morphology of adult worms but also, on the
   dimension of fresh, living eggs released from naturally and
   experimentally infected cats and hospitalized patients (in the metraterm
   of worms, emitted in the beginning of prepatent period and laid by
   living worm), length of prepatent period and duration of eggs
   incubation. The presence of this species in human patients is confirmed.
C1 Radujkovic, Branko M.; Univ Montenegro, Fac Sci, POB 5455, Podgorica,
   81000, Montenegro, Montenegro.
EM danijelasun@yahoo.com

PT J
AN ZOOR15411078645
DT Article
TI Digenetic trematodes from siganid fish Amphacanthus sigan at Macady Bay,
   Southern Hurghada, Red Sea, Egypt.
AU Abd El-Latif, Mohey El-Din Z.
   Mohammed, Tarek Abdel-Aziz Ahmed (tare_mote@yahoo.com) 
SO Egyptian Journal of Aquatic Research
VL 40
IS 4
PS 451-458
PD 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Forty fish samples of Amphacanthus sigan were collected from Sharm
   El-Naga southern Hurghada to study the parasitic infection included and
   present a new individual to Helicometra species using light microscope
   and re-describe another digenean trematode species using scanning
   electron microscope (SEM). Two trematode species were identified and
   described; Helicometra siganus n. sp. Nov belonging to Helicometra
   Odhner, 1902 (family Opecoelidae Ozaki, 1925) which is different from
   all the listed species in many features as having an elongated body,
   tapering anteriorly and larger sucker ratio; the vitellaria extended
   from the intestinal bifurcation to the posterior extremity of the
   hind-body and finally the cirrus sac and cirrus longer than the other
   species and extended to the midpoint of esophagus level. So, these
   criteria are specific and sufficient to consider it as a new species.
   The other species, Gyliauchen volubilis Nagaty, 1956 (Gyliauchenidae
   Fuki, 1929 and Ozaki, 1933) which was described before but some other
   constituent are not evident and appeared using the electron microscope.
   However, the present sample illustrated transverse striations on the
   body surface, the acetabulum evaginates outward, ovoid shaped and
   surrounded by lip-like structures and finally, the excretory pore is
   situated at some distance from the acetabulum at the posterior end
   extremity. (C) 2014 National Institute of Oceanography and Fisheries.
   Hosting by Elsevier B.V.
C1 Mohammed, Tarek Abdel-Aziz Ahmed; Natl Inst Oceanog & Fisheries, Red Sea
   Branch, Hurghada, Egypt, Egypt.
EM tare_mote@yahoo.com
SC Zoology; Parasitology
SN 1687-4285
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Description; Parasites
   diseases and disorders; Parasites; Helminth parasites; Hosts; Marine
   zones; Indian Ocean; North Indian Ocean
DE Amphacanthus sigan [Digenean parasites / Gyliauchen volubilis / Parasite
   redescription] [ / Helicometra siganus / New parasite species] [Red Sea
   / Egypt / New platyhelminth parasite species] [ / Egypt, Hurghada,
   Macady Bay / ]. 
   Gyliauchen volubilis [Piscean hosts / Amphacanthus sigan /
   Redescription] [Red Sea / Egypt, Hurghada, Macady Bay / ]. 
   Helicometra siganus [Piscean hosts / Amphacanthus sigan / New parasite
   species] [Red Sea / Egypt / New species from piscean host]. 
TN Chordates; Fish; Invertebrates; Platyhelminths; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Pisces, Osteichthyes, Actinopterygii,
   Perciformes, Siganidae, Platyhelminthes, Trematoda, Digenea
OR Amphacanthus sigan (Siganidae): [Host]. 
   Gyliauchen volubilis - Nagaty 1956 (Digenea): [Redescription, P. 456;
   Parasite]. 
   Helicometra - Odhner 1902 (Digenea): [Diagnostic characters of
   subordinate taxa, P. 455]. 
   Helicometra siganus (Digenea): [Sp nov, Egypt (marine), Parasite of

DT Article
TI The Crambinae from Ethiopia and Mozambique collected by the University
   of Molise expeditions in 2008 and 2009 (Lepidoptera: Pyraloidea:
   Crambidae, Crambinae).
AU Bassi, G. (graziano.bassi@alice.it) 
   Trematerra, P.
SO Entomologia (Pavia)
VL 2
IS 1
PS 35-45
PD 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB This study sterns from samples of Crambinae specimens collected in
   Ethiopia and Mozambique by the University of Molise, Italy. A list
   species with their known distribution is given; Ancylolomia parentii
   Bassi, sp. n., Angustalius casandra Bassi, sp. n., Calamotropha dagamae
   Bassi, sp. n., Ccilamotropha virginfae Bassi, sp. n., and Crambus
   bellinii Bassi, sp n. are described. The new synonymy Chrysocatharylla
   agraphellus (Hampson, 1919)=Chrysocatharylla fusca Bassi, 1999, syn. n.
   and Angustalius malacellus (Duponchel, 1936)=Crambus hapaliscus Zeller,
   1852, syn rev are established. A lectotype for Crambus hapaliscus
   Zeller, 1852 is designated and the female genitalia of Ancylolomia
   tnelanothoracia Hampson, 1919 and Ancylolornia obscurella de Joannis,
   1927 are illustrated for the first time.

DT Article
TI Description and biological features of a new species of Anagrus Haliday
   (Hymenoptera, Mymaridae).
AU Nugnes, F.
   Viggiani, G. (genviggi@unina.it) 
SO Entomologia (Pavia)
VL 2
IS 1
PS 65-72
PD 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Anagrus lindberginae sp. n. (Hymenoptera: Mymaridae), an egg parasitoid
   of the leafhopper Lindbergina aurovittata (Homoptera: Cicadellidae), is
   described from Italy. It is included in the atoms group of Anagrus
   Haliday and compared with the allied known taxa. The parasitoid's life
   cycle is characterized by a long larval diapause from spring to fall,
   which allows for synchronization with its leafhopper host; other
   biological traits of A. lindberginae on the evergreen plant Quern's ilex
   are discussed.
C1 Viggiani, G.; Univ Naples Federico II, Dipartimento Agraria, Via Univ
   133, Portici, NA, Italy, Italy.
EM genviggi@unina.it
SC Zoology; Parasitology
SN 2281-9584
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Key; Parasites diseases
   and disorders; Parasites; Insect parasites; Hosts; Insect hosts; Land
   zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Europe
DE Anagrus atomus group [Europe /  / Key to species]. 
   Anagrus lindberginae [Hemipteran hosts / Lindbergina aurovittata / New
   parasite species] [Italy /  / New species from hemipteran host]. 
   Lindbergina aurovittata [Hymenopteran parasites / Anagrus lindberginae /
   New parasite species] [Italy /  / New hymenopteran parasite species].

DT Article
TI Tettigonia balcanica, a new species from the Balkan Peninsula
   (Orthoptera, Tettigoniidae).
AU Chobanov, D.P. (dchobanov@gmail.com) 
   Lemonnier-Darcemont, M.
   Darcemont, C.
   Puskas, G.
   Heller, K.G.
SO Entomologia (Pavia)
VL 2
IS 2
PS 95-106
PD 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Tettigonia balcanica, sp. n., discovered in the mountainous regions of
   the Central, Western and North Balkan Peninsula, is described in this
   paper. This species has many similarities with T. silana and T. cantans.
   However, it differs by the song and some morphological characters. Its
   range differs from that of T. cantans, with which it has been confused
   so far, but the border between their ranges has yet to be specified.
C1 Chobanov, D.P.; Bulgarian Acad Sci, Inst Biodivers & Ecosyst Res, 1 Tsar
   Osvoboditel Blvd, Sofia, 1000, Bulgaria, Bulgaria.
EM dchobanov@gmail.com

   Communication; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Europe

   ] [Bulgaria /  / ] [Croatia /  / ] [Greece /  / ] [Macedonia /  / ].

DT Article
TI DESCRIPTION OF A NEW SPECIES OF THE BRISTLETAIL GENUS Pedetontinus SILV.
   (THYSANURA, MACHILIDAE) FROM CHINA WITH A REVIEW OF SPECIES OF THIS
   GENUS.
AU Kaplin, V.G. (ctenolepisma@mail.ru) 
SO Entomologicheskoe Obozrenie
VL 93
IS 3-4
PS 628-645
PD 2014
PY 2014
NT Serial normally translated cover to cover in: Entomological Review.
LA Russian
U1 0
U2 3
AB A new species of a bristletail, Pedetontinus kabaki sp. n. is described
   from Sichuan Province, China. It has compound eyes clearly longer than
   wide, with the contact line less than 0.5, paired ocelli relatively
   closer to each other, and fore femur swollen. A key to 18 described
   species of the world fauna is given. The plesiomorphic and apomorphic
   states of 13 characters of Pedetontinus are considered; the phylogenetic
   relationships of species are discussed.
C1 Kaplin, V.G.; Samara State Acad Agr Village Ust Kinelsky, Moscow,
   Russia, Russia.
EM ctenolepisma@mail.ru

   Sciences &Ecology

   Asia; China

   region / East / ].

DT Article
TI A NEW TRIBE, A NEW GENUS, AND A NEW SPECIES OF THE SUBFAMILY
   DICTYOPHARINAE (HOMOPTERA, DICTYOPHARIDAE) FROM CHILE.
AU Emeljanov, A.F. (hemipt@zin.ru) 
SO Entomologicheskoe Obozrenie
VL 93
IS 3-4
PS 646-652
PD 2014
PY 2014
NT Serial normally translated cover to cover in: Entomological Review.
LA Russian
U1 0
U2 0
AB Rancoda rakitovi gen. et sp. n. is described from Chile (La Campana
   National Park, Valparaiso Region), for which a new monotypical tribe
   Rancodini trib. n. is established in the subfamily Dictyopharidae. The
   characteristic features of the new tribe are sharp brachyptery (the
   Orgerioid habitus), presence of Sensory pits in the imago, two spines in
   the inner group on the apices of hind tibia, simple median carina on
   abdominal tergites, and straight margin between the metopa and clypeus.
   The similarity with the advanced representatives Of the subfamily
   Orgeriinae (sensory pits in the imago) is convergent and is conibined
   with primitive characters absent in all Orgeriinae but present in the
   Dictyopharinae.
C1 Emeljanov, A.F.; RAS, Inst Zool, St Petersburg, Russia, Russia.
EM hemipt@zin.ru
SC Zoology; Anatomy &Morphology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology
SN 0367-1445
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; General morphology; Ecology;
   Community structure; Land zones; Neotropical region; South America
DE Dictyopharidae [General morphology /  / systematics; taxonomic
   implications] [Species diversity /  / ]. 
   Rancoda rakitovi [Chile /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; True Bugs
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Hemiptera, Homoptera, Auchenorrhyncha,
   Fulgoroidea, Dictyopharidae
OR Dictyopharidae (Fulgoroidea). 
   Rancoda (Dictyopharidae): [Gen nov, of new tribe Rancodini, Type species
   Rancoda rakitovi, p. 647]. 
   Rancoda rakitovi (Dictyopharidae): [Sp nov, Chile, P. 650]. 
   Rancodini (Dictyopharidae): [Tribe nov, of subfamily Dictyopharinae,
   Type genus Rancoda, p. 647].

DT Article
TI A NEW SPECIES OF THE BLISTER-BEETLE GENUS Meloe L. (COLEOPTERA,
   MELOIDAE) FROM TAJIKISTAN.
AU Shapovalov, A.M. (Andrej-shapovalov@yandex.ru) 
SO Entomologicheskoe Obozrenie
VL 93
IS 3-4
PS 662-665
PD 2014
PY 2014
NT Serial normally translated cover to cover in: Entomological Review.
LA Russian
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new Species Meloe (Meloe) kulabensis sp. n. is described from
   southwestern Tajikistan (Kulob, = Kulyab). The new species is
   characterized by the rather slender legs with almost straight
   inesotibia, comparatively long and narrow tarsi, metatarsomere 1 almost
   5 times as long as wide, comparatively large transverse diameter of eye
   (distance between eyes three times transverse diameter of eye), free
   (not merging) punctation, and peculiar structure of male genitalia.
   Similarly to Meloe ovalicollis Reitt. the new species has a narrow brush
   of short and not dense hairs on the ventral side of protarsomeres 1-4.
   Meloe ovalicollis recorded for the first time for Kazakhstan and
   Tajikistan.
C1 Shapovalov, A.M.; RAS, Inst Zool, St Petersburg, Russia, Russia.
EM Andrej-shapovalov@yandex.ru
SC Anatomy &Morphology; Zoology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology
SN 0367-1445
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; General morphology; Ecology;
   Community structure; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Meloe [General morphology /  / taxonomic implications] [Species
   diversity /  / ] [Asia / Middle Asia / distribution]. 
   Meloe (Meloe) kulabensis [Tajikistan /  / New species]. 
   Meloe ovalicollis [Kazakhstan /  / New record] [Tajikistan /  / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Polyphaga, Tenebrionoidea,
   Meloidae
OR Meloe (Meloidae). 
   Meloe (Meloe) kulabensis (Meloidae): [Sp nov, Tajikistan, P. 662]. 
   Meloe ovalicollis (Meloidae): [New record].

DT Article
TI CLASSIFICATION OF GALL MIDGES OF THE SUPERTRIBE BRACHINEURIDI (DIPTERA,
   CECIDOMYIIDAE: LASIOPTERINAE) WITH DESCRIPTION OF THE NEW GENERA AND NEW
   SPECIES FROM THE KURILE ISLANDS.
AU Fedotova, Z.A. (zoya-fedotova@mail.ru) 
SO Entomologicheskoe Obozrenie
VL 93
IS 3-4
PS 666-739
PD 2014
PY 2014
NT Serial normally translated cover to cover in: Entomological Review.
LA Russian
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new classification is proposed for the gall-midge supertribe
   Brachineuridi including 4 tribes, 9 subtribes, 24 genera and 156
   species: Brachineurini (Brachineurina 4 genera, 23 species; Epimyiina -
   4 genera, 9 species); Undoneurini trib. n. (Undoneurina subtrib. n. - 5
   genera, 8 species; Coccidomyiina subtrib. n. - 2 genera, 8 species);
   Rhizomyiini stat. n. (Rhizomyiina - 4 genera, 33 species; Stellaserenina
   subtrib. n. - 3 genera, 3 species); Ledomyiini (Ledomyiina - 8 genera,
   61 species; Acinacistylina subtrib. n. - 2 genera, 5 species;
   Kovaleviolina subtrib. n. - 2 genera, 3 species), and also 2 genera
   Palaeospaniocera Meunier, 1901 (1 species) and Ledomyiella Meunier, 1904
   (4) with unclear systematic position. One new tribe, 5 subtribes, 3
   genera and 7 species (Stellaserena vaga gen. et sp. n., Stelladiurna
   flustra gen. et sp. n., Kuriloneura multifida gen. et sp. n., K. trifida
   sp. n., Cornistyla tufa sp. n., Rhizomyia flammula sp. n., Acinacistyla
   sundukovi sp. n.) are described. Keys to the tribes, subtribes, genera
   and species of Brachineuridi are given. Genera Ramineura stat. n. and
   Cornistyla stat. n. are promoted from subgenera of Brachineura. A new
   synonymy is established: genus Pararhizomyia Mamaev, 1998, stat. n. (=
   Effusomyia Fedotova, 2004, syn. n.). New combinations are formed:
   Ramineura ussurica (Fedotova, 2004), comb. n. (Brachineura), R. musiva
   (Fedotova et Sidorenko, 2006a), comb. n. (Brachineura), R. subulata
   (Fedotova et Sidorenko), comb. n. (Brachineura) and R. alia (Mamaev,
   1994), comb. n. (Brachineura); Cornistyla nijveldti (Fedotova, 2004),
   comb. n. (Brachineura), C. flabellata (Fedotova et Sidorenko, 2006a),
   comb. n. (Brachineura), C. infirma (Fedotova et Sidorenko, 2006), comb.
   n. (Brachineura); Cingola pleiomorpha (Mamaev, 1998), comb. n.
   (Brachyneurina), Stabiliola arsenjevi (Fedotova, 2004), comb. n.
   (Brachyneurina); S. umbra (Fedotova et Sidorenko, 2006b), comb. n.
   (Rhizomyia), Alatostyla binaria (Mamaev, 1998), comb. n. (Rhizomyia),
   Ledomyia eocenica (Meunier, 1904), comb. n. (Ledomyiella), Kovaleviola
   pyxidiiformis (Fedotova, 2005), comb. n. (Brachyneurina).
C1 Fedotova, Z.A.; All Russian Inst Plant Protect, St Petersburg, Russia,
   Russia.
EM zoya-fedotova@mail.ru

   Sciences &Ecology; Paleontology

PT J
AN ZOOR15407042493
DT Article
TI A re-examination of the Portuguese Microlepidoptera collected by the
   Reverend A. E. Eaton in 1880.
AU Corley, Martin F.V. (martin.corley@btinternet.com) 
   Goodey, Brian
SO Entomologist's Gazette
VL 65
IS 1
PS 15-25
PD 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A small collection of Microlepidoptera made by A. E. Eaton in Portugal
   in 1880 with specimens determined by H. T. Stainton has been
   re-examined. Sixty-one specimens belong to 43 species including one
   which cannot be safely named. Sixteen species mentioned by Stainton are
   misidentifications and 12 of these must be deleted from the Portuguese
   faunal list.
C1 Corley, Martin F.V.; Pucketty Farm Cottage, Faringdon, Oxon, SN7 8JP,
   United Kingdom, United Kingdom.
EM martin.corley@btinternet.com

SN 0013-8894

   Eurasia; Europe

   misidentifications; A.E. Eaton collection].

PT J
AN ZOOR15407042503
DT Article
TI Western Palaearctic Oedicephalini and Phaeogenini (Hymenoptera:
   Ichneumonidae, Ichneumoninae) in the National Museums of Scotland, with
   distributional data including 28 species new to Britain, rearing
   records, and descriptions of two new species of Aethecerus Wesmael and
   one of Diadromus Wesmael.
AU Diller, Erich
   Shaw, Mark R. (Erich.Diller@zsm.mwn.de) 
SO Entomologist's Gazette
VL 65
IS 2
PS 109-129
PD 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB An account is given of approximately 3,250 western Palaearctic
   specimens, comprising 110 determined species, of the tribes
   Oedicephalini and Phaeogenini in the National Museums of Scotland.
   Distributional and phenological data are given for all species, and
   rearing records are provided for about 50, although not always with the
   host's identity fully clear. Twenty eight species are newly recorded
   from Britain, of which Aethecerus horstmanni sp. nov., Aethecerus
   ruberpedatus sp. nov. and Diadromus nitidigaster sp. nov. are described
   and figured. Tycherus histrio (Wesmael, 1848) sp. rev. is raised from
   synonymy with Tycherus ischiomelinus (Gravenhorst, 1829); Dicaelotus
   schmiedeknechti nom. nov. is provided for Dicaelotus ruficornis
   (Schmiedeknecht, 1903) nec (Ashmead, 1890); Aethecerus subuliferus
   (Holmgren, 1890) is proposed as a comb. nov.; and Phaeogenes nigridens
   Wesmael, 1848, is proposed as a comb. rev.
C1 Shaw, Mark R.; Natl Museums Scotland, Chambers St, Edinburgh,
   Midlothian, EH1 1JF, United Kingdom, United Kingdom.
EM Erich.Diller@zsm.mwn.de

   Kingdom

DT Article
TI Identification of Buchnera sp., symbiont of Toxoptera aurantii.
AU Perez-Lopez, Edel
   Luis Pantoja, Maritza
SO Fitosanidad
VL 18
IS 2
PS 115-117
PD 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Aphids are phloem-feeding insects which have developed symbiotic
   association with bacteria to acquire amino acids lacking in the phloem.
   Toxoptera aurantii affecting Macadamia integrifolia trees in Cuba were
   analyzed for the presence of Buchnera aphidicola, to characterize the
   aphids and find efficient management methods. The PCR amplification and
   sequencing showed that in all populations detected in every tree, was
   present the symbiotic bacteria. The phylogenetic analysis indicates that
   the bacteria detected could be new specie belonging to Buchnera genus,
   and is the first report of this bacterium in T. aurantii.
C1 Perez-Lopez, Edel; Univ Veracruzana, Inst Biotecnol & Ecol Aplicada,
   Avenida Culturas Veracruzanas 101, Xalapa, Veracruz, 91090, Mexico,
   Mexico.
SC Zoology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology
SN 1562-3009; 1023-1277
BD Associations; Land zones; Neotropical region; Central America; West
   Indies
DE Toxoptera aurantii [Associations / Buchnera (bacterium) / New record;
   symbiosis; bacterial identification] [Cuba / Artemisa / Bacterial
   associates]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; True Bugs
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Hemiptera, Homoptera, Sternorrhyncha,
   Aphidoidea
OR Toxoptera aurantii (Aphidoidea): [New record]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15303015882
DA 2020-09-17
ER

DT Article
TI Introduction to the knowledge of the subfamily Aleocharinae from the
   Australian Region (Part I) (Coleoptera, Staphylinidae).
AU Pace, R. (pace.ent@tiscali.it) 
SO Folia Entomologica Hungarica
VL 75
PS 21-56
PD 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The present study treats 42 species belonging to 8 tribes
   (Leucocraspedini, Pronomaeini, Gyrophaenini, Homalotini, Diestotini,
   Bolitocharini, Falagriini, Athetini (Part I)) and 16 genera
   (Leucosraspedum, Myllaena, Gyrophaena, Brachida, Austrobrachida,
   Sternotropa, Brachyglyptaglossa, Coenonica, Diestota, Tasgnathusa,
   Falagria, Ischnopoda, Aloconota, Australoconotida, Australoconota,
   Giachinusa), 3 of them being new to science (Austrobrachida,
   Tasgnathusa, Australoconotida). Of these species, 33 are described as
   new to science: Myllaena gullyensis sp. n., Gyrophaena fustigans sp. n.,
   Gyrophaena nadgeensis sp. n., Brachida caraiensis sp. n., Austrobrachida
   conwayensis sp. n., Sternotropa australicola sp. n., Brachyglyptaglossa
   australiae sp. n., Coenonica wilsonensis sp. n., Coenonica brownicola
   sp. n., Coenonica orbicularis sp. n., Coenonica perpusilla sp. n.,
   Coenonica coffsensis sp. n., Coenonica micropapuana sp. n., Diestota
   hartzmontium sp. n., Tasgnathusa hartzmontium sp. n., Tasgnathusa
   australiana sp. n., Falagria neoguineana sp. n., Ischnopoda benepicta
   sp. n., Aloconota cabbagicola sp. n., Aloconota lornensis sp. n.,
   Aloconota microculata sp. n., Aloconota lawersensis sp. n.,
   Australoconotida caudapiscis sp. n., Australoconota microtheca sp. n.,
   Giachinusa wilsonmontis sp. n., Giachinusa brownicola sp. n., Giachinusa
   alternata sp. n., Giachinusa superba sp. n., Giachinusa wilsonicola sp.
   n., Giachinusa truncata sp. n., Giachinusa minor sp. n., Giachinusa
   lamingtonicola sp. n., and Giachinusa forticornis sp. n. With 112
   figures.

PT J
AN ZOOR15301007094
DT Article
TI On the Trichoptera of Batanta Island (Indonesia, Papua, Raja Ampat
   Archipelago), III.
AU Olah, J. (profolah@gmail.com) 
SO Folia Entomologica Hungarica
VL 75
PS 91-131
PD 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new genus and 15 new species of caddisflies are described from Batanta
   Island of West Papua, Indonesia: Horvathomina gen. n., Chimarra kalija
   sp. n., Horvathomina gergoi sp. n., H. akosi sp. n., H. martoni sp. n.,
   Tinodes topor sp. n., T. vagot sp. n., Nyctiophylax (Paranyctiophylax)
   egyes sp. n., Polyplectropus ollos sp. n., P. pohos sp. n., Abacaria
   kovacsi sp. n., Goera batanta sp. n., Triplectides dombos sp. n., T.
   karimas sp. n., T. rojtos sp. n. and T. sugaras sp. n. New records of 40
   species are given. Details of fine structure analysis of paraproct are
   discussed. The ancient plesiomorphic and derived apomorphic character
   states are surveyed in genera of the family Ecnomidae. Taxonomic value
   of wing venation, spur number and genitalic traits are evaluated for
   species delimitation in the genus Triplectides Kolenati, 1859.
   Harpagones and mesal lobe of the gonopods in Triplectides are
   non-neutral adaptive traits under directional sexual selection, and
   provide consistent and stable fine structure to delimit species
   boundaries. With 73 figures.
C1 Olah, J.; Tarjan U 28, Debrecen, H-4032, Hungary, Hungary.
EM profolah@gmail.com
SC Zoology; Anatomy &Morphology; Cardiovascular System &Cardiology;
   Reproductive Biology
SN 0373-9465
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Techniques; General morphology;
   Appendages; Circulatory system; Blood vessels; Reproduction;
   Reproductive system; Land zones; Oriental region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Abacaria kovacsi; Chimarra kalija; Goera batanta; Horvathomina akosi;
   Horvathomina gergoi; Horvathomina martoni; Nyctiophylax
   (Paranyctiophylax) egyes; Polyplectropus ollos; Polyplectropus pohos;

   Triplectides rojtos; Triplectides sugaras [Indonesia /  / New species]. 
   Trichoptera [Indonesia / Irian Jaya, Batanta / Faunal list; new record;
   systematics]. 
   Triplectides [Identification techniques / Species delimitation / ]
   [Wings / Wing venation / ] [Veins /  / ] [Genitalia / Genitalic traits /
   ].

   Goera batanta (Trichoptera): [Sp nov, Indonesia, P. 118]. 
   Horvathomina (Trichoptera): [Gen nov, Of family Ecnomidae, Type species
   Horvathomina gergoi, p. 98].

   Horvathomina gergoi (Trichoptera): [Sp nov, Indonesia, P. 101]. 
   Horvathomina martoni (Trichoptera): [Sp nov, Indonesia, P. 103].

AN ZOOR15301007097
DT Article
TI Braconidae (Hymenoptera) from Tunisia, 4. Fourteen subfamilies.
AU Papp, J. (j.papp1933@gmail.com) 
SO Folia Entomologica Hungarica
VL 75
PS 143-166
PD 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB One hundred and twenty-seven braconid species belonging to 14
   subfamilies are reported from Tunisia. Two species are described as new:
   Bracon (Glabrobracon) flavobasis sp. n. (Braconinae) and Pholetesor
   moczari sp. n. (Microgastrinae), their descriptions and nearest allies
   are presented. Ninety-eight species are new to the fauna of Tunisia, one
   species, Frekius barbieri (Fischer, 1962) (Opiinae) is new to Spain.
   With 31 figures.
C1 Papp, J.; Hungarian Nat Hist Museum, Dept Zool, Baross Utca 13,
   Budapest, H-1088, Hungary, Hungary.
EM j.papp1933@gmail.com

   species].

   Frekius barbieri [Spain /  / New record].

   [Diagnostic characters, P. 159].

TI Two new species of Coproica Rondani, 1861 (Diptera: Sphaeroceridae) from
   the Afrotropical region.
AU Papp, L. (flyer.papp@gmail.hu) 
SO Folia Entomologica Hungarica
VL 75
PS 183-191
PD 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Two new species of Coproica Rondani, 1861 are described from the
   Afrotropical region: Coproica ashleyi sp. n. (Republic of South Africa,
   Nigeria) and C. paraunispinosa sp. n. (Kenya, Tanzania). Both are sister
   species ("vicariants") of Oriental species. A revised key for the C.
   serra species group is given. With 16 figures.

TI Valdesetosum atrum gen. et sp. nov. from Honduras (Coleoptera:
   Dermestidae: Megatominae).
AU Hava, Jiri (jh.dermestidae@volny.cz) 
SO Folia Heyrovskyana Series A
VL 22
IS 2-4
PS 9-12
PD 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Valdesetosum atrum gen. et sp. nov. from Honduras is described,
   illustrated and compared with similar Neotropical genera. The new genus
   belongs to the subfamily Megatominae, tribe Megatomini and differs from
   similar genera by the long shape of its setose body and structure of
   antennae.

TI A review of 'Group 1' of the genus Paulianellus (Coleoptera:

   Kral, David
   Rakovic, Miloslav

VL 22
IS 2-4
PS 54-73
PD 2014

LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Species of the genus Paulianellus Balthasar, 1938, which belong to
   "Group 1", as considered by Stebnicka (1986), are reviewed and keyed.
   The following three new species are described: Paulianellus laoticus sp.
   nov. from Laos and Thailand, Paulianellus neomaderi sp. nov. from China
   (Shaanxi, Sichuan and Yunnan) and Paulianellus taiwanensis sp. nov. from
   China (Taiwan). The species Paulianellus asahinai (Nakane, 1951) comb.
   nov. is revalidated and a further new combination, Paulianellus
   mureensis (Stebnicka, 1981) comb. nov., is proposed.

TI Mycetochara kazdagiica sp. nov. from Turkey (Coleoptera: Tenebrionidae:
   Alleculinae: Mycetocharini).
AU Novak, Vladimir (alleculinae.vn@centrum.cz) 
   Oncul Abacigil, Tuba
   Varli, Sakin Vural
   Jansson, Nicklas
SO Folia Heyrovskyana Series A
VL 22
IS 2-4
PS 134-141
PD 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The saproxylic beetle fauna on old hollow oaks was studied in Kazdaoi
   National Park near Edremit, Balikesir in Turkey in 2011. In the
   material, a new species of comb-clawed beetles (Tenebrionidae:
   Alleculinae) was found. This species, Mycetochara kozdagiica Novak sp.
   nov., is described, illustrated and compared with the similar species
   Mycetochara axillaris (Paykull, 1799).

TI New species of Clytini Mulsant, 1839 from the Oriental Region
   (Coleoptera: Cerambycidae: Cerambycinae).
AU Viktora, Petr (viktora_print@centrum.cz) 
SO Folia Heyrovskyana Series A
VL 22
IS 2-4
PS 148-179
PD 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Demonax moraveci sp. nov. and Rhaphuma discreta sp. nov. from Thailand,
   Demonax tryznai sp. nov. from India, Demonax novaki sp. nov., Rhaphuma
   hajeki sp. nov., Rhaphuma jakli sp. nov. and Rhaphuma ryjaceki sp. nov.
   from Laos, Chlorophorus undosus sp. nov., Demonax pardus sp. nov. and
   Rhaphuma carolusi sp. nov. from Peninsular Malaysia are described and
   illustrated. Chlorophorus puncticollis Dauber, 2003 obviously belongs to
   the genus Rhaphuma. Rhaphuma puncticollis Dauber, 2003 hom. nov. is new
   homonym of Rhaphuma puncticollis Holzschuh, 1992. For this reason, I
   named it Rhaphuma dauberi Viktora, nomen novum. Chlorophorus lepesmei
   Pic, 1950 is transferred to the genus Rhaphuma Pascoe, 1858 as Rhaphuma
   lepesmei (Pic, 1950) comb. nov.

DT Article
TI On the type specimen of Otiorhynchus (Dodecastichus) ambrosii Bertolini,
   with a catalogue of Dodecastichus (Coleoptera: Curculionidae).
AU Colonnelli, Enzo (ecolonnelli@yahoo.it) 
   Casalini, Roberto
SO Fragmenta Entomologica
VL 46
IS 1-2
PS 11-17
PD 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Study of the type specimen of Otiorhynchus ambrosii Bertolini, 1893
   allowed to reinstate the synonymy: Dodecastichus mastix (Olivier, 1807)
   (= Otiorhynchus (Dodecastichus) ambrosii Bertolini, 1893; syn. n.). As a
   consequence, the following synonymy is also established: Dodecastichus
   consentaneus (Boheman, 1842) (= Otiorhynchus (Dodecastichus)
   consentaneus alticola A. Solari & F. Solari, 1915; syn. n.). A revised
   list of Dodecastichus Stierlin, 1861 is also drawn up to correct some
   errors in the latest 2013 catalogue, to include the revised synonymies
   above, and additional data on all the species of the genus. The
   alternative original spelling Dodecastichus oligostictus (J. Muller,
   1946) is selected over Dodecastichus oligolepis (J. Muller, 1946), both
   used in the description of this species.
C1 Colonnelli, Enzo; Via Delle Giunchiglie 56, Rome, I-00172, Italy, Italy.
EM ecolonnelli@yahoo.it
SC Zoology
SN 0429-288X
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Synonymy; Documentation; Publications; Land
   zones

ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Polyphaga, Curculionoidea,
   Curculionidae
OR Dodecastichus (Curculionidae). 
   Dodecastichus (Dodecastichus) oligolepis - (J. Mueller 1946)
   (Curculionidae): [Spelling, P. 12]. 
   Dodecastichus (Dodecastichus) oligostictus - (J. Mueller 1946)
   (Curculionidae): [Spelling, P. 12]. 
   Dodecastichus consentaneus - (Boheman 1842) (Curculionidae): [Syn nov,
   Otiorhynchus (Dodecastichus) consentaneus alticola A. Solari & F. Solari
   1915, p. 12]. 
   Dodecastichus mastix - (Olivier 1807) (Curculionidae): [Syn nov,
   Otiorhynchus (Dodecastichus) ambrosii Bertolini 1893, p. 11].

PT J
AN ZOOR15201005520
DT Article
TI Revision of the pollen beetle genus Meligethes (Coleoptera:
   Nitidulidae).
AU Audisio, Paolo
   Sabatelli, Simone
   Jelinek, Josef (paolo.audisio@uniromal.it) 
SO Fragmenta Entomologica
VL 46
IS 1-2
PS 19-112
PD 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 1
U2 4
AB A taxonomic revision of members of the genus Meligethes Stephens, 1830
   is carried out. Taxonomic and distributional notes are provided on
   fiftythree Meligethes species, mostly known from the Eastern Palearctic
   and marginally from the Western Palearctic and the Oriental Regions.
   Among these, twentythree new species of Meligethes are diagnosed,
   figured and described: M argentithorax sp. n. (Central China: Shaanxi,
   Shanxi), M aurantirugosus sp. n. (Nepal), M aureolineatus sp. n.
   (Central China: Sichuan), M aurifer sp. n. (Central China: Shaanxi,
   Shanxi), M brassicogethoides sp. n. (SW China: Yunnan), M clinei sp. n.
   (SW China: Yunnan), M elytralis sp. n. (Central China: Sichuan), M
   ferruginoides sp. n. (Central China: Sichuan), M cinereoargenteus sp. n.
   (Central China: Sichuan), M henan sp. n. (Central China: Henan), M
   luteoornatus sp. n. (SW China: Yunnan), M marmota sp. n. (Nepal), M
   nivalis sp. n. (SW and central China: Xizang and Chongqing), M martes
   sp. n. (Central China: Shaanxi, Shanxi, Sichuan), M nigroaeneus sp. n.
   (SW China: Yunnan), M occultus sp. n. (SW China: Yunnan), M
   pseudochinensis sp. n. (Central China: Hubei), M pseudopectoralis sp. n.
   (SW China: Yunnan), M schuelkei sp. n. (Central China: Sichuan,
   Shaanxi), M simulator sp. n. (Central-N China: Shanxi), M stenotarsus
   sp. n. (SW China: Yunnan, Xizang), M tryznai sp. n. (SW China: Yunnan),
   and M volkovichi sp. n. (SW China: Yunnan). Revaluations at specific
   rank from synonymy are introduced for Meligethes lutra Solsky 1860, and
   for M melleus Grouvelle, 1908. Three new synonymies are established:
   Meligethes brevipilus Kirejtshuk, 1980 = M auripilis Reitter, 1889 (syn.
   n.), Meligethes zakharenkoi Kirejtshuk, 2005 = M shirakii Sadanari
   Hisamatsu, 1956 (syn. n.), and Meligethes shirozui Sadanari Hisamatsu,
   1965 = M wagneri Rebmann, 1956 (syn. n.). Complete redescriptions are
   given for Meligethes binotatus Grouvelle, 1894, M castanescens
   Grouvelle, 1903, M ferrugineus Reitter, 1873, and M melleus Grouvelle,
   1908. The male of Meligethes lloydi Easton, 1968, is described and
   figured for the first time. The female genitalia of Meligethes auricomus
   Rebmann, 1956, M cinereus Jelinek, 1978, and M griseus Jelinek, 1978 are
   described and figured for the first time. Available information on
   insect-host-plant relationships and ecology are summarized for each
   species; probably all are associated as larvae with flowers of Rosaceae,
   chiefly of members of the closely related genera Rosa L., Rubus L.,
   Prunus L., and Crataegus Tourn. ex L. All treated species are grouped in
   two here revaluated subgenera (Meligethes s.str. and Odonthogethes
   Reitter, 1871), and tentatively grouped also in species-groups and (when
   necessary) species-complexes, based on their morphology.
C1 Jelinek, Josef; Natl Museum Circusova 1740, Dept Entomol, Praha, Horni
   Pocernice, CZ-19300, Czech Republic, Czech Republic.
EM paolo.audisio@uniromal.it
SC Zoology; Anatomy &Morphology; Biochemistry &Molecular Biology; Nutrition
   &Dietetics; Genetics &Heredity; Evolutionary Biology
SN 0429-288X
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type material; Description;
   Synonymy; Taxonomy; Documentation; Publications; Biometrics; General
   morphology; Biochemistry; Nutrition; Diet; Genetics; Evolution;
   Zoogeography; Land zones; Oriental region; Palaearctic region; Eurasia;
   Asia; China
DE Meligethes [Checklists /  / taxonomic revision; distribution]
   [Biometrics / Morphometrics / ] [General morphology /  / ] [Nucleic
   acids / DNA analysis / ] [Food plants /  / ] [Molecular genetics /  / ]
   [Phylogeny /  / ] [Zoogeography /  / ] [Oriental region /  / ]
   [Palaearctic region /  / ]. 
   Meligethes (Meligethes) argentithorax [Qinghai /  / New species]
   [Sichuan /  / ]. 
   Meligethes (Meligethes) aureolineatus; Meligethes (Meligethes)
   cinereoargenteus; Meligethes (Meligethes) elytralis [Sichuan /  / New
   species]. 
   Meligethes (Meligethes) aurifer [Shaanxi /  / New species] [Shanxi /  /
   ]. 
   Meligethes (Meligethes) clinei; Meligethes (Meligethes) stenotarsus;
   Meligethes (Meligethes) tryznai; Meligethes (Meligethes) volkovichi;
   Meligethes (Odonthogethes) brassicogethoides; Meligethes (Odonthogethes)
   luteoornatus; Meligethes (Odonthogethes) nigroaeneus; Meligethes
   (Odonthogethes) occultus; Meligethes (Odonthogethes) pseudopectoralis
   [Yunnan /  / New species].

   aurantirugosus [Nepal /  / New species].

   Meligethes (Odonthogethes) ferruginoides [Hubei /  / New species]
   [Sichuan /  / ]. 
   Meligethes (Odonthogethes) henan [Henan /  / New species]. 
   Meligethes (Odonthogethes) pseudochinensis [Hubei /  / New species]. 
   Meligethes (Odonthogethes) schuelkei; Meligethes (Odonthogethes)
   xenogynus [Shaanxi /  / New species] [Sichuan /  / ]. 
   Meligethes (Odonthogethes) simulator [Gansu /  / New species] [Shaanxi /
    / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Polyphaga, Cucujoidea,
   Nitidulidae
OR Meligethes - Stephens 1830 (Nitidulidae). 
   Meligethes (Meligethes) (Nitidulidae): [Status, P. 26]. 
   Meligethes (Meligethes) argentithorax (Nitidulidae): [Sp nov, Qinghai,

TI A new cave-dwelling Centromerus from Sardinia (Araneae: Linyphiidae).
AU Bosmans, Robert
   Gasparo, Fulvio (rop_bosmans@telenet.be) 
SO Fragmenta Entomologica
VL 46
IS 1-2
PS 113-116
PD 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Centromerus marciai sp. n. is described on both sexes on specimens
   collected in a karstic cave in the province of Nuoro, North-eastern
   Sardinia, Italy. Differences with other species of the genus Centromerus
   Dahl, 1886 occurring in Sardinia are pointed out.

PT J
