PT J
AN ZOOR15303019213
DT Article
TI A review of Microdontinae (Diptera: Syrphidae) of Surinam, with a key to
   the Neotropical genera.
AU Reemer, Menno (Menno.reemer@naturalis.nl) 
SO Tijdschrift voor Entomologie
VL 157
IS 1
PS 27-57
PD 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB The fauna of Microdontinae (Diptera: Syrphidae) of Surinam is reviewed,
   based on a recent field survey by the author and a re-evaluation of
   previously collected material, mostly deposited in the RMNH collection
   (Leiden). A key to all 28 Neotropical genera of the subfamily is given.
   A total number of 42 species belonging to 13 genera are recorded from
   Surinam. Habitus photographs of all species are given. Compared with the
   checklist of Van Doesburg (1966), 24 species are added and five are
   removed. The following new species are described: Domodon peperpotensis
   sp. n., Microdon (Microdon) colakriki sp. n., Peradon satyricus sp. n.
   and Peradon sciarus sp. n. Five possibly new species are left unnamed,
   pending revisionary work of the species groups they belong to. A neotype
   is designated for Aphritis angustus Macquart, 1846. The following new
   synonymies are proposed: Microdon instabilis Wiedemann, 1830 = Microdon
   aurifex Wiedemann, 1830 jun. syn. n., Microdon batesi Shannon, 1927 =
   Microdon beebei Curran, 1936 syn. n.
C1 Reemer, Menno; Naturalis Biodiversity Center, P.O. Box 9517, 2300 RA
   Leiden, Netherlands, Netherlands.
EM Menno.reemer@naturalis.nl
SC Zoology
SN 0040-7496
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type material; Synonymy; Taxonomy;
   Key; Documentation; Publications; Land zones; Neotropical region; South
   America
DE Domodon peperpotensis; Microdon (Microdon) colakriki [Surinam /  / New
   species]. 
   Microdontinae [Checklists / Updated checklist / Systematics; new &
   deleted records] [Neotropical region /  / Key to genera] [Surinam /  /
   ]. 
   Peradon satyricus; Peradon sciarus [French Guiana /  / New species]
   [Surinam /  / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; True Flies
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Diptera, Brachycera, Cyclorrhapha,
   Syrphidae
OR Aphritis angustus - Macquart 1846 (Syrphidae): [Neotype designated, P.
   43]. 
   Domodon peperpotensis (Syrphidae): [Sp nov, Surinam, P. 35]. 
   Microdon (Microdon) colakriki (Syrphidae): [Sp nov, Surinam, P. 39]. 
   Microdon instabilis - Wiedemann 1830 (Syrphidae): [Syn nov, Microdon
   aurifex Wiedemann 1830, p. 37]. 
   Microdontinae (Syrphidae): [Key to genera, Neotropical region, P. 51]. 
   Peradon satyricus (Syrphidae): [Sp nov, Surinam, P. 44].

AN ZOOR15303019214
DT Article
TI Australasian endemic no more: four new species of Miropotes Nixon
   (Hymenoptera, Braconidae, Microgastrinae), with the first record from
   the Oriental region.
AU Fernandez-Triana, J. (jftriana@uoguelph.ca) 
   van Achterberg, C.
   Whitfield, J.B.
SO Tijdschrift voor Entomologie
VL 157
IS 1
PS 59-77
PD 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Four new species of Miropotes Nixon (Hymenoptera, Braconidae,
   Microgastrinae) are described: Miropotes orientalis Fernandez-Triana &
   van Achterberg, from Thailand and Vietnam, and three species from
   Australia, M. austini, M. neglectus, and M. lordhowensis (all authored
   by Fernandez-Triana and Whitfield). A key to all known 14 species of the
   genus is provided, as well as brief, software-generated descriptions
   (Lucid 3.5.4). Miropotes is distributed mostly within the Australasian
   region, although it is here reported for the first time for the Oriental
   region. The relationships with other genera of Microgastrinae are
   briefly discussed.

PT J
AN ZOOR15303019215
DT Article
TI Synopsis of Cotesia species, biological agents for pest control on
   vegetables in Vietnam, with description of one new species.
AU Long, Khuat Dang (khuatdanglong@iebr.ac.vn) 
   Dzung, Dang Thi
SO Tijdschrift voor Entomologie
VL 157
IS 2-3
PS 83-93
PD 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The biology of four allied species of the genus Cotesia Cameron is
   reviewed. All these species were reared from larvae of pest insects
   mainly belonging to the families Lymantriidae, Noctuidae, Pieridae and
   Plutellidae. They are larval endoparasitoids and considered as important
   agents for biological control of pest insects infesting different
   vegetable crops in Vietnam, such as cabbage, kohlrabi, small colza,
   cauliflower, peanut, soybeans, and various other legumes. Of those four
   species, Cotesia clethrogynae Long sp. n., is described as new and
   illustrated; the biology and distribution of the other three allied
   species are given, they are illustrated and compared, and a key to four
   species is provided.This paper resulted from the identification of a new
   species of Cotesia reared from limantrid larvae of Clethrogynae turbata
   Butler and the necessity to compare related species. The host is an
   important pest infestant on soybean, different beans, peas and peanut in
   Vietnam.
C1 Long, Khuat Dang; Institute of Ecology and Biological Resources (IEBR),
   VAST, 18 Hoang Quoc Viet Road, Cau Giay, Ha Noi, Vietnam, Vietnam.
EM khuatdanglong@iebr.ac.vn
SC Zoology; Parasitology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology
SN 0040-7496
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Key; Animals and man;
   Control; Parasites diseases and disorders; Parasites; Insect parasites;
   Hosts; Insect hosts; Land zones; Oriental region; Eurasia; Asia

   parasite species] [Vietnam /  / New hymenopteran parasite species].

   Cotesia clethrogynae [Lepidopteran hosts / Clethrogyna turbata / New
   parasite species] [Vietnam /  / New species from lepidopteran host]. 
   Lepidoptera [Biological control /  / biology; distribution; systematics;
   pests of vegetables] [Hymenopteran parasites / Cotesia / ] [ /  / Key to
   parasite species] [Vietnam /  / ] [ /  / Key to hymenopteran parasites].

PT J
AN ZOOR15303019216
DT Article
TI Tachinidae (Diptera) reared from Ropalidia nests (Hymenoptera: Vespidae)
   from Madagascar, with two new species of Anacamptomyia.
AU Zeegers, Theo (th.zeegers@xs4all.nl) 
SO Tijdschrift voor Entomologie
VL 157
IS 2-3
PS 95-103
PD 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB This paper deals with the Tachinidae reared from Ropalidia nests
   collected on Madagascar. The material belongs to two genera,
   Anacamptomyia and Parapales, each represented by two species. Both
   species of Anacamptomyia are described as new: A. aurifrons sp. n. and
   A. blommersi sp. n. Their relation to the species from the Afrotropical
   mainland is discussed. The host records for Parapales are the first for
   this genus, supporting their placement in the Anacamptomyia group.
C1 Zeegers, Theo; Eikenlaan 24, 3768 EV Soest, Netherlands, Netherlands.
EM th.zeegers@xs4all.nl
SC Zoology; Parasitology
SN 0040-7496

   Parasites diseases and disorders; Parasites; Insect parasites; Hosts;
   Insect hosts; Land zones; Afrotropical region; Africa

   [Madagascar /  / New species from hymenopteran host]. 
   Anacamptomyia group [Afrotropical region /  / Key to genera].

   Ropalidia grandidieri; Ropalidia variabilis [Dipteran parasites /

   Tachinidae, Hymenoptera, Apocrita, Aculeata, Vespoidea, Vespidae
OR Anacamptomyia - Bischof 1904 (Tachinidae): [Key to species, Madagascar,
   P. 97]. 
   Anacamptomyia africana - Bischof 1904 (Tachinidae): [Redescription, P.

   Anacamptomyia group (Tachinidae): [Key to genera, Afrotropical region,

DT Article
TI Synopsis of the Ethmiinae (Lepidoptera, Gelechioidea: Depressariidae) of
   the Afrotropical Region and descriptions of new species.
AU Mey, Wolfram (wolfram.mey@mfn-berlin.de) 
   Shovkoon, Dmitry F.
SO Tijdschrift voor Entomologie
VL 157
IS 2-3
PS 105-122
PD 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB In Africa south of the Sahara 55 valid species of the subfamily
   Ethmiinae have been recognised to date. These species are listed
   alphabetically including important synonyms. The country of origin and
   the depository of the type material are indicated. In this article seven
   new species are communicated from Kenya, Namibia and South Africa. They
   are described as Ethmia aberdaresi sp. n., Ethmia anikini sp. n., Ethmia
   kagamegensis sp. n., Ethmia karasbergensis sp. n., Ethmia kunenica sp.
   n., Ethmia kuisibi sp. n., and Ethmia fluviatilis sp. n. The adult moths
   of the new species are illustrated in colour. The male and female
   genitalia are depicted as black/white photos including line drawings of
   lateral and dorsal views of male genitalia. The systematic position of
   the new species is briefly discussed.
C1 Mey, Wolfram; Museum fuer Naturkunde, Leibniz-Institut fuer Evolutions-
   und Biodiversitaetsforschung an der Humboldt-Universitaet zu Berlin,
   Invalidenstrasse 43, 10115 Berlin, Germany, Germany.

U1 0
U2 0
AB Three species of Neurogenia Roman, 1910 are described as new from Asia:
   N. auco Reshchikov & van Achterberg sp. n. from Vietnam, N. kamapura
   Reshchikov sp. n. from India and N. sayama Reshchikov sp. n. from Japan.
   Group assignment changed for N. gorochovi (Kasparyan, 2008) comb. n. The
   other Asiatic species are reviewed and an illustrated, updated diagnosis
   of the genus and a key to the Asiatic species of Neurogenia are
   provided.

DT Article
TI Reconsideration of the Nearctic species Haliplus mimeticus Matheson and
   its relatives with description of a new species (Coleoptera:
   Haliplidae).
AU van Vondel, Bernhard J. (haliplus@kabelfoon.nl) 
SO Tijdschrift voor Entomologie
VL 157
IS 2-3
PS 137-144
PD 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB The three species of Nearctic Haliplidae related to Haliplus mimeticus
   Matheson, 1912 are re-examined. Two species, H. rugosus Roberts, 1913
   and H. eremicus Wells, 1989 are considered junior synonyms of H.
   mimeticus as characters used to distinguish the species proved to be
   variable and unreliable. A new species H. kenneri is described from Baja
   California, Mexico. The new species differs from H. mimeticus in the
   shape of the penis and the strongly serrate elytral apical margin.
C1 van Vondel, Bernhard J.; Natuurhistorisch Museum Rotterdam, p/o Roestuin
   78, 3343 CV Hendrik-Ido-Ambacht, Netherlands, Netherlands.
EM haliplus@kabelfoon.nl

SN 0040-7496

   Nearctic region; North America

   Haliplidae

DT Article
TI Hydroporus emergens sp. n. from south-western Turkey (Coleoptera:
   Dytiscidae).
AU Vorst, Oscar (oscar.vorst@naturalis.nl) 
   Fery, Hans
SO Tijdschrift voor Entomologie
VL 157
IS 2-3
PS 145-149
PD 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Hydroporus emergens sp. n. is described from Tekirova (south of Antalya)
   in the south-western part of Turkey. The species is provisionally
   attributed to the H. normandi-complex which is part of the H.
   memnonius-group of Hydroporus Clairville, 1806. With the new species the
   known distribution of that complex - which so far was considered
   strictly western Mediterranean - is considerably expanded to the eastern
   Mediterranean. The species is compared with its western relatives as
   well as described and illustrated in detail.
C1 Vorst, Oscar; Naturalis Biodiversity Center, PO Box 9517, NL-2300 RA
   Leiden, Netherlands, Netherlands.

   Eurasia

DT Article
TI Two new Peruvian species of Paravelia (Heteropera [Heteroptera]:
   Veliidae) from water-filled bamboo internodes, and distributional notes
   for other Paravelia species.
AU Polhemus, Dan A. (bugman@bishopmusuem.org) 
SO Tijdschrift voor Entomologie
VL 157
IS 2-3
PS 151-162
PD 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Two new species of Paravelia [long dash] P. loutoni and P. reclusa [long
   dash] are described from water-filled bamboo internodes in the forests
   of eastern Peru. Color dorsal habitus photographs of both species and
   line drawings of key male genitalic characters are provided, accompanied
   by a distribution map. Line drawings of the male genitalic structures of
   P. myersi Hungerford, the closest putative relative to these two new
   species, are also provided for comparison. Although Neotropical Veliidae
   have been previously reported from bromeliad phytotelmata, the current
   results from bamboo internodes are the first records for veliid
   utilization of this habitat in the Western Hemisphere, and indicate that
   further samples from such habitats are likely to result in the discovery
   of other heretofore undetected veliid species. New records are also
   provided for 12 other previously described Paravelia species; the new
   records serve to clarify the geographic ranges and ecological
   preferences of these taxa.
C1 Polhemus, Dan A.; Department of Natural Sciences, Bishop Museum, 1525
   Bernice St., Honolulu, HI 96817, USA, USA.
EM bugman@bishopmusuem.org
SC Marine &Freshwater Biology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Zoology
SN 0040-7496
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Habitat; Land zones; Neotropical
   region; South America
DE Paravelia [Freshwater habitat / Bamboo internodes / New habitat record]
   [South America /  / New records] [Peru /  / ]. 
   Paravelia loutoni; Paravelia reclusa [Peru /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; True Bugs
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Hemiptera, Heteroptera, Gerromorpha,
   Gerroidea, Veliidae
OR Paravelia (Veliidae): [New record]. 
   Paravelia loutoni (Veliidae): [Sp nov, Peru, P. 152]. 
   Paravelia reclusa (Veliidae): [Sp nov, Peru, P. 154].

DT Article
TI Ocyochterus irmae, a beautiful new species of Ochteridae (Heteroptera)
   from the Northern Andes.
AU Polhemus, Dan A. (bugman@bishopmusuem.org) 
   Polhemus, John T.
SO Tijdschrift voor Entomologie
VL 157
IS 2-3
PS 163-171
PD 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The new species Ocyochterus irmae is described from the Andes Mountains
   of Colombia and adjacent Ecuador. This species is only the second known
   in the genus, and the first in which male specimens have been available
   for dissection of the genitalic structures. A new record is also
   provided for the previously described O. victor (Bolivar), constituting
   only the fourth known specimen of this taxon since the original
   description in 1879, and the first new collection in over 90 years.
   Color photographs of the dorsal habitus and anterior head are presented
   for both O. irmae and O. victor, as well as photographic figures of the
   male parameres, aedeagus, proctiger and pygophore for O. irmae,
   representing the first illustrations of the male genitalic structures in
   this genus. A distribution map for O. irmae and O. victor is also
   provided.
C1 Polhemus, Dan A.; Department of Natural Sciences, Bishop Museum, 1525
   Bernice St., Honolulu, HI 96817, USA, USA.
EM bugman@bishopmusuem.org
SC Zoology
SN 0040-7496

   Neotropical region; South America

   Ocyochterus irmae [Colombia /  / New species] [Ecuador /  / ]. 
   Ocyochterus victor [Ecuador /  / Distribution; new record; systematics].

DT Article
TI SURVEY OF CORRELATION BETWEEN INTERNAL INTESTINE HELMINTHES WITH SEX,
   SEASON AND SIZE OF MARINE FISHES (BRACHIRUS ORIENTALIS) IN NORTH OF
   PERSIAN GULF-ABADAN HARBOR.
AU Bagherpour, Ali (Alibagherpour20@gmail.com) 
   Soltanialvar, Masoud
   Tavana, Mahdi
SO Trends in Life Sciences
VL 3
PS 33-39
PD 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB This study was conducted to identify intestinal helminthes parasites and
   Survey of correlation between this helminthes with sex, season and size
   of Marine fishes in North of Persian Gulf in Abadan harbor. The
   helminthes fauna is collected from body cavity and intestine of 100
   specimens, Brachirus orientalis obtained from Abadan harbor were
   investigated during the year 2013-2014. A lot of 4 species of helminthes
   were found in intestine and body cavity of examined fishes. The
   helminthes found was composed by 2 digenetic Trematodes (Lepocreadioides
   zebrine, Allocreadium brachirusii) all in adult state in intestine. A
   statistically significant correlation was observed between the fish
   parasites with sex and weight of fish in Lepocreadioides zebrine
   (P=0.03) and no significant correlation between the fish parasites with
   weight of fish in Allocreadium brachirusii, one nematode
   Hysterothylacium aduncum that the prevalence was23% the only cestod
   Protocephalus sp with 16%. Except Protocephalus sp which was reported
   previously often parasites species found in this study are reported for
   the first time from Iran. There is no significant correlation between
   the fish parasites with sex and weight of fish in Protocephalus sp
   (Sig>0.05).

DT Article
TI Revision of the world species of Chiloplatys Townes (Hymenoptera:
   Ichneumonidae: Tryphoninae).
AU Bennett, A.M.R. (Andrew.Bennett@AGR.GC.CA) 
   Barnes, D.I.
SO Trudy Russkogo Entomologicheskogo Obshchestva
VL 85
IS 1
PS 19-62
PD 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The world species of Chiloplatys Townes (Hymenoptera: Ichneumonidae:
   Tryphoninae) are revised including re-descriptions of the two previously
   described species: C. mexicanus (Cresson) and C. lucens Townes et
   Townes. The genus is endemic to the Neotropical region (previously known
   from only Mexico and Costa Rica) and is one of only eight genera of the
   tribe Tryphonini from the region. Ten new species are described: C.
   alophos sp. n., C. cenodontis sp. n., C. convergens sp. n., C. divergens
   sp. n., C. dmitrii sp. n., C. fasciatus sp. n., C. kalyx sp. n., C.
   melanosoma sp. n., C. oaxacaensis sp. n., and C. verticalis sp. n. The
   genus contains two monophyletic species groups: the C. lucens group and
   the C. mexicanus group. New country records for the genus are noted for
   Guatemala, Nicaragua and Ecuador, the latter being the first record of
   the genus from South America. A key to species is provided.
C1 Bennett, A.M.R.; Agr & Agri Food Canada, Canadian Natl Collect Insects,
   960 Carling Ave, Ottawa, ON, K1A 0C6, Canada, Canada.
EM Andrew.Bennett@AGR.GC.CA

SN 1605-7678

   zones; Nearctic region; Neotropical region; North America; Central
   America; South America

   Ichneumonoidea, Ichneumonidae

   species, P. 25; New record].

TI A revision of Sachtlebenia Townes, with notes on the species of
   Townesion Kasparyan (Hymenoptera: Ichneumonidae: Banchinae).

AB The genus Sachtlebenia (Ichneumonidae: Banchinae) is revised and two new
   species described, S. dmitrii sp. n. from Vietnam and S. gillae sp. n.
   from Brunei. The two species of the related genus Townesion are
   distinguished and T. japonicus Kasparyan is newly recorded from Russia
   (Sakhalin). Synapomorphies are proposed for Sachtlebenia and Townesion.

DT Article
TI Three new species of the genus Probles Forster (Hymenoptera:
   Ichneumonidae: Tersilochinae) from the Russian Far East.
AU Khalaim, A.I. (ptera@mail.ru) 
SO Trudy Russkogo Entomologicheskogo Obshchestva
VL 85
IS 1
PS 103-113
PD 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Three species of the genus Probles Forster belonging to the subgenus
   Euporizon Horstmann are described from the Russian Far East: P.
   carinator sp. n., P. dmitrii sp. n. and P. hankaensis sp. n. A partial
   identification key to Far Eastern species of Euporizon is provided.

   Petersburg, 199034, Russia, Russia.

DT Article
TI A new species of the genus Cremastus Gravenhorst (Hymenoptera:
   Ichneumonidae: Cremastinae) from Turkey.
AU Kolarov, J. (jkolarov@uni-plovdiv.bg) 
   Gurbuz, M.F.
   Birol, O.
SO Trudy Russkogo Entomologicheskogo Obshchestva
VL 85
IS 1
PS 114-116
PD 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Cremastus kasparyani sp. n. from Turkey is described. The new species is
   distinguished from all Western Palaearctic species by swollen and partly
   flattened from below trochantellus of hind leg.

PS 117-121

   Palaearctic region with asymmetric ovipositors, C. crassivalvus Hinz and

LA English
U1 0

AB Four new species of Metopiinae, Trieces kasparyani sp. n. from Belgorod
   Province of Russia, Exochus ignobilis sp. n. from Primorskiy Territory
   of Russia, E. dilutus sp. n. from South Kazakhstan Province (Kazakhstan)
   and E. callus sp. n. from Uzbekistan, Tajikistan and Almaty Province of
   Kazakhstan, are described. Female of E. pilosus Tolkanitz is recorded
   for the first time.

PT J
AN ZOOR15201000234
DT Article
TI A new species of the genus Trioxys Mackauer (Hymenoptera: Aphidiidae)
   from Sverdlovsk Province of Russia.
AU Davidian, E.M. (GDavidian@yandex.ru) 
SO Trudy Russkogo Entomologicheskogo Obshchestva
VL 85
IS 1
PS 157-159
PD 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species, Trioxys kasparyani sp. n., with short prongs on the
   terminal metasomal sternite is described from Sverdlovsk Province of
   Russia. Until now, only two Palaearctic species with short prongs, T.
   bicuspis Mackauer, 1960 and T. microceratus Mackauer, 1960, were known.
   Trioxys kasparyani sp. n. differs from these species by the spiracular
   tubercles situated in centre of the first tergite, shape of the
   ovipositor sheath, and prongs with apical and preapical setae hair-like
   and similar to each other.
C1 Davidian, E.M.; All Russian Inst Plant Protect, St Petersburg, 196608,
   Russia, Russia.
EM GDavidian@yandex.ru
SC Zoology
SN 1605-7678
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Taxonomy; Key; Land
   zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia
DE Trioxys [Palaearctic region /  / Key to species]. 
   Trioxys kasparyani [Russia /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Hymenopterans; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Hymenoptera, Apocrita, Terebrantia,
   Ichneumonoidea, Aphidiidae
OR Trioxys - Haliday 1833 (Aphidiidae): [Key to species, Palaearctic
   region, Portion of key, p. 158]. 
   Trioxys bicuspis - Mackauer 1960 (Aphidiidae): [Diagnostic characters,
   P. 159]. 
   Trioxys kasparyani (Aphidiidae): [Sp nov, Russia, P. 158]. 
   Trioxys microceratus - Mackauer 1960 (Aphidiidae): [Diagnostic
   characters, P. 159]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15201000234
DA 2020-09-17

DT Article
TI A new species of Encarsia Forster (Hymenoptera: Chalcidoidea:
   Aphelinidae) from Altamira, Tamaulipas, Mexico.
AU Myartseva, S.N. (smyartse@uat.edu.mx) 
SO Trudy Russkogo Entomologicheskogo Obshchestva
VL 85
IS 1
PS 165-169
PD 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new aphelinid species Encarsia dimai sp. n. is described and
   illustrated. It was reared from whitefly Aleurothrixus sp. (Aleyrodidae)
   collected on epiphyte plant Struthanthus sp. (Loranthaceae) in Altamira,
   State of Tamaulipas, Mexico. The genus Struthanthus is recorded for the
   first time as a host plant for whitefly genus Aleurothrixus.
C1 Myartseva, S.N.; Univ Autonoma Tamaulipas, Fac Ingn & Ciencias, Cd
   Victoria, Tamaulipas, 87149, Mexico, Mexico.
EM smyartse@uat.edu.mx

   Nearctic region; North America

   hymenopteran parasite species] [ /  / ].

PT J
AN ZOOR15201000237
DT Article
TI Nepolynema, a new genus of Mymaridae (Hymenoptera: Chalcidoidea), and
   its two new species from Costa Rica and Papua New Guinea.
AU Triapitsyn, S.V. (serguei.triapitsyn@ucr.edu) 
SO Trudy Russkogo Entomologicheskogo Obshchestva
VL 85
IS 1
PS 170-182
PD 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new fairyfly (Hymenoptera: Mymaridae) genus, Nepolynema gen. n., is
   described and diagnosed. Its type species, Barypolynema grandis Taguchi,
   1971, for which a neotype is designated, is re-described as N. grande
   (Taguchi) (comb. n., from Polynema Haliday) based on specimens from
   Japan and Taiwan (China, new record). Two new species, N kaspatyani sp.
   n. (Papua New Guinea) and N. shatenka sp. n. (Costa Rica), are described
   and illustrated. The new genus is compared with Agalmopolynema Ogloblin,
   Polynema, Stephanodes Enock and other relevant genera.
C1 Triapitsyn, S.V.; Univ Calif Riverside, Dept Entomol, Riverside, CA,
   92521, USA, USA.
EM serguei.triapitsyn@ucr.edu
SC Zoology
SN 1605-7678
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type species; Description;
   Combination; Taxonomy; Taxonomic position; Key; Land zones; Australasian
   region; Neotropical region; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia; Central
   America; Australasia
DE Nepolynema grande [Taiwan /  / New record]. 
   Nepolynema kasparyani [Papua New Guinea /  / New species]. 
   Nepolynema shatenka [Costa Rica /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Hymenopterans; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Hymenoptera, Apocrita, Terebrantia,
   Proctotrupoidea, Mymaridae
OR Barypolynema grandis - Taguchi 1971 (Mymaridae): [Designated type
   species for new genus, Nepolynema, p. 171]. 
   Nepolynema - Triapitsyn 2014 (Mymaridae): [Key to species, Females, p.
   175; Gen nov, Type species Barypolynema grandis Taguchi 1971, p. 171]. 
   Nepolynema grande - (Taguchi 1971) (Mymaridae): [Redescription, P. 176;
   Comb nov, Transferred from Polynema, p. 175; New record]. 
   Nepolynema kasparyani (Mymaridae): [Sp nov, Papua New Guinea, P. 179]. 
   Nepolynema shatenka (Mymaridae): [Sp nov, Costa Rica, P. 179]. 
   Polynema grande - (Taguchi 1971) (Mymaridae): [Referred to, New genus
   Nepolynema, p. 175].

PY 2014
LA English
U1 0

AB Seven species of the encyrtid wasp genus Encyrtus Latreille,
   characterized by the facial scrobes not meeting dorsally, are reviewed

DT Article
TI A new species of the genus Ormyrus Westwood (Hymenoptera: Ormyridae)
   from the Russian Far East.
AU Zerova, M.D. (zerova@izan.kiev.ua) 
   Seryogina, L. Ya
SO Trudy Russkogo Entomologicheskogo Obshchestva
VL 85
IS 1
PS 188-190
PD 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB A new species, Ormyrus kasparyani sp. n., is described from the Russian
   Far East. It differs from the similar species O. orientalis Walker, 1871
   in having a longer gaster (with particularly long epipygium), more
   distinct sculpture on the gastral terga in both sexes, less sharp
   longitudinal median carina in female, and bright blue-violet colour of
   the gaster, especially in female.
C1 Zerova, M.D.; Natl Acad Sci Ukraine, II Schmalhausen Inst Zool, 15 B
   Khmelnytsky St, Kiev, UA-01601, Ukraine, Ukraine.
EM zerova@izan.kiev.ua

   disorders; Parasites; Insect parasites; Hosts; Insect hosts; Land zones;
   Palaearctic region; Eurasia

   species] [Russia /  / New hymenopteran parasite species]. 
   Ormyrus kasparyani [Hymenopteran hosts / Dona / New parasite species]
   [Russia /  / New species from hymenopteran host].

TI Genus Entomacis Foerster, 1856 (Hymenoptera: Diapriidae) in the fauna of
   Russia, with description of two new species.
AU Chemyreva, V.G. (diapriidas.vas@gmail.com) 
SO Trudy Russkogo Entomologicheskogo Obshchestva
VL 85
IS 1
PS 191-198
PD 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A review of the Russian fauna of the genus Entomacis Foerster is
   provided. Two species of this genus, E. curticera sp. n. and E.
   kasparyani sp. n., are described from the Russian Far East. Entornacis
   penelope Nixon, E. graeffei Kieffer and E. hajeki Macek are recorded for
   the first time from Russia, E. perplexa (Haliday) from the Russian Far
   East, and E. platyptera (Haliday) from the European part of Russia. Key
   to seven species of Entomacis occurring in Russia is also provided.

DT Article
TI New Trematothoracinae (Hymenoptera: Sepulcidae) from the Lower
   Cretaceous of Transbaikalia.
AU Kopylov, D.S. (aeschna@yandex.ru) 
   Rasnitsyn, A.P.
SO Trudy Russkogo Entomologicheskogo Obshchestva
VL 85
IS 1
PS 199-206
PD 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Two species of Trematothoracinae, Trematothorax kasparyani sp. n. and T.
   demeter sp. n., are described from the Lower Cretaceous of
   Transbaikalia. The morphological features of Trematothoracinae, namely
   structure of mesonotum, size of metanotum, and "double" costal vein, are
   discussed.

DT Article
TI A REVIEW OF GENUS CYRTODACTYLUS (REPTILIA: SAURIA: GEKKONIDAE) IN FAUNA
   OF LAOS WTTH DESCRIPTION OF FOUR NEW SPECIES.
AU Nazarov, R.A. (r_nazarov@mail.ru) 
   Poyarkov, N.A., Jr
   Orlov, N.L.
   Nguyen, N.S.
   Milto, K.D.
   Martynov, A.A.
   Konstantinov, E.L.
   Chulisov, A.S.
SO Trudy Zoologicheskogo Instituta
VL 318
IS 4
PS 391-423
PD 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB We describe four new species of the genus Cyrtodactylus based on the
   results of phylogenetic analysis of 673 bp of the COI mtDNA gene and
   morphological description of voucher specimens from Khammouane and
   Vientiane provinces, Laos. The three of the new species, namely
   Cyrtodactylus khammouanensis sp. nov., Cyrtodactylus darevskii sp. nov.
   and Cyrt-odactylus multiporus sp. nov., are described from a small area
   in monsoon tropical forests on limestone in the environs of Nahome
   Village, Boulapha District, Khammouane Province, Central Annamites.
   Cyrt-odactylus darevskii sp. nov. differs from all other Laotian
   Cyrtodactylus by a combination of the following morphological
   characters: (1) maximum SVL up to 100 mm; (2) dorsal pattern formed by
   the narrow dark nuchal band and 4-5 dark transverse breaking bands with
   light yellowish posterior edges between limbs; (4) 38-46 ventral scales;
   (5) continuous series of 38-44 precloacal and femoral pores in males and
   24-34 precloacal and femoral pores in females; (6) preclocal groove
   lacking; (7) 4-5 postcloacal spurs present in both sexes; (8) one median
   row of subcaudal scales. Cyrtodactylus khammouanensis sp. nov. appears
   to be closely related to the recently described C. jaegeri Luu et. al.,
   2014 and can be distinguished from this species and the remaining
   Laotian congeners by a combination of the following morphological
   features: (1) medium size, with a maximum SVL up to 73 mm; (2) males
   with continuous series of 40-44 precloacal and femoral pores; (3)
   preclocal groove lacking; (4) 32-38 longitudinal rows of ventral scales
   at midbody; (5) weakly keeled tubercles present on the dorsum and
   lacking on the head; (6) 5-6 enlarged postcloacal spurs in both sexes;
   (8) one median row of subcaudal scales; (7) dorsal pattern consisting of
   wide dark nuchal band and 4-5 dark wide transverse bands. Cyrtodactylus
   multiporus sp. nov. is distinguished by a combination of the following
   morphological attributes: (1) maximum SVL of up to 98 mm; (2) dorsal
   patterns consisting of dark irregular separate spots between limbs and
   on the dorsal surface of the head; (3) nuchal band absent; (4) 30-38
   ventrals; (5) continuous series of 58-60 precloacal and femoral pores in
   males; (6) preclocal groove lacking; (7) 5-6 postcloacal spurs present
   in both sexes; (8) one median row of subcaudal scales. Cyrtodactylus
   spelaeus sp. nov. is described from a cave in north of Vientiane
   Province of Laos and differs from other congeners by a combination of
   the following characters: (1) maximum SVL of 98 mm; (2) dorsal pattern
   formed by oblong dark irregular butterflyshaped blotches with light
   contrast margins; (3) nuchal band with light edging consists of two
   separate parts, which contact in occipital region; (4) 37-39 ventral
   scales; (5) 7-8 precloacal pores in males; (5) preclocal groove lacking;
   (6) 2-3 postcloacal spurs present in both sexes; (7) ten rows of
   enlarged dorsal tubercles. Our study increase the number of
   Cyrtodactylus species known for Laos to fifteen. COI DNA-barcoding is
   successfully applied to reveal cryptic diversity within the genus
   Cyrt-odactylus.
C1 Nazarov, R.A.; Moscow State Univ, Zool Museum, B Nikitskaya St 6,
   Moscow, 125009, Russia, Russia.
EM r_nazarov@mail.ru
SC Evolutionary Biology; Zoology
SN 0206-0477
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Evolution; Land zones; Oriental
   region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Cyrtodactylus [Phylogeny /  / Systematics] [Laos /  / distribution]. 
   Cyrtodactylus darevskii; Cyrtodactylus khammouanensis; Cyrtodactylus
   multiporus; Cyrtodactylus spelaeus [Laos /  / New species]. 
TN Chordates; Reptiles; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Reptilia, Lepidosauria, Squamata,
   Sauria, Gekkonidae
OR Cyrtodactylus (Gekkonidae). 
   Cyrtodactylus darevskii (Gekkonidae): [Sp nov, Laos, P. 402]. 
   Cyrtodactylus khammouanensis (Gekkonidae): [Sp nov, Laos, P. 406]. 
   Cyrtodactylus multiporus (Gekkonidae): [Sp nov, Laos, P. 410]. 
   Cyrtodactylus spelaeus (Gekkonidae): [Sp nov, Laos, P. 414].

PT J
AN ZOOR15408052650
DT Article
TI Diet Composition of Hawksbill Turtles (Eretmochelys imbricata) in the
   Republic of Seychelles.
AU von Brandis, R.G. (rainer@saveourseas.com) 
   Mortimer, J.A.
   Reilly, B.K.
   van Soest, R.W.M.
   Branch, G.M.
SO Western Indian Ocean Journal of Marine Science
VL 13
IS 1
PS 81-91
PD Jan 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Effective conservation of the critically endangered hawksbill turtle
   (Fretmochelys imbricata) in the western Indian Ocean is hindered by a
   lack of basic ecological information about its diet and habitat
   requirements. This study utilised stomach samples from dead turtles and
   oesophageal lavage. together with in-water observations of foraging
   turtles, to identify the relative importance of species contributing to
   the diet of hawksbill turtles at five localities in the Republic of
   Seychelles. Diets were remarkably similar to those of hawksbill turtles
   from the Atlantic and Pacific in that they fed predominantly on
   demosponges and anthozoans. In total, ten demosponges, four anthozoans,
   three seaweeds, one seagrass, one ascidian and the egg cases of a
   mollusc were identified. The most prevalent taxa encountered were
   Stelletta sp., Spheciospongia sp. (both demosponges) and Zoanthus
   sansibaricus (anthozoan). Five genera are new to the global list of taxa
   consumed by hawksbill turtles. viz. Stelletta, Rhabdastrella, Haliclona,
   Pseudoceratina and Discosoma. The relative merits of the various methods
   of dietary determination am discussed and it is concluded that in-water
   observations of turtle feeding yields results that are in many ways
   superior to oesophageal lavage or the collection of gut contents from
   dead animals. Recommendations am made for further research and
   conservation efforts, including the identification of adult hawksbill
   foraging grounds offshore. and the protection of habitats rich in
   hawksbill food.
C1 von Brandis, R.G.; Save Our Seas Fdn SOSF, DArros Res Ctr DRC, Rue
   Philippe Plantamour 20, Geneva, CH-1201, Switzerland, Switzerland.
EM rainer@saveourseas.com
SC Nutrition &Dietetics; Zoology; Anatomy &Morphology; Environmental
   Sciences &Ecology
SN 0856-860X
BD Nutrition; Feeding behaviour; Digestive system; Ecology; Habitat
   utilization; Marine zones; Indian Ocean
DE Eretmochelys imbricata [Diet / Dietary composition / ] [Foraging /  / ]
   [Stomach /  / ] [Habitat preference / Habitat suitability / ] [South
   Indian Ocean / Seychelles / ]. 
TN Chordates; Reptiles; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Reptilia, Anapsida, Testudines,
   Cryptodira, Cheloniidae
OR Eretmochelys imbricata (Cheloniidae). 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15408052650

DT Article
TI Schistura sexnubes, a new diminutive river loach from the upper Mekong
   basin, Yunnan Province, China (Teleostei: Cypriniformes: Nemacheilidae).
AU Endruweit, Marco
SO Zoological Research
VL 35
IS 1
PS 59-66
PD Jan 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB An ichthyofaunistic survey of Mekong tributaries in Lincang Prefecture,
   Yunnan Province, China yielded a new species of nemacheilid loach,
   herein described as Schistura sexnubes species nova. The new species is
   readily distinguishable from its congeners by the following combination
   of characters: 8+8 branched caudal fin rays, an incomplete lateral line,
   a dissociated caudal bar, a shallow caudal peduncle depth (7.6%-9.6% SL;
   respectively caudal peduncle 1.76-1.95 times longer than deep), a
   diminutive size of less than 50 mm SL, and no sexual dimorphism. A
   dorsocephalic pattern consisting of a black, forward directed V-shaped
   formation located between the nares, and a white, ovoid blotch on the
   upper operculum serves as an autapomorphy.
SC Zoology
SN 0254-5853
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Land zones; Palaearctic
   region; Eurasia; Asia; China
DE Schistura sexnubes [Yunnan /  / New species]. 
TN Chordates; Fish; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Pisces, Osteichthyes, Actinopterygii,
   Cypriniformes, Balitoridae
OR Nemacheilidae (Cypriniformes): [Diagnostic characters of subordinate
   taxa, P. 61]. 
   Schistura sexnubes (Balitoridae): [Sp nov, Yunnan, P. 60].
